content:
ber 27, 2014
												Edit: This was a review of the EARLY ACCESS! This does not reflect the new content added in the update, but once I play the retail version enough, I will be sure to update!For a while I have been looking for a good open-world space game, with nothing really looking like a decent game. For me, spore is the most experience with a space-style game, which I really loved, but I wanted to move on to better things. Then I saw Starpoint Gemini 2 in development. After watching some videos and seeing how fantastic the game looked, I decided to buy it, which was an excellent decision and one that I recommend anyone reading this review to follow.Little more needs to be said about the visuals. They are fantastic. Combat is also really well done, and content is surprising since it is still in development and only has one gamemode so far. The most disappointing thing about this game for me was that there is no option to actually explore planets. This is purely a space exploration game, which of course is why the price is not rediculously high and is very reasonably priced especially for a game so modern that it is still in development. That limitation is really the one thing which is keeping this from being my dream game, but it is definitely fantastic for what it was designed for. Just make sure to dock whenever possible so that you can save and not lose a ton of progress!Overall, I definitely recommend this game whether you are new to the space scene or a veteran. Especially at this price point, it is an excellent buy!

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 28, 2014
												This game can be summed up as a modern day Freelancer, but with capital ships instead of fighters. It shares many similarities with the aforementioned game, as well as some enjoyable improvements, and will probably be the best single player Freelancer-style space sim available for a good while. With Star Citizen focused on multiplayer, look no further than Starpoint Gemini 2 to fill the gap between the two.Like Freelancer, you can play with keyboard and mouse, with a rather familiar flight control style to Freelancer players. But although SG2 offers support for other gaming controllers, it's far from polished right now - it's near-enough unplayable with the popular Saitek X52 HOTAS, given the rediculous deadzone on all axes. However, if anything, the keyboard and mouse feels more natural to use in this game anyway, given you're playing the role as a ship (and later, fleet) commander.Comparing this game to the failure that was X-Rebirth, SG2 comes out on top. Although more arcady, SG2 is significantly more enjoyable from the getgo.

Early Access Review
								This is a great game. Like all space sim/action/whatever, it takes a little to get comfortable with all the controls. There is so far only one real thing I'd change. There is a sense of "I'm never ever gonna be able to afford that...". The experience gained from freelancer missions is way too freaking small, and the upgrades to weapons are insanely expensive, not to mention I have no real idea how much of a boost they are giving me, because the data doesn't have % signs or adjustments shown.So really, it's a great game. Period. It seems like it would never end really, which is great. But I still have no sense of how long it will take to get to higher levels, because right now I'm level 3 (so like 6300/9000 points to next level) and each of these freelancer missions gets me like 50 freaking points! So I'm asuming never.I know I am just griping about that over and over, but that's it, that's the only drawback. Other than that, it has everything you want in a space RPG. Exploring, mining, upgrading, fighting (which is pretty hard, but really fun), assassinations, etc.

								for those that wish a space trader/shooter/free movment around the universe well worth while i have been playing it now for a good 16 hours. there is a few things i like and dont like they are as follows. good first. i love freelancer and i always will. but after the main mission there really wasent much to do  but it let me be a good guy  a pirate  access to alian weapons  etc  was good fun.  look im not going to say this is the best game ever. the potential could be one of the best out there look for  $15-$20 you will get every pennys worth and a lot more. this is now the beta version and it will still crash on you do  save as often as you can  moneys hard to get large amounts at this stage  making around 300-400k for around 4-5 hours work seems the normif you like ship to ship combat there is a few interesting aspects with the combat system that i found  fun and interesting everytime you pass a new area there is always  new quests anything from vip needs a taxi to a station or planet pays well. matanamce on satalights  anomalyes scaned for  sience, s.o.s help ship out  etc. the map size  is huge take you a month to just fill the map in great potential for multi play down the track, i would like to see if you run as a trader  what price you get from each planet or starport what they would buy and  what they have for sell this would be a must to make it a ledgend game  ( ow sorry for the spelling mistakes i know  i suck hehe ) as games go out of 10  7.5  potental 10 graphics 9 sound 8 easy to use or play they have tryed to keep it simple and complex 7  anyone buying this for a fun game you wont regret buying it  i am actually getting excited  what will they do nextso enjoy have fun and might see you out there in the galaxy one day

content:
17, 2014
Early Access Review
								After playing EVE Online (Non-Steam) I've been really looking for a space-sim similar to it but an offline version. X3 (Non-Steam) was the best one I've played so far, and Rebirth I've never touched because it looked pretty disappointing.Music: The tracks so far are good and fit the game well but there's only 4 tracks I've heard so far but hopefully more will come.Gameplay: Depending on the class you pick, you'll have a set of skills that you can utilize in combat or other purposes, there's a leveling system as well which you progress by doing missions, mining, exploring new sectors, repairing ships/stations, scanning anomalies and blowing other ships up, with this in mind the game felt like it was a Space Sim/RPG mix to me. Combat is good, I have freedom of movement and aim. It's also cool how you have troopers on your ship and you can get them to board other ships, unfortunately I never succeded.Graphics: Ship/Station models, anomalies look decent, the background looks excellent, planets look ok but overall the game looks great.Single Player: So far there's only a Sandbox mode where you can do whatever you want, there's no story mode at the moment but they have said that they are working on it and we'll probably end up seeing it sooner or later.Summary: Starpoint Gemini 2 has alot of potential and It's pretty good for an early access title, so far I've enjoyed my time with and will continue playing it. One thing I would love to see is the ability to actually fly into the planets and explore the landscapes, not just dock on the planets with a menu and what not.

												One of the most fun games I have ever played...Got a half decent ship by smuggling some weed between 2 planets, actually made a killing of that until the cops caught me and I lost reputation in the area which basically put me on the line between "friendly" and "enemy"  so they almost killed me...I came back though...Upgraded my ship with a cloaking system..now the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s can't see this weed smuggler..I skipped the campaign and I am just playing as a Trader Currently and it is quite a bit of fun..only had the game for a little while and its starting to become my go to chillaxing game...the mod support/Workshop support is amazing...hopefully more people catch on and develop some mods =)We have StarTrek and some OP ship mods but thats about it.Picked mine up for $10 on ♥♥♥, I would say this game in its current state is worth $15 maximum....$10-5 when StarCitizen Releases.

content:
er 27, 2014
												Very enjoyable, a bit rough around the edges.Even with a few issues (voiceover audio not playing, no docking animations, navigation issues when you hit go-to when you're next to a station you've docked at, etc.) this game is very, very fun.Unlike the space sims before it (Freelancer) and the modern ones coming out (Elite: Dangerous and Star Citizen) which focus on the mechanics of a more agile fighter, Starpoint Gemini 2 focuses much more on a capitol ship feel. You're not a lone pilot darting through space in a dogfight, you're sitting at the helm of a Carrier, deploying fighters, and watching your crew unload your ship's payload. Power management is stressed, as is the use of powers and items that bolster shields, shut down enemy systems, etc. One thing I love about this game which I have not yet seen in another space sim is the ability to send your troops over to capture another ship. This happens to be one of the best ways to make money, and is extremely fun.Unfortunately it doesn't give you any experience (which seems a little peculiar, considering it's an integral part of many people's strategies), but the payout is fantastic.All in all, worth buying, though I haven't played it since Elite: Dangerous came out lol

content:
14, 2014
Early Access Review
								You can pilot anything from a gunship to a carrier (you can NOT pilot fighters, they are launched from carrier class vessels), do freelance missions like assassinations (destroying marked ships), assistance (Fight off attackers and protect a ship). However the ships you have to destroy are not necessarily your enemy, in fact they could be allies!The game might be in alpha (going in to beta very soon), and there are bugs/missing features (Alpha is alpha after all). But in it's current state it is highly playable and very fun for anyone interested in piloting their own spacecraft, and the developers interaction with their playerbase is very commendable. I see them answering questions in almost every quistion topic here on steam, and they are active on their own forumes as well.I have heard the original Starpoint Gemini was not that good (I have not played it myself), and if that is so: do not fear, this game, even in alpha, is very enjoyable. Any spacesim enthusiast will get their moneys worth, and then some!

, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is like what others have said, lacking in entertaining content for the moment, story, challenge on demand, and does have you with little to do after a certain amount of time.However, i still recomend this as a purchase for early access and most definitly recomend feature complete status on-ward.The game runs smoothly and brilliantly, and how many early access games can you say has a games workshop up n running at this stage? there are 3 ships available right now in the workshop from star trek, one of the three is one im unfamiliar with, so perhaps an original model idea. new content will steadily flow into this game that has had me checking every other day for new workshop mods or new patches that allows for entertainment in of itself. I recomend early access to people who would actually want to see a game develop into something new and unique, you can help using the workshop, and even if you dont have the skills, they do not kid around when they say they are using OUR idea's. Suggest something in the forums, however simple or elaborate as you like and they WILL consider it.There are compenies we've seen who have had amazing communities launching suggestion barrages at them just ignore every single one and watched as the game died off (i have one in mind specifically for this =p) yet here, just take a look at the forums, at how often you get responses from the dev's in regards to suggestions. I've heard of a wish list that includes a unicorn! This is a game to keep an eye on at the very least, i feel we'll see great things from this gem in future.

r 13, 2014
												Alright. So...Downsides:1. There's a Commander class that benefits fleet and the best you can do for a "fleet" is hire 2 mercenaries later in the game.2. The map is THE BIGGEST FREE ROAM I'VE EVER SEEN. And it takes forever to get anywhere even with the PTE speed.3. First 4 campaign missions are travels (you kill like 2 ships) that take 5mins of travel time each if you don't get sidetracked. (Haven't gotten further yet)4. When mining, debris containing your precious loots flys everywhere faster than your ship moves, slowing the process.Upsides:1. The map is THE BIGGEST FREE ROAM I'VE EVER SEEN. I've spent almost 6 hours trying to open 10% of the map up. I've explored basically none of it, but now I know where the faction structures are for a little bit of a corner of a section of the map.2. Auto-aim from Open Fire actually leads the target instead of dicking around with straight shots based on current location. Awesome job.3. The ship types are easy enough to learn and yet there are enough of them to still have a good enough variety.4. Graphics are decent.5. You mine the same way you fight. By blowing ♥♥♥♥ up with your weapon systems.6. The ship you start with is more than enough to ♥♥♥♥ around and get work done for a while (so far all I had to replace was the weapon system).7. Enemies spawn/warp in often enough you don't have to explore to find cargo to sell. And they won't persue you fast enough that you can get away fairly quickly without much worry. 8. The radar/scanner/mini-map is easy to understand as long as you're not a brick.9. Middle Mouse Button is your friend.10. Controls take a minute to get used to during combat, but you'll pick it up pretty quick since you just have to worry about positioning/dodging instead of aiming your light weapons.11. There's still a challenge when you're fighting in big fights.10/10 worth my money and time so far. Haven't played far into the campaign but I'll see how that goes, also. Awesome first empression and I definitely suggest dicking around in freeroam instead of starting with the campaing to figure stuff out, then turning off tutorials in campaign for a smoother ride.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
ry 16
												I'm not sure how to review this one. There are some issues that I have with it that are just hallmarks of past space sims. So if you hate typical downsides of space sims, then this game doesn't really break that barrier. If you're not a fan of classic space sims, then this game doesn't deliver much outside of that. But first off, I got this game when it was 80% off 2 years after it released. I got it primarily to scratch that never-ending itch of playing a worthwile space sim while waiting for Star Citizen to be a more complete game. My review is about the base game with its base story missions and content.The main campaign is a revenge story of a son wanting justice for his dad's murder, but like past sci-fi games it quickly evolves into you saving the whole world or in this case a solar system. Cliched, I know, but I won't spoil it. The story likely took me about 8 hours to complete which I expected for a game like this. Like previous space sims before it, it allows you to do whatever you want and start any mission you want after the initial mission without an artificial lock like you need to be level X to do mission Y. Personally, I like that in open world games. There are supposedly 13 non-story mission types that are randomly generated on the map, but depending on your ship these missions can range anywhere from super easy or downright impossible. That was my first problem with this game. The randomly-created missions support the grindiness aspect of the game, and the rewards often feel lackluster even after progressing so far into the game. When you've done one ferry mission or security mission, you've done them all. There's no variation in each mission type. Just a difference in NPC ship difficulty. That's where problem 2 comes in.You can mine asteroids, crystals, and pockets of gas in certain sectors of the map that will reward you depending on the market value and how big your cargo hold can take. After getting the ship with the most cargo capacity and mining said sectors, the tediusness and grindiness settles in quick. If you like that aspect of space sims, where grinding = bigger and better ship then this is right up your alley. If not, then look elsewhere. Personally, after ~50 some hours of mining, salvaging, bounty hunting, raiding commercial ships and stations, escorting/protecting/rescuing NPCs and scanning space anomalies, I feel like this game scratched that itch. I can't say I enjoyed the whole grind experience, but I did feel satisfaction upon earning one of the best ships in the game. Once you get past the tedium and set up a ship goal, hours did fly for me by working up the reputation and credits to earn it. If you expect not to grind for a better ship, then expect to mod the game or not get the game at all.The leveling system is typical with missions giving you x amount of credits and experience points. You use these points to level up different abilities for one of three chosen classes (commander, gunner, engineer) that activate in-game to give your ship better stats momentarily like faster speed, more weapon damage, faster shield regeneration, etc. The reputation system is binary where doing missions for X faction will yield Y rep points and -Y rep for the opposing faction. You can side with "bad" factions, stay lawful/chaotic neutral, or side with "good" factions. I chose to be lawful good throughout the game, like a good boy scout that I try to be irl. Siding with either faction will either open or close certain planets and stations which will lock you out of a certain achievement if you're not neutral. It's a lot harder to stay neutral because the story doesn't let you choose outcomes and there aren't enough non-story missions that will help keep you neutral. So what's my problem with this? The leveling system on top of the grindy non-story missions really does show how tedius this game can get. It doesn't really get better once you reach your ship goal. I'm still left with the same missions and rewards that don't scale as much as I wanted it to.You'd think that once you're Commander Badass with a Dreadnought, fighter ships you can deploy and merc ships you can hire, that you'd be making bank by melting everything in sight with your plasma cannons. Nope. I still have to mine/salvage/scan/trade ad infinitum to make serious money. Having a bigger ship does help with not dying every 10 minutes or so from seemingly random incursions with other giant ships, often multiple giant ships to contend with. That's another problem I have with this game. NPC ships that scale from a trivial threat to impossible come out of nowhere at random times. Even when you're technically in safe sectors of space, NPCs that are against your faction (which to me is every bad guy in the game) will spawn or decloak out of nowhere and proceed to tear you a new one very early in the game, until you have one of the best ships then you can go toe to toe with one of them. If dying repeatedly due to random incursions regardless of where you are in the map isn't your thing, then that's a big problem. I get it, space is dangerous and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s can be anywhere in the vast emptiness of space. But if I'm 10 seconds away from the good guys Navy fleet, you'd think that pirates and marauders wouldn't go that close and tear you a new one. If/when I create a chaotic evil character save, I will update this review to reflect my experience being on the other side of the law.One aspect I failed to use in this game before this review are mods from the Steam workshop. They range from quality of life mods (better loot, more damage, faster speed) to custom assets in game (ships, stations, missions, etc.) to total conversions, so fellow Star Trek fans will be able to scratch that itch.I'd like to say that after ~60 hours of playing this game, I will recommend it to fans of classic space sims with the caveat that there is a space sim grind to it and that it doesn't hold your hand. If you're looking for a revolutionary game that breaks the typical downsides of space sims, then please look elsewhere. If you know that you want to scratch that classic space sim itch with the understanding of the problems that I've explained above, then I do recommend this game to you.

content:
8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Being a SCI-Fi fan, it brings me much joy to review SPG2. This is an awesome space sim/ fighter game in which you command one of many space worthy vessels against pirates, factions and even natural elements like radiation which will wreak havok on your ship and crew. There are missions, faction missions, mining and salvage operations, and if your more about chaos and destruction then you can go around hijacking other ships to add to your own collection or sell, its all up to you. Currently the game is still in Beta and the game has its bugs and balancing issues but the Devs are always hard at work bringing constant updates and answering questions from the community, which is a major plus these days. The game at is current state is beautiful to look at with many various galaxies, planets and space stations, this game easily surpasses other sims that have already had time to mature. Future updates include strory lines, more complex missions, and ships, also the list as the devs have called it is always growing from ideas of players and the community as a whole. So if you love space, ships, fighting, customization, looting, selling and RPG elements then this is the game for you, trust me when I say you wont regret it.

content:
r 2, 2014
												Da. Best. And that is an exact measurement.  Starpoint Gemini 2 successfully brings the open world 3D single player RPG to space.  Some may say that sprpg is past its prime but SG2 didn't get that memo because this game doesn't feel dated at all and includes all the modern accessories like side quests, an engaging story, lots of skills and ranks and points to customize your character, hireable mercenaries, customizable ships (oh yea), and some awesome new stuff to make you feel like you are not only piloting, but commanding a fleet.  I played this game a lot during early access and I said then that this game had the potential to be awesome if executed correctly and man was it ever!  On top of all that your ship is a whole character of its own with everything from frail gunships to massive carriers that can cloak themselves and launch entire fighter wings from their carrier bays! I would recommend this game to anyone who has suffering in the drought of good space games and anyone who enjoys rpgs.  Oh and [name redacted] this isn't Eve, you get to shoot the guns and do stuff.

content:
r 13, 2014
												Alreet peeps, so this is my experience shot and review. So first things first id like to recommend this title and hope you enjoy it as much as i did.  This however will just be a general impression not a rating or in depth review.Reasons : I'm coming from the original Starpoint Gemini and really enjoyed it for its single player freelancer style of gameplay. I picked it up in early access which i dont usualy go for but due to my experience with the original i toke a chance, this was not a mistake though as the title has come along way since i originaly purchased this.Graphical: not cutting edge but still a really good looking game. fx to physics all of which are well made and are still being refined even after full release.Sound assets : I have no ear for sound effects but they where up to standard, no odd sounds that ruined the experience.Performance : Runs great. I dont have a uber rig, i run a very avarge system and this game runs great even in larger battles.Content: A good solid campaign backed up with a freeroam mode that allows you to strip away the main story and play the universe in the way you want to. So many ships that you wont get to fly them all in one play through i reckon even with a few play throughs you will find some new ship to fly, some new mission and or enemy to beat up on. Also the ability to play as a peace keeper or as a bandit.faults : no borderless window mode and lack of a multiplayer.Overhall: Solid singleplayer title that if you like freelancer / startrek online / x3 then your gonna be at home with this title. Defo pick this up and i pretty sure you will enjoy whats here and whats coming in the future as the team behind this is great and im sure this game can only get better.Update- the original games campaign reto fitted into this game for free!, why cant all develpers do this. Perfect actualy prefect.Stay Frosty

content:
r 18, 2014
												This game has lots of flaws, but I like it so much since it's the game i've been looking for a long time.PROS:-Absolutely beautiful, the way the binary stars cast shadows on asteroids, to the way distant nebulae appear giant and intimidating-Most of the locations you see in space are reachable-Great soundtrack-You can be what you want, a pirate, trader, privateer, whatever-Lots of ships-Lots of modules and countless ways to setup your loadout-For a space game, the environment is extremely varied-Boarding and stealing a ship feels damn good-MODDING!!!!!1111111!!11MIXED:-Probably just me, but the trading and interface feel to simple; after playing EVE Online for so long, the UI feels like it needs more-The active ability RPG portion feels tacked on, I find myself almost always autofiring; at least never using my 1-4 keys-Sometimes the autopilot glitches out and it's hilarious; I like to think of it as a feature-Doesn't have SLI support, unless forced through a third party program like NVidia inspector or even just the control panel. However, once you do force it, it runs really nice (minus some annoying microstuttering).CONS:-The downscaling of the universe is really obvious and weird-Things pop in a lot, like anomalies and stations-Bad sound effect design, especially in weapon firing sounds-Inconsistant graphics, some things are really highly detailed while others look like they came out of a 2006 game-Missions get repetitive, and if you strip all the lore and factions away, all the gameplay is literally the same, minus enemies getting tougher over timeCool game, go buy, shoot ships in the face.

content:
er 6, 2014
												I haven't played this game for too long but it has proven to be very fun and challenging.  I am currently playing through the campaign but I am also conducting side missions.  The side missions include (from what I have seen so far): assassination of trouble makers, repairing installations, bounty hunting, and transporting VIPs. I mine asteriods and trade at stations frequently to balance my finances.  Capturing and selling enemy starships have proven to be the most lucrative transaction.  Combat is somewhat confusing at first but the games excellent tutorial guide and fully customizable control menu is very helpful.  Pros:-Good graphics.-Intense space combat.-Can easily change viewing settings - Rudder control"bridge" view, Rudder control third person view, and turret third person view.-Ability to purchase and upgrade several starships.-Can hire mercs and form a fleet. -Large open world to explore.-Many unique ways to "jump"around the map e.g. rifts and wormholes.-Story is ok.-Background music is pretty good and varied.Cons:-No NPCs to interact with at space stations.-No first person perspective.-No ship interior perspective. Mixed:-Fairly steep learning curve to become proficient with all of the games functions.Overall a great indie title!  Give your self lots of time to play this game...it is hard to quit this game for the night!

number of helpful: 9 of 14 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
3, 2016
												Basically Freelancer.Similar to Sid Meier's Pirates but in space. Huge space.Ship customization similar to Mechwarrior's mech customization.Mine asteroids, hunt bounties, play with the market, buy better ships, better equipment, etc.Streamlined user interface.Combat is good. There's several weapon types for you to try out. Rockets, laser beams and plasma cannons to name a few, each with their own properties and upgrades. Get on your gunship and chase enemies by their tail or line up your battleship and bombard them mercilessly. Your choice.Exploration is good. The game gives the player a huge world to explore. Planets, space stations and shipyards that offer different products depending on their region. Planets and space stations act as hubs, you can't set foot on them and explore. Not as huge as Elite Dangerous but huge nonetheless. Music is good. Too bad there's not much to go around. If you have a space exploration playlist then add this game's music to that playlist and play that instead.Economy is there. Trade clean goods or contraband. You can take advantage of rising and falling prices of materials but the economy isn't deep enough to make it an engaging enterprise. You can mine asteroids or scavenge space junk while going about your trade route, I guess.CAN'T FORM A FLEET. You can capture enemy ships. You either sell them, keep them or scrap them. Keeping them puts them in your garage. You can switch between ships YOU CAN ONLY USE ONE SHIP AT ANY TIME. The closest to a fleet you'll get is by hiring mercenaries to fly with you for a price. Even then you can't command them. This is probably the worst negative point of the game in my opinion.Light RPG elements.A good space game overall but if you're into trading, playing with the economy or empire building then this game won't satisfy you. I bought this on sale at 80% off so it's more than worth the money.

content:
, 2015
												I remember getting this game when it was still in its alpha/beta form with only a few things to do besides blowing up ships, blowing up asteroids, taking their goods, and then selling them at a market for a few dollars (which seemed weird back then because ships cost a ♥♥♥♥ TON and still do, but there are ways to get more money now.) So playing now, seeing that it is full release form, welllllll....it's still empty. I mean, there is absolutely almost nothing going on except for an occasional enemy ship flying in to a friendly territory that gets obliterated in a second. Other than that, nope, nothing. People that hate you, hate you and people that like you, like you, not much else. I thought it'd be awesome to be the revered space pirate captain who steals from all and gets in the way of people to scavenge as much money as possible, even between factions. Which is another huge problem, factions do not feel like they have bad ties between each other, it's as if they are both completely isolated with their borders set in place without anything in between. And there aren't even any huge battles as well, the closest one I got was between myself and 30 other enemy ships. So you might ask, "What is there to do?" Well, exactly what I explained at the beginning, you do missions, kill enemies, blow up debris and turn it into a station for some money, like, a little amount of money. And the most money you get is from ship debris -floating ship debris and destroyed ships- which on maximum with the stock ship which can only hold 45 units is about $30,000 maximum give or take. So how much does an upgraded ship minus weapons cost? Depending on your preference from the different types, a direct upgrade would be from 2-5 mil even though it can go higher to prices of 30 million. So with mining and missions ranging in price from 10-20 thousand, you're looking at doing this 66 times to afford a new ship and that's at the maximum you'll get from mining and missions just for a 2 mil ship. Yes, there are hero ships that give you about 5 mil if you destroy them, but so far I've found no real way to track them other than hearing the news saying they are in so-and-so region, and even if you do find them, they are at impossible difficulty and usually have other ships around them so good luck. Did I have fun though? Yes, I had fun in some parts when I tried to dodge enemy ships while firing, but after your first few things to do it gets incredibly boring.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 29, 2014
												There are ultra realistic space sims,  there are slow paced datasheet space sims,  and on and on and on you can go down the laundry list of space games.   What Starpoint Gemini 2 seeks to accomplish is finding a healthy balance of it's predecessors without leaning too far in any particular direction.   Make no mistake,  SG2 will take you hours to accomplish anything substantial,  but it won't take you hours to start doing something fun.  Want to be a trader?  You can do that.   Want to mine for rare materials?  You can do that.  Want to be a pirate?  You'll eventually be able to do that.  Want to be the force of good bringing bad guys to justice while getting paid for your bounty kills?  You can do that to.    My 7 hours have been mostly spent divided between the three classes that you can choose from in the freeform game.  There is the Leader,  Gunner and Engineer.   Each class provides a fairly substantial difference on terms of feel however the common objective between most of these skills is all the same...   kill your enemy.   I was a bit disappointed to see that many of these skills are not overly helpful for more mundane tasks like mining,  trading,  or exploration.  Seeing as how the game puts heavy emphasis on providing you options - this particular part said to me "We're only truly designing this game with combat in mind".   While the other things to do are definitely not afterthoughts,  they're not quite as fleshed out and as robust as I would have liked.There is a story mode but unfortunately the voice acting is horrible.  Normally I can manage some bad voice acting but found this to be a bit too much.  This turned out to be alright in the end as the sandbox aspects of this game are fun and easy to get into.  The tutorial or lack there of was at least filled with a pop-up tips menu which got me rolling quickly enough.  I had to spend some time rummaging through the keybind menu but after that I was off and racing.  This game still feels very young with a lot of possiblities.  My 7 hours is definitely not enough time to even have a completely firm grasp of what the late game or even middle game will be like but I have a hunch it's going to just be more of the same but with higher stakes involved.  Instead of combat with 3-6 ships,  it'll be more along the lines of 10-20 ships if the trailers and other various videos are telling a truthful tale.   Scaling of this nature is not altogether a bad thing if you're having fun with everything you're doing at the start of the game.  Essentially,  it's not going to mix up the formula a whole lot as you get deeper into the game.  Sure you'll be able to use more skills due to having higher energy and more points to place down extra turrets and systems...  but most of those tools could be used at the start of the game as well,  just within limitations.   If I could pick one thing I wish this game had, it would be co-op support.  Sharing a universe with 2-16 friends could serve for some amazing lan or house hold family fun.  Luckily the mod community seems to be getting behind this game so at the very least the variety of things to do will be getting mixed up a lot.  If you're still on the fence of this game I'd say just keep checking back.  Look at what the devs and the mod community are up to.  There is already a decent amount to do here and it's just done well.   If I had to give it a 1-10 rating I'd say we have ourselves an 8.2 with the clear opportunity to become a 9-9.5 if they continue to add features.   If you're someone who enjoys smelling the flowers and doing assorted tasks with some grinding mechancis involved due to large credit costs to purchase anything substantial,  then this game is the game for you!Give me a thumbs up if you found this review useful.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
r 8, 2014
												One of the first Space-sim type of games I have found fun in quite a while. The controls/UI wont scare you away and are very functional, and the game feels pretty polished for a new release. While combat only missions are getting slightly repetitive I find the combat itself is very fun if you use manual aim and avoid just getting into a rythym of auto-fire on locked targets. It adds more challenge to the combat and keeps it fresh every encounter trying to dodge incoming fire while positioning yourself correctly to fire your batteries and having to stay on your toes while aiming. I have been seeing a lot of threads calling combat "lackluster" or boring, but every one of them have been people using auto-aim and most likely just flying circles around the enemy ships haha. Of course that would become boring quickly, and the manual aiming is what makes me like this game more than a lot of other space sims that do not even have that option.On top of the combat there is trading(though not really worth it right now, but patches will surely improve it), mining, and boarding enemy ships to capture and haul back for good cash or to use it yourself. Mercenaries have been fixed in the latest patch as well which I have yet to try so cannot comment on that(allies that fly with you and help in combat which you can control to an extent). The campaign is pretty basic, but it has a decent story going on and gives you something else to do on the side when you get bored of freelance missions, mining, or trading to get into better ships and better upgrades for each ship. All in all I am enjoying the game and can't wait to see what else is added down the line(devs have already confirmed they want to add more endgame with station ownership and faction warfare). And to top it all off you can already mod the game and there a few complete revamps already even though the game has just released. Highly recommended if you liked any older space-sims like Freelancer or the like.

That being said it’s the best addition the genre in years. i may be speaking too soon as the developers seem to have fair bit of steam left for adding and fixing things up too.The game plays like a more arcade version of the X series it reminds me a lot of X rebirth without all the complete fail. It’s simple and fast paced space action that falls between somewhere between dog fighting and EVE online ship management and thankfully nothing like the orginal starpoint gemini.ProsBest, fight, trade and explore game in years.Solid graphicsDecent universe to exploreReasonably fast and action packedOngoing development ConsSeems 90% FinishedNo empire building Shipload equipment and loadout overly simple.Campaign worth avoiding – just don’t

content:
r 10, 2014
												I can't believe how awesome this game is. I just roam around and upgrade my (Weapons, shields, etc). Doing random mission trying to save up enough money to buy a new ship. There are so many ships with different stats, so its nice to find a ship that fits to your game-play. Like one that has great guns and shield for dogfights. Or huge freighters used for trading and mining. Also as you do more missions you began to improve your rank, What that basically means is you can control bigger and badder ships. Eventually you will feel the awesome power of Dreadnoughts or Carriers. These ships have more slots for weapons and diffrent weapons, just to customize it the way you like it. Also be careful there are high level ships out there. Some with bounties of 5mill, it's a gamble but if you can defeat them, you get paid bank! I personally love seeing an amazing ship and attacking it, bring it down to it knees. Weakening their defense and killing some of their troops in the process but before I kill them I latch the tractor beam and order my troops to board. If you have more troops (stats) then them you can capture their ship and tow it to the next star base to put in your garage or to sell for good $. I been having a blast.

content:
9, 2016
												I would definately recommend this game... but with some notes of caution.  I consider my self a supporter of 'Little Green Men', because I've always enjoyed their games ( at least the few I have).  However... I feel this one is falling a bit short, and I'm unsure if these are problems they are having issues resolving... or have just given up.  However... the problems that I've seen thus far, are more inconvenient than Game Stopping.There's a serious issue with early game over powering of the enemy.  While I've heard a claim by the developers that this was a Development decision, I personally believe this is a Bug that they haven't been able to resolve.  Basically, when taking a mission which is marked at a specific level, the mission turns out to be impossible to complete even though your level made be higher than the recommended level.  Option:  Run and find another mission and hope this doesn't happen too often... but it will.Another issue deals with Enhancements which can be added to ship's equipment and weapons, but the Enhancements do not actually enhance the item.  Note:  some... not all.Licenses, also, which should provide specific bonus do not work.  Note:  some... not all.Other than the above I have no other negative issues with this game.  It has all of the elements of a Good Space Sim, with many choices on how one wishes to play... Fighter... Merchant... Miner... Salvager... or even pirate.  I usually don't play pirate until I get bored with a game, but don't want to stop and need a new challenge.  however, the problem with being a pirate in many space sims is the limited choices you get; often being more of a headache than anything else.  But with this game I've seen the pirates (or more correctly, the Hostile Factions) have as much territory to operate in as the 'So-Called' Good Guys.  I'm actually looking forward to trying my hand as a pirate.The merchant side of the game is IMHO as well done as it seems to be possible based on the many games I've played, and wanted to be a Merchant.  In short... I don't feel like it's Great... but it does seem Very Good; just haven't got a decent size Cargo Ship for really trying it out.  However... for the little trading I've seen and done... it looks like it has "Very Good" Potential.  Mining for both Ores and Gases was done in a very fun and unique way... which I've been enjoying for the most part.  It doesn't really seem to make as much money as Combat... but then again, this is a Combat Game; I just like mining; with a touch of combat to give me a reason to wake up in the morning.  But you'll still need to focus on combat fairly early just to get a decent ship for mining.Combat was a bit disappointing at first because of the mechanics used to control the ship.  I found it was best to turn on Auto-Fire on all turrets... which seemed a bit Impersonal to me.  However... as I got better with all that you can do to Protect and Enhance you ship in battle... Aiming my Laser became the least of my problems, and I was rather happy I didn't have to worry about that anymore.  But that is a matter of Personal Preference.Also... the Skill and Perk system is fun; I like the fact that you can "Sort Of" custom build yourself for the type of Player and Character you choose.  I'm not a fan of being forced to play a specific character as is done in the Campaign (I feel disconnected to my Character while following the story line), but that, again... is just Personal Preference.  And the fact that I can build him the way I choose is far more important to me.One of the best aspects of this game "To Me" is that Money, thus far, is maintaining it's value.  Too often in Single Player Games you find that Money loses it's value far too soon.  Once you get to your 3rd or 4th ship -or- 20th or 30th level, you find  you start ignoring ways of making money... and just focus on leveling... because there just isn't anything left to buy that you can't afford.  I'm current level 43, and still find myself occasionally trying to scrap together a few Bit Coins to buy that Blaster with the Extra Kick.  I find that once a game's currency loses any real value (or more directly; Need) the game heads down hill from there.  At the time of this writing I have roughly $17mil, and trying to get to $29mil for the next for the next ship I want; but not the last ship I'll fly.All in all; while I got this game on sale, I would not have been disappointed if I had paid full price (assuming full price was under $40).  I definately would recommend this game; with hopes of certain issues being resolved.. but with confidence it's still a Fun and Addictive Game.Enjoy!!!

content:
r 4, 2014
												The latest update has elevated this to the most satisfying trading simulation I have ever had the pleasure of playing. Not only can you see what various commodities are trading for at the stations you have visited, you also see the distance you currently are from each of those stations. This adds another level of decision making – is the extra distance you might have to travel for a ‘best’ price worth the time it will take to get there, or is a slightly lower price actually the better deal? A small thing, perhaps, but it does make you approach your cargo manifest a bit more critically when deciding on what and when to trade.The second thing this encourages is exploration. You only see the prices for the stations and planets you have discovered. I find myself compelled to push into unknown territory on that never ending quest for the ultimate trade route. And the commodity information screen itself is wonderfully easy to use. The filters are a tremendous help, eliminating the need to scroll through every item available. Are you a miner? Click on ores. Love to hunt down pirates? Quickly discover who is offering the best price for those contraband items.As you may have guessed, I’m a merchant at heart, not a fighter. But I’ve found the battles to be well-balanced and a simple click will tell you if that tantalizing enemy ship you have your eye on has the capability to turn you into so much space dust. Not that the knowledge will necessarily stop you, but at least you’ll know what you’re up against. And for those times when you do take on just a bit more than you can chew and yet somehow manage to pull it off by the skin of your shields, well – you know the feeling.The graphics are gorgeous, the gameplay is addicting, and personalizing your ship is as much fun as creating a new character in most RPGs. At this point the only thing I’m hoping for is that we may eventually see a larger collection of avatar portraits. The new group was a nice addition, but as a female gamer I find the two current offerings lack some of the personality that the male portraits possess. And that something so minor is the only flaw I can find says a lot about how truly innovative and honestly fun this game is. Now if you’ll excuse me, I have a trade empire to build.

content:
ber 28, 2014
												It brings back that good feeling of having the galaxy at your fingertips, like in Freelancer and Elite, without the insane complexity of X3 etc. I still feel like I'm just starting out and I've put in some hours allready. It is not the new & perfect game. Some mechanics need some tweaking or better explanation (Turrets, all power to engines, etc.) but you can generally customize your ship to do exactly what you want it to. In particular the open world / sandbox play works nicely.In general I'd recommend the game, but be mindful of what the game is and isn't. It is not the hugely ambitious world of X, but then again, it is much easier to pick up and play; it is relatively approachable, but complex enough that you'll spend the first half hour at least going 'Now what? How do I do this?'. It is worth muddling through, though, if you're interested in this type of game.

Early Access Review
								Tracked one of the most notorious pirates through out several star systems. Cloaked my ship, and carefully positioned myself right behind his engines. Then all at once I unleashed a volley of plasma, beams, and fusion torpedos. After crippling his ship, and his crew members, I launched a viral torpedo to further reduce his fighting force. I next beamed over my superior marine forces and collected the bounty on his head. With his ship a drift, I tractored it to the closest friendly base where I added his battleship to my garage. Now I fly around fighting these pirates in his old ship. Big thumps up for this beta game.

content:
15, 2014
Early Access Review
								Starpoint Gemini 2 maybe an early access game right now but the game feels a lot more complete than a number of new releases. The game is best described as a tactical space simulator in an open universe. The game in early access has no story mission i have found yet but a lot of small missions, exploration,mining and combat. The combat is a joy once you get used to the tactical use of gun turrets and weapon usage. The game has some really interesting ship to ship combat that is easy to get the hang of. Graphics at this stage are  excellant. Ship models are good and the effects are nice and are a lot more polished than what you would think for a game not completed yet. Sound and music are good with a nice musical track (although limited just now but will be increased when ame is finished)Would i recommend this game. Hell yes even at this stage and i look forward to seeing the end product.One other interesting note is the developers are always on the forums answering our questions and listining to our input and shows how dedicated they are to both the project and to their customers.

content:
14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Amazing game. As close to Freelancer 2 as I think we've gotten or will get with next gen sims like Elite and Star Citizen coming out. There's a huge amount of depth here and free play mode is seriously awesome. So far I have...Missions / Trade / Exploration ( the universe is pretty huge and there are no jumpgates, you want to go somewhere be prepared to have a tea and fly it )Boarded and pirate who attacked me while mining. Stole their ship, towed it back to station, 60k profit w/ a hold full of ore as well. Enough to purchase some weapon and power grid upgrades & repair my own hull.Still mining, happily shooting rocks in a deep and immersive asteroid belt miles from any station ( the graphics are fantastic ) again unaffiliated scumbag smuggler drops my shield and attempts to hack my power grid. Fire a grappler, boost shields, send feedback up his signal to shut down his shields instead, steal everything on board, destroy his engines and leave him to die in the darkness.Ships are hugely expensive. Hatched a plan... equip a gunship w/ a cloak and heavy shielding. Observe trade routes and traffic to a wormhole. Wait for lost lamb transport indy with no escorts ( they are tough as nails and heavily armored ) ... decloak, target, fire a grappler, boost shields and tear their ship apart until they surrender, kill everyone on board, towed it to station under a salvage license since it was an independent, now it's mine. All repaired and with a new coat of paint & trade license ( my main job, trading is awesome and dynamic, you need smarts and a good memory of hundreds of stations / planets )Right now I'm flying across the universe in a heavily armored trade / transport ship carrying passengers, 2 vips and sipping a tea on autopilot. 100 thousand K to go, it's going to be a long flight. If anyone needs me I'll be in my cabin.All is quiet... for now.And this is alpha. Srsly.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
2014
Early Access Review
								Starpoint Gemini 2 a sequel with lots of improvements, while keeping to the free form of the predecessor.This game feels as motivating as Freelancer with its extensive Universe to explore, dozens of ships, different ship classes and moddable loadouts.I did enjoy this game very much, it plays like a cross-over between freelancer (free to explore universe, dozens o ships) and the Star Trek Fleet Command titles (tactical fights, commanding capships).Whether you want to relax mining and trading, or engage in combat missions and piracy, this game will be worth its money.Did i mention you can capture enemy ships by boarding combat? You can!If it flies, it is there for the taking!As a captain your first and foremost crucial choice will be your class.You can either be a Commander, featuring buffs for your fleet, empowered strike craft, retaliatory attacks and defensive boosts.Or you can try to outgun the enemy by becoming a Gunner, who can specialize his offensive power by adding effects like disabling hits to his beam weapons, firing more shells with railguns, adding a higher refire rate to his high damaging plasma canons or boosting his heavy weaponry (schockwave cannons, missiles and torpedos).Last but not least the Engineer, a very versatile class with a lot of debuffs.Ever got tired of fast moving corvettes and gunboats dodging your railgun shots?Just place a Rift-Anomaly and slow them down, then hit 'em hard!Your second decision might be to specialize in a ship-category, as you can boost the efficiency of your ship by spending perk-points granted every 5 levels.What will be your choice? A fast and mobile light ship(gunboat/corvette)A merchantship, to rule the market with your cunning? (transport/freighter/freight-liner)A medium class mobile Warship? (Frigate/Destroyer/Cruiser)A vessel of personified dread? (Battleship/Dreadnought/Carrier)The Choice is yours to make, though it is not final,for you can reset your spent skill- and perk-points while being docked to a station or planet and try anew.Currently this game is in Beta Version 0.7, so there are still some issues and lacks:- ingame descriptions of skills and mechanics lack some love and proper english translation - the weapons need some diversity, e.g. faster firing weapons need a higher projectile speed to use them against fast moving targets (railguns and plasma weapons)- boarding combat is currently a numbers game, lacking the predecessors ingame videos and feedback- the missions currently are restricted to Assassination (search and destroy), delivery, repair of beacons and rescue missions- they need to put in some ships from the predecessors (prokhorov for example) to add even more diversity to the allready well modeled and animated ships- ship special abilities are not included yet (like a full frontal arc auto-canon for baeldor frigates or high-energy blasts for dreadnoughts)

content:
27, 2014
Early Access Review
								UPDATE: After lots and lots of play time, I've lost very little enthusiam and this has become my favorite game.If you find yourself missing Freelancer but wishing it was more robust in just about every measure (barring an in-cockpit view), this game is for you. There is a vast universe, seamlessy connected* so that you can fly between them without having to load at a "waygate" like almost every other space game out there. Sure there are gates and wormholes and all the other staples, but they're not necessary. The starter ship is gorgeous, and you can customize the look of your ship in small ways. Combat uses a lot of showy glowy beams that seem to trade off well against each other balance wise, short-ranged instabeams, blaster/plasma-beam-ish projectiles, glowy-trails-having missiles and so on. Your turrets don't just magically fire through your ships, so firing arcs are a concern, and multiple turrets with mismatched areas of defense are possible. You can enlist specialists in your crew who cost you extra expense but provide bonuses, in addition to an amazing range of customizations. You can reassign power between guns-engines-shields on the fly.It's currently an open-world, with promises of guided story plots to come. At the moment you can mine and take run-of-the-mill and short missions, kill this scan that ferry those. You can buy hunting licenses for different groups froim their enemies. The game needs longer more immersive plots, but the dev has already stated there's more to come int hat regard.There's the controls. There is a wide range of things you can do in this game, giving somewhat detailed commands to your fleet and crew, cloaking, grappling (best to shoot the enemies' guns off first), instructing your crew which guns to shoot off first. It is... daunting... looking at your control customization options. I recommend playthrough with the control defaults at first until you find which controls you will actually use best in your personal play style. You will be using just about every key on your keyboard make no mistake.That takes me to the tutorials. Just suffer through them they are awful annoying popups but informative. *this is beta and there's a slight hiccup when moving from grid to grid

content:
r 8, 2014
												This is a fun, engaging "light" strategy / action game. It draws inspiration from both Starfleet Command and EVE online without being nearly as complex as either one. content:
ber 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								As a long-standing fan of the sci-fi genre, I can say that this is the kind of game I've been looking for. It has everything that any space-fan would enjoy! Anomalies, planets, asteroids, nebulas, and tons more! You can trade, customize your starship, upgrade, and fight against pirates as well as enemy factions. The gameplay is unlike anything I've played before, in a good way, and makes it feel like it's ship-on-ship combat. Fighting in space is dynamic, involved, and intricate so it can be challenging at times but never too difficult. The variety of weapons you can add to your starship also helps to give the game a unique feel in combat. The game has the look and expanse of Eve while remaining a single-player only game. Finally, it is workshop/mod friendly! Personally, I like to cross-over different franchises into my games so it's really cool to see a Federation Starship flying around space and using weapons from Star Trek as a way to create a personalized and awesome experience. Definitely would recommend to any sci-fi fan. Better than a lot of AAA titles I've bought. Keep up the good work!

content:
y 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a "first (actually second) impression"It's shaping up.I bought this game a while back, in my seemingly neverending search for a satisfactory Space game.There is a text-only tutorial that I never bothered with, so I can't comment on that. You can skip ahead without worries since you can reread it later on if you need to. Graphics are pretty decent, the ship designs I've seen so far are varied and cool for the most part.The biggest plus part so far, is that this game seems to focus more on capital ship warfare, rather than on fighters and small corvettes like many of its rivals.The interface is also good, albeit a bit unintuitive and at some times utterly unresponsive. Some keybinds don't seem to work and it still needs some visual or audio queues as to what you just did, there is no indication anywhere on your screen whether your weapons are set to free fire or not (at least none I can spot). It seems sandboxy enough so far, with content appearantly procedurally generated and catered to your ship and level.It's a diamond in the rough and clearly unfinished, but already playable enough for me, I will surely be spending some more time in this game than before.So if you have the money and can live with the flaws listed above, give this game a try.

content:
3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Think StarTrek meets Cowboy Bebop. Yes, that good. At this stage in development only two things can be suitably inferred from this game. Its tone and core mechanics. And I am exceptionally pleased with both. Even as an early alpha it is successfully scratching a difficuly itch to reach.I wanted a game where I could zoom around the solar system getting into fights with phasers and torpedos, having to jockey for position all the while balancing my shields, engines, and weapons. SG2 gave me exactly that. The combat is very nice. In its current state the missions are randomly generated, MMO style, filler quests, but this does not prevent the encounters from being very fulfilling, if for no other reason then the solid underlying mechanics. This game will really cause you to think strategically. Will you perform the risky gambit of dumping all power to the shields and weapons to try and pick off a weakened enemy in one pass or will I shift that power into the engines and hope for a second chance to strike at that exposed hole in their shields. As the game progresses you will be making that decision and others as you have to contend with swarms of fighters and imposing warships. It requires just enough of the player to be extremely fulfilling when a risky maneuver works without being unduely frustrating when it fails. And you will fail alot. But the game is at its best when it is challenging. That is when the flexibile thinking and fast micromanagment that characterizes its combat will bring out your inner Jean-Luc Picard. And when it does you will feel great. The tone is harder to express then the mechanics, but is a perfect compliment to them. If you have ever watched Cowboy Bebop then this game will be like putting on a pair of comfortable shoes. Two things drive this feeling. First, the music distinctly reminds me of some of the tracks from the show. There are no jazzy interludes, but the background music reminds me of some prog songs accompanying the space scenes. The music is seamlessly woven into the background noise of your lasers, phasers, engines, and missles. Most of the time it is barely noticeable above the ruckus but it is a soothing distraction during a long sprint across the map. It simply suits the game, perfectly conveying the mystery and the solitude of space. The more obvious callout to the tone of Bebop is the types of missions available so far. Most are bounty type missions and trading runs. All taking place in fantasitic locals with cool space stations. The game has a very awesome setting. And the scale of which really makes you feel like a plucky captain trying to scrape by in a much larger universe. All in all I was looking for a game that would let me feel like I was flying a spaces ship. This did that and more! Not only did it have the gameplay I desired but it did so in a very cool way. As such SG2 has exceeded my expectations. It is perfectly filling a niche in my gaming library which I have been searching to fill. I would highly recomend the game to anyone who has got the space captain itch. Star Citizen is a far way away. But even in Alpha SG2 rocks! And its future looks so promising. All things considered, 9/10. The only downside is a slightly difficult camera. You will get used to it but I feel like it doesn't need to be something that we should have to get used to. An autolock feature which would keep the camera centered on a target and  making the turret mode more responsive with less 'momentum' would be sufficient. But this is just nitpicking. SG2 looks to be a great niche game. And if you are interested it deserves your money and attention. -rm

content:
ber 28, 2014
												The game is fun, it's sort of a mix between X3(ship control, selling items) and Darkstar One(upgrading weapons, equipment and such). This game has some potential but right now it is still a bit lacking. Fun factor: You will have fun fighting and dodging enemy fire. Having troops board enemy ships and take them over. Looting dead ships. Seeing how different ships are and act. The joy of dragging a captured ship to a dock.Unfun factor: You are very much alone, yes you can hire mercs, up to two, but the only person you can talk to is the ship computer who in fact will only say anything to you do an action (move command, fire at will) or when an enemy teleports right to you. The world is pretty empty, NPC's are just sitting there really, and they tend not to do anything else unless an enemy happens to be around.The makers have stated they plan to add expansions which will lighten things up, but those things are in the future.  They also stated they have plans to change things up, shields will matter later on for boarding and such. Time will tell.I have put in 13 hours and so far feel a little worried. I ran most of my time in a Frigate capturing ships to sell. I even in fact captured a battleship by running back and forth between two stations to fill my troops and relaunch new boarding attacks.  It took very little time to level, and as well I fear I may never enjoy all the ships this game has to offer in the long run.So is it worth it?Positives: Somewhat fun, feels semi-polished, the devs are hard at work fixing bugs very fast, what seems like a bright future for a game.Negatives: World is full of things, but they might as well be boxes floating in space. No life really. It seems like the same type of AI as Minecraft. Seems a bit short so far even with Freeroam (world is open, no story).  I feel the game's price is sort of almost right at 25 bucks.

content:
r 7, 2014
												If you have fond memories of Privateer or Flreelancer, then Starpoint Gemini 2 is for you. If not, but you like traveling the universe, trading and selling (and smuggling) goods, blasting space pirates trying to steal your booty, or even mining asteroids on your downtime; then SG2 is also for you!Controls can be interesting (a bit wonky) at times, and I read there may be some joystick issues, but mouse and keyboard are my choice anyway so I've had no issues. Presentation and graphics look great, and there are some truly amazing views around the galaxy. Combat is fun and ship styles range from giant transports, to carriers with multiple fighter wings. I've got 20+ hours in at this point and while I started the campagin, I'm having more fun just roaming around, trading and upgrading my ship. If you've been looking for a game to scratch the space sim itch, this is a good game for it.

												I'm enjoying my first few sessions of Starpoint Gemini 2. Very nice atmosphere - graphics, music and sound have all had some close attention paid to them. content:
ry 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is fantastic, especially for an Alpha release.  Several things are still in the works, but it is a fine game as is.  Right now it is essentially a space sandbox.  I tend to play the role of pirate, or privateer, rather (I only attack the bad guys, but I'm always trying to board them and steal their ships so I can tow them back to a planet or space station and sell off their guns, then the ships themselves... seems to be pretty lucrative).  You'll love it when you get a big carrier with a bunch of fighter wings or bombers... it's awesome having a swarm of firepower surrounding you.  The game is massive and consists largely of traveling between planets and space stations (press B to boost your engines to full and enjoy the ride and the amazing scenery), doing sidequests, mining asteroids, or being a merchant or pirate or whatever suits your fancy.  There is currently no storyline or any story missions (but plenty of sidequests are available and constantly appearing), and a lot of things are currently non-functional (like the useable items... thankfully they are super valuable so I just sell them for lots of money), but with that being said, this game is amazing... I'm really looking forward to years of fun with this thing.

content:
27, 2014
Early Access Review
								A really interesting looking game. I like the controls, highly customisable, flying star-fighter style seems equally as easy turret-based capital ship combat( depends only on the style of ship, which can be better suited to either, which is exactly what it should be). HUD and contextual control panel pack a LOT of options and info into a simple, streamlined system. Graphically it's easy on the eye, won't praise it, but there's nothing I can think of that would need pointing out.The thing that would need tweaking is a detail, but impacts the game heavily, since it does with navigation: The waypoints do not say WHAT they point to on the map. Can't tell whether it's my active mission, accepted but not active or a completely new one. To be fixed ASAP, as going from point to point IS the game.The only other minor thing doesn't impact gameplay, but would make it a bit more interesting:*Refine the weapon mounting system. Grouping them together for ship sides is a good idea, but it would be good to have access to all single individual mounts anyway, also showing where they are on the ship, Star Wolves style (since they avoid fireing THROUGH the ship, which is as unexpected as it is brilliant), for enabling a more tactical loadout.*Connecting to the former, make the whole drydock/store/exchange window bigger and clearer. As it is now is not very intuitive and requires spending at least a few minutes just studying it to finally grasp what half the options actually are, much less taking advantage of them.In general, a good game even at this stage, just needs tweak and a good plot implemented. The latter would make a good game a great game.

content:
27, 2014
Early Access Review
								UPDATE: After lots and lots of play time, I've lost very little enthusiam and this has become my favorite game.If you find yourself missing Freelancer but wishing it was more robust in just about every measure (barring an in-cockpit view), this game is for you. There is a vast universe, seamlessy connected* so that you can fly between them without having to load at a "waygate" like almost every other space game out there. Sure there are gates and wormholes and all the other staples, but they're not necessary. The starter ship is gorgeous, and you can customize the look of your ship in small ways. Combat uses a lot of showy glowy beams that seem to trade off well against each other balance wise, short-ranged instabeams, blaster/plasma-beam-ish projectiles, glowy-trails-having missiles and so on. Your turrets don't just magically fire through your ships, so firing arcs are a concern, and multiple turrets with mismatched areas of defense are possible. You can enlist specialists in your crew who cost you extra expense but provide bonuses, in addition to an amazing range of customizations. You can reassign power between guns-engines-shields on the fly.It's currently an open-world, with promises of guided story plots to come. At the moment you can mine and take run-of-the-mill and short missions, kill this scan that ferry those. You can buy hunting licenses for different groups froim their enemies. The game needs longer more immersive plots, but the dev has already stated there's more to come int hat regard.There's the controls. There is a wide range of things you can do in this game, giving somewhat detailed commands to your fleet and crew, cloaking, grappling (best to shoot the enemies' guns off first), instructing your crew which guns to shoot off first. It is... daunting... looking at your control customization options. I recommend playthrough with the control defaults at first until you find which controls you will actually use best in your personal play style. You will be using just about every key on your keyboard make no mistake.That takes me to the tutorials. Just suffer through them they are awful annoying popups but informative. *this is beta and there's a slight hiccup when moving from grid to grid

content:
ry 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								There are a lot of really good space sims out there, this is one of them.  But one thing that sets this game apart from those other games is this:  Noob friendliness.  This games UI and setup is so easy/simple that even someone who has never played any space sims before can get the hang of within an hour or so, and that's FAST.  The UI may be simple, but it's still got the same flexibility to let you do what you want.  Every time I start a new space sim, I always think 'oh god, i gotta relearn the whole system again.'  but not for this one.  Also, that map UI reminds me soo much of google chrome.  Currently, the gameplay is extremely fun even for not being complete.  One could hardly tell, except for the fact that skill, equipment, and fighter keybinds don't work--but that's okay, they're all just a mouseclick away via the easy to use UI.  I haven't played long enough though to figure out how deep this game is, whether or not the trading system is static or dynamic, or whether or not what you do affects prices.  I haven't played long enough to see whether or not the universe is 'alive' like in other games, but this is good enough for someone who wants to pick up their first space sim and not be overwhelmed.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is fantastic, especially for an Alpha release.  Several things are still in the works, but it is a fine game as is.  Right now it is essentially a space sandbox.  I tend to play the role of pirate, or privateer, rather (I only attack the bad guys, but I'm always trying to board them and steal their ships so I can tow them back to a planet or space station and sell off their guns, then the ships themselves... seems to be pretty lucrative).  You'll love it when you get a big carrier with a bunch of fighter wings or bombers... it's awesome having a swarm of firepower surrounding you.  The game is massive and consists largely of traveling between planets and space stations (press B to boost your engines to full and enjoy the ride and the amazing scenery), doing sidequests, mining asteroids, or being a merchant or pirate or whatever suits your fancy.  There is currently no storyline or any story missions (but plenty of sidequests are available and constantly appearing), and a lot of things are currently non-functional (like the useable items... thankfully they are super valuable so I just sell them for lots of money), but with that being said, this game is amazing... I'm really looking forward to years of fun with this thing.

I have much more to play of course, and I am excited. There's plenty to explore and learn. Also the game has a great team behind it that communicates with it's player and fans. If you liked freelancer, tie fighter/x-wing, open world RPGs, and games that involve the players, like steam workshop and such, then this game should give you all the feels you need.

content:
er 12, 2013
Early Access Review
								Ok, first I want to say that overall, this is a fun game.  Even though it is in it's alpha phase, it still has a lot of fine points to keep me playing for the time being.  There is one point about this game that is going to kill it for me, but I'll get to that later.The graphics are well done.  I have several hours into it, and have yet to experience a graphical glitch.  The ship models are well done and the stations aren't bad to look at.The flight controls are a bit weird at first, but it really doesn't take much to get used to them.  The biggest gripe I have is that there is no first person view so you can't fly directly at something.  If you try, you actually fly over it.  Not that big of a deal and after you get used to it, it works out.  If you are flying mouse mode, there isn't enough dead space for level flight.  Your ship is always changing direction.  I ended up not utilizing the mouse mode and stuck with WASD.As it is still in Alpha phase there are only a few different types of missions to work on.  These are called Freelances.  They are usually quick and easy.  It looks like there will be several different types of missions put in later on, so this isn't a slight, just an observation.  Also, the money doesn't keep up with your pilot level.  I'm currently level 25 and still can't afford to buy another version of the same ship I'm currently in.  I should have been able to upgrade ships a while ago.  I'm sure with the advent of other missions, the money thing will probably work itself out.There needs to be more tutorials.  There needs to be something on Grappling and taking over ships.  Might be offered farther down the road.  Also on derelicts.  Try as I might, I can't figure them out.  I don't seem to get anything off of them.  I might not understand their mechanics, but since there is no tutorial on them, I don't know.Now for the part that breaks this game for me personally.  I do enjoy combat and exploration.  I've never been huge into trading or diplomacy.  However, I love games where I can create things.  Crafting is huge for me.  Starpoint Gemini 2 has these huge asteroid fields that if I spent years playing, I wouldn't be able to empty them out.  However, all you can do with them is shoot them for ore and then vendor it...for a very small price I might add.  There is nothing else to do with all of this ore.  Now, your saying...wait, it is still alpha, they might add it in later.  Well, I've read up in their forums and one of the developers has already stated that they don't plan on adding in any kind of crafting utility to the game.If I could put a station out in the fields, and have them manufacturing ship equipment, weapons & and ships themselves, this game would be one that I kept and played for years to come.  As it is, I'm going to get tired of shooting random encounters pretty quick.As a single player game, I need something that is going on in the background while I'm out exploring and building for the economy would be great.  Without this ability, the game gets stale, at least for me.For most people, this game will be great.  I know that a good majority of people don't care to craft anything.  For me, without it, it is a game breaker.

If multiplayer's eventually implemented, I can easily see this being the next big thing for online MMORPG space simulators.
