number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
2, 2015
												Starpoint Gemini 2 + Secrets of Aethera DLC:Excellent sandbox space game, campaign missions are quite easy at first and then they aren't, you need a bigger ship. Which means credits.  Trading, pop-up missions, side missions, capturing ships and mining are your friends now.Once you get you fingers trained on flying it's a lot more fun...fly in hard and fast and then slow down to stay on the tail pipe of your target, watch out for the explosive radius of your own missiles.Trading/Mining could use some TLC. The small cargo space and low margins on items makes for a lot of trips for those playstyles to make a lot of credits. A dedicated mining ship would be a good idea, with maybe a compressor item or mining laser enhancement or something so that you can fit more than 1 ore in 1 cargo slot.The trading screens in the map could really use a mode to show best to/from, rather than a per-item best buy/sell, also remote buy/sell ala Eve would be great.But trading and mining isn't what this game is about. The real fun comes with capturing ships and running the various types of missions. Capturing takes a while to figure out, I suggest youtube and practise.  Basically, grapple, burn the hull down 2/3rds of the way, transport your troops and keep transporting them as long as you have troops. After you get the hang of it, you take every mission around your level just to try and capture another ship.The pop-up missions are rather generic, about 10 or so different types that I've found and they differ only in the difficulty of the enemies. Some are out-right free credits and XP (science, repair).The Side Missions are quite variable from the few I've done, more credits and XP and more difficult than the pop-ups.The Campaign Missions are similar to the Side Missions in reward and difficulty but advance the story-line.Exploring the map is a lot of fun, it's huge...also more areas to find capturable ships and missions. One downside, when you play windowed, if you focus off the game, it will pause. This is non-condusive to setting a long waypoint, maxing your engine power and doing something else on the other monitor. Very fast save/loads. The fights can be quite intense, the AI seems to be aggressive, but not stupid, it'll gang-tackle you quite happily. The auto-firing works great, but I'm not a fan of the way it keeps shifting targets to closest enemy as opposed to the target you've selected. I guess I have to learn manual firing.I suggest staying with the Tauris starter boat, pick a weapon type, level that type up  and stay with it for the first 20 levels or so. The gunboat is a paper-tiger, so you learn a lot about dodging, firing, and your equipment needs. Lot's of save and reloads figuring it out. ++Shield Boosters, Repair Nanobots, Hull Plates.66hrs, 8.5/10 and am still playing. It's not solo-Eve, but darn close.

content:
y 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								pros:great ship designs, backgrounds and tunes. no really, the work put into the lighting etc is excellent and for a graphics junkie like me its was stunning.the variation in weapons and system additions is quite impressive for an alpha game as theres plenty to try out (if you can earn the credits)....the controls were easy to get to grips with and the learning curve isnt all that steep, more like a shallow bowl then the eiffel tower.i liked the ability to select missions from the system map as it saved soooo much time with reagrds to the: fly here > dock > mission select > fly there > kill whatever > done.  a novel and great idea and adds more of a flow to the game.mining is ok if thats your thing, point shoot collect as normal, however i couldnt find any indication of whether the rocks i were shooting were full of good stuff or crap...cons:couldnt work out if the shield was full coverage or sectional as in the previous gemini game as angling different sides of the ship would stop hull depletion, well sometimes not everytime. got quite confused.some enemies get stuck in space and dont move apart from shooting back, for some reason this makes them invulnerable too, so you die.currently no save feature in the game options, limited auto save though.combat, and this is my main gripe as its a space combat sim, theres no strafe or reverse!!  if you get to close to an object you have to bounce off it to turn around. increasing distance from targets means flying away from them all the while theyre pounding your ship. avoiding enemy fire is also very hard to do, spinning in a circle helps but only at range as the AI will fire at your current location almost without fail. however up close it just becomes a brawl between either who has the most energy or shield power...the main thing lacking is the fact theres no strafe (moving on the same access from left to right, up and down) the ability to dodge fire is essential in any fight but sadly gemini 2 does not provide this ability. in essence the fighter fights become nothing more then lancing, flying at each other trying to hit the enemy until you are in close, see above as to why this is bad... i suppose constantly changing the power distribution from shields to weapons to speed could help and some peeps will like that but i prefer flying by the seat of my pants and dodging for that true dogfighter feeling.furthermore, i loved the beam weapons, very powerful with exceptional rangedownsides, very power hungry and can empty your charge in seconds plus theres no zoom feature so no way of knowing if your shots are hitting the target until the enemies hull depletes and as previously stated power to the weapons depletes fast!!the only bug ive encountered so far was when the game freezes mid flight, not annoying yet as reminisent to PS1 games and their "loading next area" moments.overall for an alpha its quite enjoyable, very straight forward missions and great visuals.

content:
y 4, 2015
												Campaign done, here's *thoughts*.Good:  To start off with, the music in SG2 is pretty great.  That's the first thing that hits me, and it's always good whenever I've booted the game.  A bit more variety would be nice too, after a while of free-roaming, it might get a little stale, but that goes for most games, really.Bad:  The dialog and cutscenes are terrible.  No, really REALLY terrible.  The dialog is cliche, and *hideously* over-acted.  And those accents?  AND NO SKIP??  And the game doesn't really pause during these tedious, cliche, dragging, unskippable cutscenes.  I've seen better cutscenes in pretty much any other game.Good:  Ships.  Mostly.  They're all quite recognizable, and have a lot of variety.  Once you know the ships, you can see a silhouette of most of them from most angles, and be able to ID the specific ship, or at least class.  Nexus ships a couple others in particular are EASY to spot.  Transports less so, but their class is obvious, so no matter.Bad:  Firing arcs.  These are SPACE ships, they should have minimal blind spots.  They are not floating in an ocean, they need coverage above and below.Bad:  There is a single "best" weapon, DPS-wise?  The stats show that, anyway.  Beams tickle, the only NPC weapons that seem to DO anything are rails and plasma.  This balance state made it out of early access?Bad:  Map and space design.  Freelancer got this right, and they had space with "too much" stuff in it.  The SG2 single solar system is both incredibly too small and insanely crowded.  It would be fine for say, underwater on an ocean planet, but for "outer space" it's just crowded.  And the "movement" field for dust floating past makes it feel like a fish tank with a broken filter and a bunch of pooping fish.Space Engineers and EVE and to a lesser extent Freelancer made the game FEEL spacious.  SG2 is a lot of LARGE factions crammed into a small fish tank with a bunch of stuff floating in the water.Bad:  I finally managed to get a ST-drive, yay!  ...Only to find that it doesn't actually work?  *All* the things should be working before the EA tag comes off.  At least implemented in some state.

content:
, 2014
Early Access Review
								Edit: So here we are after full release.In all honesty, the story is not presented in a manner I really find easily accessable, which is too bad but survivable. Besides that, everything I was told would be in this game is here, and all the fun I saw coming back in EA is also here. This is early access done right.In case you haven't read any other reviews, the game is very similar to EVE or X3 in sandbox mode. In story mode it feels quite a bit more linear, but as I said, this is simply because the method of presentation is just not my style, and you may find it's exactly what you like.Still, lots of fun, lots of freedom, and lots of beautiful, beautiful space in which to make your own story. Good use of your money if you like spaceship combat/trader/adventure sims.Original reviews:Even in beta, this is a good game. Not only is the game very playable, but the graphics are good and I personally find even the beta to be more stable and friendly to my recommended-spec rig than many full releases of other games I've played. Great forum community too and the devs are very open to feedback. There is not quite enough to do yet for freeroam to be worth $30,  but if you are reading this after the full release, then you should buy this!EDIT:Worth noting that the devs are so active on this that right now, only a few weeks after writing the initial review, enough stuff has been finalized or added to the current beta to probably make it worth your $30. Get on it!

Early Access Review
								It's been ages since we've had an excellent free roam space roleplaying game.  While in the current early alpha stage gameplay focuses more on "make stuff asplode" rather than "trade for all the things", the action gameplay that's already there is right at home with such greats as Starfleet Command paired with the frenetic nature of Freelancer.  Even if you aren't a sci-fi geek (EXCELSIOR!), I'm willing to bet that once you get past the learning curve you'll absolutely love this.Where Starpoint Gemini 1 was rough around the edges and everyone talked in broken English that would make even the European Union cringe, this is a finely-polished brilliant-cut gemstone with actual English-as-a-first-language voice actors -- so if you're expecting your ears to bleed, then you're wrong.  Wrong, wrong, wrong.Also, power-to-engines.  Power-to-engines, omigod, power-to-engines.  Exclam, like, wow, hashtag awesome.  Or whatever the kids are saying these days.

content:
r 25, 2014
												Starpoint Gemini 2 is hours of constant enjoyment. I've been wanting a great space simulator for years and this fills that gap. Space combat ranges from you being overwhelmingly powerful and slaughtering a weaker enemy convoy, to suddenly being completely outmatched as hordes of enemy fleets warp in. You'll go from shifting your power-flow to fully charge your weapons; unleashing torrents of weapon-fire and watching enemy ships violently explode, to frantically diverting power to your shields and engines, cutting power from your weapon-batteries to overcharge your engines and jettison yourself free from the firestorm. The space combat, environment, and ships are all wonderful and deserve high praise. The only downfall is the narrative in the story mode. My only noted negative is that the plot dialogue is very poorly written: conversations are written with very simplistic wording, adding unnecessary filler dialogue in the middle of a conversation. The characters have no expression and sitting through the dialogue moments are frustrating to even hear the characters speak. All the character interactions are not written as real conversations, monologues occur at inappropriate times. A complete re-writing of the entire game's plot narrative (by someone with writing experience) would make the game perfect. 8.5/10

What this means is if you buy something at 80 and sell at 100 you make 20. You can hold 100 things so you make a total of $2,000   Go mining. Best thing I found to mine sells for 900, get 100. 900x100=$90,000. This takes a lot of time   Go kill guys and loot them for random amounts so lets just say you only save the items worth 2,000+ so call it $100,000 but this takes a lot of time OR   Start the game and as soon as you have control of your ship hang out around a space station and board the weakest ship you can find. Then sell that ship at the space station for $400,000+ depending on the ship.... takes 5-10 minutes or less..... Late game is even worse as you will be selling ships for millions.

content:
y 23, 2016
												I'm going to start this review by being negative. This is not to savage the work that Little Green Men did on this game, but rather to emphasize the positive bits later."Starpoint Gemini 2" has some pretty rough areas. The campaign, framed through (sometimes yawn-inducing) text boxes and uneven voice-acting, didn't connect with me very well. There's an interesting twist here and there, but I just couldn't manage to care that much about what was going on. The necessary "gloss-n-polish" doesn't exist, especially with the game dialogue writers having a strange aversion to using the word "the."The game's difficulty curve is lumpy and strange, with the procedural mission generation apparently taking into account your level, but not what ship you have. This is also aggravated by a lack of mission information. Especially with the campaign, you don't know that much about what you're heading into. It's possible to get to a point where you just "hit a wall," and get thrown into an engagment that you simply can't win without (at least) having gotten into the next class of ship. There's nothing wrong with this if you have some sort of warning, but for it to happen suddenly and with no advance notice is a kind of "fake difficulty" that I dislike.(I can appreciate a game that's not interested in hand-holding, but there's also a point where it all turns into sloppy experience design. "Freelancer" got this right by walling you off from taking the next campaign mission if you didn't have the prerequisites. "SG2" gets it wrong by basically telling you nothing aside from the story's flavortext. I simply don't equate legitimate game challenge with failing to communicate effectively.)I finally got to the point where seeing what happened next in the story was insufficient incentive to work my way up to a more durable spacecraft.But here's the thing - the above happened more than once. This is where things go positive; That I got pulled back into the experience is a testimony to just how well the basic gameplay loop was crafted.What the developers really managed to do beautifully is to create an addicting "travel, do, upgrade, repeat" cycle that keeps dragging you back in. The space you fly through is nicely crafted, with a sense of scale that is large without having interminable length between interesting features. The combat is generally satisfying (as long as you're not in a situation where it's overwhelming), and the other game mechanics manage to be pretty deep without being clunky or hard to get your mind around. Other free-roaming space games give you all kinds of controls, and then those controls don't behave consistently (or at all) as you expect. This title, on the other hand, is very solid in terms of behaving intelligently when you give commands.If Little Green Men Games built a sequel that was basically the same core mechanics, but with a far more refined mission (both campaign and procedural) experience, they would be in the same league as "Freelancer." The foundation is there - it just needs to be built upon.

content:
r 18, 2014
												I bought this game during a Steam sale not expecting too much of it, but it's had me hooked for weeks now. It's fun to play and offers you a lot of things to do and ways to play. For instance, you can focus on the story, pirating, freelancing or trade goods that you either buy legally or gain by looting other ships. You can even specialize in mining asteroids and gasclouds and sell the gains. Or do all of the above!The game gets updated regularly and now has a very extensive tutorial library to help new players get started. You're able to customize your ship's weapon loadout and, to a certain level, it's color and decals.The only things I've noticed so far that could be improved is the voice acting in the storyline (which is pretty hilarious at times) and weapon impact effects. The latter look really poorly done compared to the sleek and smooth ship designs, explosions and absolutely beautiful galaxy you travel through.Oh, and the main menu music alone could have made me buy this game, just thought I'd mention that too.

content:
ry 29, 2016
												Bought this game in Early Access ~3 years ago.  Been playing it off an on.  I doubt I'll ever get over 200 hours but that doesn't mean I don't like the game.  It's amazing seeing how barebones it was back then come to life - as in, freelance missions gave you like 1000 credits and a few dozen XP. Half of the interface was useless and many things were still placeholders.  It's neat to come across a large battle and swoop in to help or to loot.Quick list of pros/cons+Beautiful environment+Living world+SPACESHIPS!+SPACESTATIONS!+Many ways to get money/XP-I have zero interest in the Campaign (don't let that sway you; just a personal preference)-In sandbox mode, it doesn't feel as though you're a big part of the solar system, which makes sense. I guess what I was looking for in this game won't be realized until Starpoint Gemini: Warlords.-Damn PTE disrupting pirates.-A few things are underexplained.-Ship size difference is not noticeable enough and was a complaint since Early Access.

number of helpful: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
r 19, 2014
												Finally, a game that scratches my decade-long Freelancer itch.But first, a disclaimer. While no longer an Early Access title, Starpoint Gemini 2 - as of October 2014 - is not quite the finished article. The game still has a number of items turned off in the options menu. Certain gameplay features seem to be half-finished, and the AI does not seem to be taking advantage of all the tools available in combat. In fact, many newcomers are bound to be turned off by the obtuse UI design and the text-heavy, non-interactive tutorials that spit out seemingly unending streams of text on things they have no idea about.Get past the initial frustrations, however, and you will find an absolute gem of a timesink. SG2 nails the three key elements of a good space sim: simple controls, a massive universe full of activities, and a million paths to success on your own terms. Starting off in a tiny gunship and a poorly-voiced campaign mission, you are quickly set loose and given freedom to roam the absolutely gigantic map to mine, trade, explore and fight to your heart's content. Veteran X players may be disappointed by the comparatively static world, limited fleet building options and inability to set up your own industrial empire in the stars, but everyone else should be more than satisfied with the wealth of choices at hand. This is more than worth it at full price, and absolutely unmissable in a sale.

number of helpful: 10 of 17 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
30, 2015
												This game is fun for a little while but there's so little variation it gets very tedious, which is a shame becuase the game mechanics are good.Cons:There are three quests you can do: 1)Go here and kill these guys.2)Go here and scan this anomaly.3)Go here and take stuff over there.In order to make money you can either grind for days ferrying junk around, or buy a few upgrades for your crew and start hijacking enemy ships.  The former will take hours before you can buy your next ship, the latter will take minutes.  Rinse and repeat and winthin one afternoon you have the biggest, baddest ship with all the best hardware.There's no variation across the map: each sector feels identical.  I guess in real life the universe is very homogenous but you probably shouldn't use WMAP as your basis for a space RPG.The voice acting is pretty dull.  You can tell the actors aren't at all enthused by the story and nor was I.Pros:You can adjust the power balance of your shelds, weapons and engines, giving you a more hands on approach to aggresion, defence and running away.Each weapon and shield module has its own power and can be drained if over taxed during a fight, forcing you to keep manouvering to keep your better charged side towards the enemy.  This makes the big lumbering ships more interesting to play.You can take your unstoppable death machine, paint it shiny pink and name it "Winnie the Pooh".Summary:The game world is too big and too bland.  If the devs had put the effort into writing a better story and varying the world rather than inflating it, this game could be great.  Otherwise it feels more like work than fun.

ber 29, 2014
												What i liked:- Multiple options for combat (capture, shoot them up, cloaked assisn)- Vast universe with multiple factions- Many interesting travel options (jumpgates, gravity anomalies, wormholes, speed boosters and jumpdrive)What i disliked:- Poor storyline and terrible voiceacting- Horrid combat balance based on owned ship (if you have a tiny gunship and upgrade to a corvette or a frigate, suddenly all the enemies upgrade equally and you get blasted to smitherines in a matter of seconds)- Enemy difficulty based on player level (why on earth would i take a +xp perk - if i want increased difficulty i just do so in the option menu)- Due to scaling enemies almost instantly have many more troops in their ship than you can hope to send, which makes the troop capture option obsolete- Sinle use boost.. make them cost more (-> multiuse with cooldown) and dont make me run around half the universe looking for the ones i use- Class based skills - useless at best, let me at least replace them with usable items (boosts)SummaryI might give this game a thumbs up once balancing issues have been adressed and class skills make a difference.

content:
0, 2016
												Had to write a review because I looked and saw that this game was getting really negative reviews. I think that most of these come from skewed expectations. The game, is fantastic, but not for everyone. If you are expecting an Eve style game: turn around and walk away. If you are expecting an Elite: Dangerous style of game: turn around and walk the other way. If you are expecting a Freelancer style game: then come right on in and enjoy the ride. I'm a pretty big space junkie, even bleeding into the mobile area *gag reflex*, I know. But when I'm not playing some space game on my PC, I'm playing Galaxy on Fire on my phone. As far as the game goes don't expect much "dogfight" type flying and combat. While there is a small amount of that in the early game, very quickly it turns into a game with battleships and cruisers, where the tactic is to broadside your adversary rather than run at him head on. Being that it is in space, that type of combat is amplified tenfold. Think of a great conflict with you in your dreadnought vs 3 other battleships. You launch fighters and prepare for combat. Being that this is space one of the battleships flys above you, so you rotate your ship so that your port side is now facing the underside of his ship, leaving you with a perfect angle of attack. If that doesn't sound awesome to you than this game is now for you.

												As a sequal to Starpoint Gemini it's beginning to look good... In a nutshell, they did a great job on the graphics and the 3rd dimension in the 3D environment can now actually be used. They also took away the seperate sectors and merged them into 1, with sometimes undesirable lag but no more loading screens and the feel of a huge area to play around in. Big plus there.The gameplay has suffered greatly though, as you can no longer buy/sell individual ship systems as would in the previous game, since a somewhat different system has been employed, but worse yet, there no longer is a significant subsystem targeting system, but from what I understand that is yet to be implemented.Bare in mind though that this is still in Beta when this was written, but it should give a general idea about what happened. With Starpoint Gemini in mind, I am a little bit more optimistic compared to my last edit. I did love that interface, but that's gone...

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
r 4, 2014
												"Full PTE ahead! Oh wait, Captain there's something wrong.."Honestly, I like it. It's a decent game, it has a strong core and does have entertaining values inside of it. It's pretty, runs well on my AMD machine, and keeps you at least somewhat busy. However, there are some very odd issues and difficulties I have with the game, I'll list them below.Game is too light; When I say this, I mean that the game is not that deep. The statistics for ships is relegated to a few simple stats (such as hull, cargo and crew). I feel that if I'm going to be driving around a big ship, I'd wanna know more about what's going on with it's internal systems. What makes ship A better than ship B? Well look at hull, cargo and troop capacity. That's it. Where's my statistics? Scaling for ship size; This is actually a big complaint. The ships don't look..big. They don't have imposing statures or good camera angles. They don't refelct how big (or small) they actually are. I have a small gunship and I'll go past ships marked as frigates or destroyer and I can't tell a size difference. That makes no sense to me. Sure, if I get within "I'll melt you with point blank lasers range" I'll notice a very small difference, but otherwise it's hard to tell. Reminds me of Star Trek (the show).Lots of loot, nothing to do with it; There's a plethora of loot in the game. Computers, drugs, minerals and ores. ALL YOU CAN DO IS SELL THEM. You can't craft, you can't allocate them for energy on the ship, they are just fluff. They don't have any real impact on the game other than that they can be sold (and what's worse, caputring enemy ships is far more benificial). I wish there was an in depth crafting system, something. Notifications; The game does not notify you when you pick up loot, meaning, that when I loot a ship with the "auto loot" function, it does not tell me what I got! I have to go into my menues and see what was put in. A prime example of how this is bad. I looted a big ship once, got an AMAZING missle system. I didn't know I had it, it never notified me. So I spent 250,000 credits on a missle system (worse by the way) and then, while equping it, realized I had the other one. Bye bye money! Camera angles; Not dynamic, not good. No cockpit view. Sadface.No real interaction with the universe; I will have to state, this is one of my biggest issues. Doing freelance quests gives you no satisfaction. When I'm picking up a VIP to transport, no chat initiates. It's a simple grab and go. Even the quest text is shallow. "Pick up A, drop off at B." There's no context as to what I'm doing this for. When I have a mission to go kill some pirate, there's nothing to it. It's just "We of the Such-and-such want Pirate dead". That's it! There's no interaction with the universe around you, it's all text and empty requests. You can't even interact with the ships system officers!! There's never a point where I feel truly a part of a living organism, I feel like the ONLY living organism in the game.Difficulty; Thus far, it makes no sense. I'll take on a quest to kill a pirate that's my level. Then I'll go to said zone and find that the pirate has two or more friends and he himself is listed as "Impossible" for my skill level. WHY? The game never notified me on what gear I should have when. The ships I'm going up against are a cool 2-10 MILLION credits, where as in my entire game play, dedicating time to making credits, I've made roughtly 800,000 at most, at one time. I read a forum post stating that some people ran into a sinkhole of difficulty, they leveled up too fast and the game scaled their enemies up too high, too quick. My point is, leveling should be more fluid and less wreckless. Don't allow me to level up to level 20 when I can't afford/fight level 20 ranked ships. EXP needs to be reworked, slow down leveling. Class "System"; It's strait forward and dull. No real custiomization other than "Put point here, see marginal benifits". It's like old school WoW. Funny enough above I listed the games not deep, but it has a +% based level system. That's okay, I get it. But my skills don't feel impact, even against trivial ranked enemies, they still melt through my shield and kill me.I could go on, there's a lot to complain about with this game. However, give it a shot. If you really like space-sandbox-adventure action, you can't go wrong here. But there's better out there. "General Statement. These are my thoughts on the game. Any opposing or likeminded feelings are welcome to be directed and discussed at me, however, don't be an idiot about it."

content:
r 11, 2015
												I played Elite: Dangerous, then X3AP, then X:Rebirth, went back to X3AP and finally I stumbled on Starpoint Gemini 2. How I came to this game? In elite, I was fascinated by the cool-looking fighters, the dog-fighting with HOTAS controller and hype of Horizon. I soon realised the game was time-consuming and i was unable to accomplish as much as I would expected. I loaded up X3 (I bought during a steam sale) and started playing. This game also had dog-fighting, tons of ship classes but the main draw was the scope and depth of the game. At the midpoint, I coud lead a wing of fighters, setup space stations and managed a fleet of trading freighters. It was really cool but I spent way too much time and the graphics were not as cool. I hopped over to X: Rebirth and got a headache navigating in the engine. I hopped back to X3 for a short while and finally got to SPG2.SPG2 is a Space-Theme ARPG. In free-roam, you control a ship and navigate through a gigantic starchart map. You can pick up alot space-thremed missions, mine asteroids, trade between space stations and planets, be a pirate or police. It cover much of everything you can think of in a space sim game but to a limited depth. I won't not say it is a shallow game because you have a pretty good idea of what a space sim would be like after playing this game.+ Tons of playable ships + Beautiful ship designs+ Space combat is flashy and exciting. + Tons of things to do, you won't get bored of things to do - Limited functionality in several aspect of a typical space sim game - Reputation system, licences and bulletin news interface seems like a mere after-thought - Shield system is surprisingly 2 dimensional - No real space dogfighting - It is definitely not SPG1 or starfleet command - I had this feeling it is designed to be played on consoles since it is evidently simplified, not a good thing for PC players.This game shines when you play at it as a ARPG in a space theme setting and not as a typical space sim. Its greatness comes from the sum of all the parts it has to offer. For its vast contents and production value, I disagree it is a poor man's Free Space.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
r 9, 2015
												Pardon the format of my review, I am not formatting it very well.I bought Starpoint Gemini a couple of years back and just could not get into it.  I had put Starpoint Gemini 2 on my wishlist, hoping for a sale.  So I recently bought it on sale and I am find the freeroam mode very satisfying.I started out mining asteroids, then doing missions and all the while figuring out the different mechanisms for the game.  I had googled some "Getting started" guides and found out that boarding and selling ships was where most money could be made.  I had changed the game mode to easy, I wanted to check out all the different ships the game has to offer without too much of a struggle.   There is a clear progression with the choice of ships and going from your beginner Gunship and ending up with a Dreadnought is very satisfying.   The controls are a lot like Freelancer. Selling ships and taking out the most wanted from the Bounty board is a sure way to get rich fast.  There are different "zones" near friendly space stations that offer baddies from the different factions that are ideal for getting xp and capturing ships and dragging them to the spacestation.   Troopers are the currency that allow you to capture ships, space stations run out of them and then you have to go look for them somewhere else or wait until the space station has a new shipment of them.  I love the map with all the different factions and things to discover, there are structures called artefact vaults where you can collect an artefact, the objective is to collect all 50.  Some special kills (usually baddies from the most wanted board) yield unique weapons with better than average stats and some missions/kills yield   blueprint for unique equipment.  Most subsystems of  your ship can changed with upgrades that give bonuses.  You also can hire different officers that give bonuses. Furthermore once you reach a certain level,  you can hire mercs that join you so you end up with a little fleet.The combination of different ships (70 apparently), different officers, skills, perks, mercs and equipment and the huge map makes this game a great experience for me. I enjoy the grind of doing missions and capturing ships.   Overall a great Elite clone.  The story is a little thin and the game could use some world-lore detailing the history of the various factions beyond the news bulletins, something like the books in the Elder Scroll games would be nice. Also, the capture/trooper mechanic could be reworked a little, I never understand why some of my troopers still have to die when they are capturing an empty enemy ship.

												This is my impression of the game after about 39 hours of play. This game is mostly fun, as a game like this can be “fun”. This is a space simulation and as such, there is a lot of “space”. Moving from one place to another is a test of patience. It is very nice to look at and the music background/atmosphere is gorgeous; I can just listen to this game for hours. Unfortunately, the main story is not very interesting (after having done a few missions, I don’t even know what it is about). I am currently at level 17 but haven’t advanced much in the story because I don’t have any incentive to do so, or I don’t care for the story.I am mostly having fun exploring, mining, capturing ships and selling them to make money, because the game doesn’t give you much of that and selling ships is the best and the fastest way to make money. There doesn’t seem to any real purpose in this game; you just go around doing stuff that, ultimately, has no purpose. This is a nice game to play if you know what you are getting into. But I should point out that this is not a fast game to play so you need to have lots of time and patience on your hands.

content:
er 5, 2016
												Okay, I loved this game.  The ship models are fantastic and deeply customizable.  The "Heroes" that can optionally be hunted down have curiously ordinary names and faces - I think I've been killing the developers inside their own game.  The sandbox is massive, and while most of the missions really boil down to "go here and kill this guy" and "go here without getting killed", the enemies scale well enough that you're never really assured a victory.  Until you get a titan.  I didn't play the first game, but I get the feeling that the Levithan was the final battle.  Building your own ship off of that design, then, really skews the odds in your favor.  Fortunately, this is only an option at the very end, so look forward to scurrying away from enemy reinforcements.  Long story short, this will probably devour almost a hundred hours of your life and you won't resent it for that.

content:
r 1, 2016
												So I bought this on sale and it was one of those impulse buys, I did not get this game at all when I first tried it, but when I was in a more patient mood to learn the confusing interface I have now started playing it more and actually understand it as I read the tutorials carefully and just got used to everything, there is a learning curve with this game, but considering it's singleplayer so you don't have to worry about player population and it's a really massive space sim it is definitely worth it.Do you remember the days of Freelancer? Well I do and I played that game to death, one of the most fun aspects for me was the huge amounts of factions, the hidden bases, the exploration and the rather limited sandbox experience when it came to trading this game has decided to focus on all of that.I may actually even check out mining properly now, because I remember wanting to do it in Freelancer but because that game was primarily about combat it was all very limited oh and just like freelancer it looks like you mine by shooting stuff rather than having any sort of specialised ship, which, while is a bit silly I do wonder if that's a good mechanic because it means you don't have to worry so much about how to defend yourself in space sims.So to sum this game up, it very much has a learning curve, think of it as Freelancer on steroids because even the steering of your ship is very similar, but once you get into it you'll have no problem getting through the map and the various interfaces loaded with information.If anyone wants a possible tip on getting into the game quicker, I recommend just getting used to using the context menu which you access with the middle mouse button or clicking your scroll wheel. Unlike most context sensitive stuff on games this menu actually seems to work decently and you can use it to quickly navigate around space.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 20, 2014
												This is my methadone to keep me going until Star Citizen is out.TLDR: It's very relaxing and enjoyable to roam around popping pirate ships, and scooping up their loot while exploring each hex.Theres some nice progression with levels earning you skills and perks to your character.  Meanwhile spend that ill gotten cash to upgrade ship systems, buy fancier guns, and stock up on consumables to give your ship an edge in a fight, or i suppose help miners in their tedious rock popping. Hire troops for the wetwork, bridge officers for passive bonuses, and later on mercenary captains to back you up in a fight. Remember, it's OK to leave them to die.  Ultimately earn enough (or take over!) that fancy new ship you've been eying. There are also purchasable licenses for financial perks like earning extra credits when killing certain factions or cheaper goods from a certain corporation, even passive credits per month so you can sit around and do squat and still earn money just like the one percenter you are.Exploration stays enjoyable by providing several modes of travel.  Pay to use an established warp gate (there's a way to make a one time license purchase to make them free though), or risk some damage and redshirt lives by using wormholes.  There's also these odd green bands of gravitational anomolies than can pull you in and whip you across several sectors very quickly, and finally the convenience of a consumable that will jump you a limited distance but can go from anywhere to any place you've already explored (and have enough drives to reach). It's also financially useful as the more stations you find, the better options you'll have to buy low and sell high with a decent variety of trade goods, some of them illicit in certain regions.I wish the different parts of space were more varied, but at least it's all uniformly pretty with nebulas, asteroid fields, ice asteroids, and clouds of floating junk (all mineable if you're into that sort of thing) to add some variety. There are scannable anomolies, though only a few types and they all just do some sort of passive thing to surrounding space like scramble sensors or block teleporters. Scanning them down will get rid of the field, and earn some xp and credits if its a mission, otherwise they are ignorable.  Some of the more unique stations are very beautiful, like the Spire, but most of the space stuff is pretty samey.Combat is  pretty simplistic you can even (and its recommended) set your turrets to autofire and concentrate on turning your best shields towards the light show. I wish the different guns and damage types were a little more varied. Heavy weapons have limted ammo but help speed things up, and there are some other consumables that can be deployed to help increase offense or survivability.  Spice things up by locking your grappling array on a wounded ship and teleporting over boarding parties of expendable no name grunts who throw their lives away so you can get a big payday.  If you're lucky and manage to successfully take over a ship you get to loot it far more effectively that picking through its wreckage, then tow it to the nearest dock to either add to your stable or sell off. Remember to keep the redshirts stocked every time you come back to port. Out in the stars are a bunch of named elites with bounty's on their heads and suprisingly deadly offensive capabilities to test your mettle. Currently theres no real story, and a very limited number of missions that just help earn credits while doing the things you're already doing, but the foundation that is there is solid and fun, and surprisingly well polished for an early access title.

content:
2014
Early Access Review
								 I'm new to Steam and one of the first games I searched for was Freelancer, no luck there unfortunatly. So I was keeping an eye out for a similar, if not even better after ten years, replacment for my space combat kicks. The vids on the Store page for Starpoint Gemini 2 look amazing, it seemed to tick all the boxes.  Regardless of your Class you start with an awesome ship, it reminded me of B5s WhiteStar. It's a beast, easily crushing the initial waves of pirate scum who think they're hard enough. As you progress slightly you come up against larger foes and more drawn out battles that require a little more thought. You can upgrade your weapons or change them out, improve your crew to improve your boarding party and the idea of having a Merc fleet to command sounds great. There is a very solid foundation for an epic game here.Combat is on the whole more tactical than Freelancers wild dog-fights, although in fairness I'm not expecting a Cruiser or Frigate Class ship to turn on a dime like a Fighter. A bit more pace wouldn't hurt though. There is currently no story mode and I didn't think I would miss it so much untill it wasn't there. The good news is that it's yet to come, so that's really something to look forward to. For the the time being however, I'm done flying about on other faceless peoples errands as it really has no impact on the greater Galactic Goings-On. The Devs have done a superb job so far but they've a real task ahead to fill out Gemini and the players role in the galaxy.

content:
2014
Early Access Review
								 I'm new to Steam and one of the first games I searched for was Freelancer, no luck there unfortunatly. So I was keeping an eye out for a similar, if not even better after ten years, replacment for my space combat kicks. The vids on the Store page for Starpoint Gemini 2 look amazing, it seemed to tick all the boxes.  Regardless of your Class you start with an awesome ship, it reminded me of B5s WhiteStar. It's a beast, easily crushing the initial waves of pirate scum who think they're hard enough. As you progress slightly you come up against larger foes and more drawn out battles that require a little more thought. You can upgrade your weapons or change them out, improve your crew to improve your boarding party and the idea of having a Merc fleet to command sounds great. There is a very solid foundation for an epic game here.Combat is on the whole more tactical than Freelancers wild dog-fights, although in fairness I'm not expecting a Cruiser or Frigate Class ship to turn on a dime like a Fighter. A bit more pace wouldn't hurt though. There is currently no story mode and I didn't think I would miss it so much untill it wasn't there. The good news is that it's yet to come, so that's really something to look forward to. For the the time being however, I'm done flying about on other faceless peoples errands as it really has no impact on the greater Galactic Goings-On. The Devs have done a superb job so far but they've a real task ahead to fill out Gemini and the players role in the galaxy.

content:
30, 2014
Early Access Review
								So I used to play EVE online a lot, and when I say alot I mean a social life endagering amount. Dont get me wrong, its an awesome game, but I always felt underpressure from my corperation and the fact it was a pay monthy subscription to play as much as I possibly/physically could. Due to this I eventually stopped playing and have ever since been on the lookout for something that comes even remotley close to EVE visually, mechanically and diversly. Starpoint Gemini 2 is the best I have found yet, and (as at the time of writing this) is still only in BETA!! Really looking forward to where they are going to take this, and no pay monthly fee so I can pick up and put down as I wish without feeling like I'm losing money. Ok so its not as complex as EVE but EVE was (imho) massivley complex and this game does just enough without frying your brain. Diversity is there, the amount of stuff you can do already without the campain is huge, visuals are breathtaking and the playable area is massive, not EVE massive but I ve been playing now for about 20 hours with 1 character and I've only explored about 1/8 of the map. Very well done on this guys and a big thumbs up on how much feedback you take from the forums. Its so nice to see deleopvers actually listening to us gamers and implementing changes directly off the back of feedback/critisims/ideas that come straight from the community. If you used to (or still do) play EVE, love space sims (or not) or are just looking for something to fill the gap between now and Star Citizen, look no further.All in all I give Starpoint Gemini 2 9/10 and watch this space, its only gonna get better

It is definitely worth it in this beta stage, which assures me that once this is released, it will be a major player in the space RPG market.

content:
29, 2014
Early Access Review
								So far, I'm impressed enough with the game to keep my eye on it.  It has some nice "widgets" implemented (I especially dig the animation of the tactical display starting up), and it is definitely pretty.  I am particularly enjoying having traded my beam weapons for longer-ranged railguns, especially since the beam weapons didn't have the "oomph" factor for me.  Now I just need to find some enemies that give me a challenge (but don't just blast me out of the stars with their first volley).One thing I'd love to see is the ability to add/remove various mount types.  For instance:  I would rather have two railgun mounts up front and ditch my heavy weapon (since I tend to go "no ammo" on anything where I can build my own loadout).  Having a little more control over "ship engineering" would be grand.  For all I know, this is planned; it just doesn't exist at the moment (as of 2014.04.29).The only real downside I've experienced so far is a few seemingly-random CTDs.   While not entirely a "downside," there can be a "boredom factor" (which is not unique to S♥♥♥♥t all - I have the same issue with the X-universe games):  not enough mission variety, so it feels like a click-fest instead of a space game at times.  It IS early-access, though, so this could be an instance of "it's not in yet."  Regardless, a little more attempted piracy or some events that feel like they have meaning (anomalies that actually affect you rather than just "drain shields/sap engines/etc," or other such challenges might help).All told, I'm glad I got in on early access for SG2, and I'm excited to see where they take it!

content:
5, 2014
												I'm loving Starpoint Gemini 2: probably the best space game in year. It's transitioned out of beta nicely, with minimal bugs, and improved optimization. The game has two modes, story and sandbox, and both are quite enjoyable. The control scheme feels a little like Nexus the Jupiter (but not exactly), in the sense that you're the commander of a large ship with various systems (and not just a fighter). Much better than the X series imo.The game excells at allowing you to create the kind of space captain you want to be, and the kind of ship you want to fly. There are three classes, commander, gunner, and engineer, and each excells at different specializations. Commanders are great pilots, and augment their fleets; while, gunners excell at blowing things up; the engineer can create space anomalies like vortexes that suck enemy ships in, deal radiation damage to crews, or they can hack and shut down ship systems.The ships are fantastic. Nearly a hundred different ships of varying classes that you can customize and taylor to your play style. You can control frigates and battleships - and command squadrons of fighters (but there are no fighters you can fly). Place different systems, weapons, and then tweak those systems and weapons with different modules. So, for example, you can tweak your teleporter to improve its capacity, or give it a defensive characteristic, and use it to block enemy teleports. (your ships have troops which can defend against and invade and take over other ships which you can later keep or sell.) Do you install a module with better accuracy, damage, or, for a little more money, both?Finally, there are a variety of things to do. You can be a trader, a smuggler, a pirate (raid and steal ships), or a fleet commander of some sorts. There are anomalies in space that you can simply go out, explore, scan, and document, and gain experience from this. You can ferry VIP or desparately needed supplies between stations. As much variety to the missions as in any space game.My only real complaints, and by no means are these game breaking, is the lack of documentation (there's very little information available on what different game mechanics do, exactly. Which is frustrating, since they obviously took the time to put different mechanics into the game. For example, some guns do "emp" damages, or "radiation" damage, and no where does it say exactly what it means by this, one is just left to assume that radiation hurts crews and emp drains batteries or shields. My second complaint is that there's just too much clutter. Don't get me wrong, the game is beautiful, but everywhere you look there's some beautiful nebulae, star, or simply space debry all around you. Your eyes get overwhelmed by the clutter, never are you allowed to enjoy the simplicity of being amongst the stars. You never get the sense that you're exploring unchartered territory, as there are ships and stations everywhere you go.All in all, excellent game. 8/10.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
2014
Early Access Review
								Let me start by saying that if you have any interest at all in the Space/RPG genre you simply have to grab this game. Anyone who liked Freelancer, Freespace 1/2, Elite, I-War or any of the X games (apart from reunion) will be right at home here.Now for full disclosure I grabbed S♥♥♥♥ couple of months ago while it was still in Alpha stage and initially I wasn't too impressed. While issues are to be expected when you are playing an Alpha version, on my low-mid system, frame rate and stability issues kept me from playing for more than a couple of hours and I left the game alone for a while until some of these things were worked out.Boy! What a difference a couple of months makes. I figured since it finally got it's nice new "Beta" tag that I'd fire it up again and I'm really glad that I did, over 12 hours in the last 3 days can attest to how much fun I've been having with it.The basic premise of the game is your a star ship captain dropped into a dynamic living game world and your free to do pretty much whatever you want in a sandbox environment. (As of this writing the more linear campaign option has not been added yet, but is coming down the pipe shortly) : Feel like transporting VIPs or cargo from one sector to another, while enjoying the scenery? Check.Want to make your fortune by mining asteroids and junk yards? Check.Indescriminately want to blow up (Or at least try) any ship that comes near you? Check.Pros:Mind blowing number of ships to choose from (If you have the cash of course!)Plenty of factions to work with or against.3 unique classes with choices on which enhancements and perks to put into different skills when you level up.Galactic news and events that actually happen in the gameworld rather than being just Lore or Fluff.Excellent ship to ship tactical combat.Player driven goals, shall I save my money for a new ship or shall i upgrade my weapons and components?Cons:UI needs to provide more feedback. (Not being able to see the target summary unless your looking right at it, is a bit of a pain)Easy for a new player to be a little lost when first starting out, text tutorials are not ideal, but they do the job.Still a few performance and stability issues at times, which is to be expected with the game still being in BETA stage.Still some balancing issues with certain weapon types that need to be fleshed out, Beams being the prime example.Suggestions:Trading - Someway of knowing where to buy low and sell high would be nice, right now it's a bit of a crapshoot.Mission markers - How about different markers for each mission type? Would also be nice in the case of a point A to point B mission if the point B marker was a different color on the map screen.Event markers - After reading galactic news it would be nice to be able to at least select a few of them and have location specific news appear on the galactic map. (Bob spotted in the smith sector, should be able to mark the smith sector on the map so you don't have to go hunting around)Overall SG2 is shaping up very nicely and I highly recommend it, with a great DEV team who constantly provide feedback to player comments, it's only going to get better and better.

This is the first game I've played where you actually feel like other people are aboard your ship helping you - normally its do everything yourself, from steer, to fire to damage control - whereas with SG2 you can do as much or as little as you wish.

Early Access Review
								OK, so the game is great. Looks great, sounds great, fun to play, everything about it is awesome.EXCEPT that it's Beta, like really Beta. While it's a fun as hell game to play it crashes pretty consistently every 30 minutes or so. It has done this to me so many times that while I have 11 hours on record with steam I have only actually progressed through the game for 6.5, so just over half. The main reason for this huge loss of time has to do with the save system. It's pretty stupid: you can only save while docked, and (right now at least) you loose those missions (not failed, you loose access to those missions as if they never existed) so every time the game crahes before I can save I loose whatever time I invested into the game.So consider this game in an update or two. Or play at your own risk. Granted right now there is no story so you're really loosing free play, which is no real big deal.

content:
7, 2015
												Game is very good for awhile, nice amount of things to do. Great controls, upgrades, options and visuals.But eventually, it's not the repetition of missions that grows old, it's the feeling that nothing around you changes, you can't own anything, build anything, destroy anything, push enemies back. So eventually becomes very stagnant. I totally get the dynamic stuff would be hard to implement, but then perhaps an easier way to liven things up is to throw in some random stuff like starports getting blown up (then coming back online after repairs), or certain races getting push back into the fringes or something. You can basically just settle into trading and fighting between two starports and essentially, aside from the background visuals not being different than another area... that.. is all the game becomes.  It's too bad because it has great potential and I admitedltly spent hours upon hours playing this game (65 I think). But I hit a point where the after reaching the 4 edges of the map, there was simply nothing else to do but even that is not bad, it's the feeling that nothing you do has any effect. Even trading seems to have no effect on prices or anything from what I can tell. I totally recommend it. But with the caveat that you too may hit this point where it just stops being interesting.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
y 8, 2015
												I'll cover the game, but first I need to talk about the developers.This game is helmed by the best company/team I've ever encountered in a long time. They work & worked very hard on this SG2 which was even a joy to play incomplete in the earlier betas - constantly (like to the point of how do you get any work done?) reading, replying, and participating in forum discussions. They entertain ideas for how to approach planned features & possiblities of integrating new ones. This game is far from done in their eyes, and we are all excited to see how SG2 evolves over the long run.Oh yeah, the game: The graphics are awesome. The difficulty is varied enough to appeal to everyone (I'm in the extreme club, and find it quite challenging at times). You feel the constant itch to explore as available ship components, slot enhancements, crew officers, mercenaries, and new ship models differ between areas - and buying a ship direct from the manufacturer is cheaper than buying 3rd party from a different faction.Don't want to or can't buy a ship (because that faction hates you)? Grind rep and switch sides, or just board and capture the ship for yourself. Want to mine asteroid fields? You can do that. Want to capture ships and sell them for millions? You can do that too. Want to hunt down obsure achievements? They're here.And this game is only going to get better.Positive+ Awesome community+ Gameplay rewarding proper piloting+ Mod support (check out sound, graphics, and UI mods)+ Craftable rare drops (blueprints) that feel as good in use as they are frustrating to get+ Power management+ Huge map+ Wormholes!+ Great music+ Interesting campaign storylineNeutral+/- Slow start - it's very hard to begin classing up in ships, especially for new players. There are guides, but there is a bit of a grind. I like the payoff feeling from earning your way. Others will just go get a mod that gives them 1 billion credits. I suggest learning.Negative- Voice acting (there is a mod that improves a bit).- Illegal goods priced roughly equivalent to expensive legal goods.- Trade market prices could be more varied for better profits.- Few factors past pool numbers for shields and hulls.- Unrealistic aggro (2 gunships will "think" they can take on your dreadnought and rip you out of cruise speed).

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
, 2015
												This game is super fun; I like Star Trek, Firefly, Cowboy Bebop, etc. and when I'm in that mood SG2 in perfect. Every time I resume my game the first thought I have is that this is a great, immersive game. It's really frustrating to see negative reviews because I love this game so much. The developers continue working on it and it keeps getting better which is really saying something since I loved it at early access. recommend for any sci-fi fan that wants a single player open world experience with a ton of ways to play. It's viable to be a miner and buy ships and outfit them just for that. I personally spent several fun hours just doing that, it was great. You can buy and upgrade ships just for smuggle or escort or freelancing. People complain about the expense of ships versus reward of missions; these people simply don't get it. There are lots of ways to build your bank roll and the time and effort it takes make the game more rewarding and immersive. The balance makes it so much better as you progress, you can't just jump from the first ship to the most powerful ship or even the most powerful weapons right away, and that is good. You actually get to enjoy and explore each level of progress , as you get a new ship, or a new upgrade and you slowly work toward that next purchase. All the while playing however you want, avoiding combat in favor of mining and trade which is super fun, figuring out how to avoid destruction or detection while making the kesel run in under 3 parsecs. Or you can be a pirate, good or bad, hijacking ships with a ship optimized just for that sort of activity. So good. So highly recommended.

content:
y 12, 2015
												If you enjoyed Freelancer, you'll love this. Many similar mechanics, with great ship customization. Maneuvering in space to get the best angles during a fight are fantastic, and managing your troops and ship's abilities and shields make every fight unique and fun.The story mode has bad writing and worse voice acting as well as being quite linear, so I'm mostly using it just for the experience to get bigger and better ships.The most frustrating bit of the game are the crashes. I've yet to have a single play session which didn't crash on me aty least 3 times. You'll be in the middle of a huge fight, and the game will suddenly die. The best thing the Devs did was implement auto save whenever you visit a space station or planet. But if you get in a middle of a big fight out in space and suddenly the game locks up, God help you.-- Edit: I wrote this mini-review/opinion piece a while ago, and the game is far, far, far more stable. Over the time since it was written, the Development team have been awesome in their implementation of not only new features, but bug fixes. The aforementioned random crashes are gone. Thoroughly enjoy this game.

content:
19, 2014
Early Access Review
								Holy ♥♥♥♥.  Ok this game is going to be very good when it's done but at the moment it is completely unplayable.  I have a very good P.C with 12gb of RAM that runs everything else I have at maximum settings with no problem.  When I first downloaded and started the game it was working reasonably well with only the slightest lag when I approached different bases and planets.  As soon as I started getting into battles with other ships the frame rate dropped down to what I swear must have been 2fps!  Frequently it would just freeze for 5 or 10 seconds straight before moving again!  I of course decided to reduce all of my graphic settings down to minimum in the hopes of speeding up the frames.  It made no difference at all!  Maybe not everyone is having this same problem but trust me my P.C should be more than adequate to run this!Besides this though the game is visually very cool and the combat is enjoyable.  They're doing a lot of things right I just wish I was able to actually play it properly right now.(update): After starting the game again today it has been working much better for the time being.  Something strange did happen however.  I suddenly had an extra 5 million credits when I had only had about $9000 when I had quit previously.  Furthermore I didn't even make 5 million credits in my first 2 hours of gameplay.  It was certainly a welcome glitch but I don't think that was intentional.  I have changed my review to a thumbs up as the only problem I previously had with the game at all was the performance issue and hopefully that only occured because it was my first time playing the game after installation.

content:
6, 2016
												If you are into sims (as in simulating [duh] or role playing) this is a great space game. It is - as far as I can tell at this point - single player only and it reminds me of EVE from CCP but more beginner-friendly, although still not easy.If you dislike grinding, abort immediately. You'll grind A LOT. I find it worth, the ambiente is amazing, the somewhat small storyline is interesting (if you read and listen) but the action you take is repetitive. I read a lot about bugs, but have not encountered any yet (~29h). Every item has a nice description that is not generic, for example for the solar panels it says that they "are an important part in Gemini due to the dual star system" or similar.Workshop is available, you can get your Star Wars or StarTrek sounds, ships etc.__e.: My savegame was corrupted (after loading into the save a mission I wanted to accept was invisible), I do not know what happened, but the guys at LGM looked at the savegame and repaired it! That is some awesome dedication. Great game by great people!

content:
10, 2016
												I had fun tooling in this game.  It's got a good sense of progression, and it's not exactly lacking in depth or scope. One complaint is that it's not as polished as it could be.  Released in 2014, you can tell a lot of great art and design work was put into this game but it's already starting to show it's age.  I personally compare it to a game like Elite Dangerous, which has a high amount of finish and looks great, but is ultimately a very boring game which lacks depth and has a very frustratingingly long grinding progression. Starpoint Gemini on the other hand, has better pacing.  While it may not be as technically complex or broad in scale, it's a good break as a single player game.

content:
5, 2014
Early Access Review
								Okay...I've been playing for a week or so now, and am overall VERY pleased with the game.  There are several bugs that obviously need to be chased down and cleaned up, but if you are a fan of the space (trading) games of the past, then this will win your heart.  There isn't much of a story line yet, but the sandbox (freeform) mode is exceptional, not to mention HUGE!  Did I mention that the map is HUGE?For a fact, there are more opponents, stations, friends, and asteroids to keep you busy for a VERY long time.  It's because the map is HUGE!The game is more akin to Freelancer than to Mass Effect (at least until they get the story part released), and you have so many options to build and customize your ship(s) it's going to make GOTY for space sims.The visuals are a little less important than the action and details, and you get to blow stuff up.  A LOT of stuff.  It's probably because the map is HUGE!Spend the money.  Buy the game.  Enjoy wiping out lots of enemies on the HUGE map.

content:
, 2015
												This is a really good space game.The game offers various control methods to let you fly your ship like a pilot/dogfighter or play more of a commander role using turret view. At first it takes a while to get used to the controls and fight effectively with a style you like but once you play out a few battles out you will find a control style that suits you and probably end up switching between them depending on the situation and the ship you are using.The graphics and interface are really nice and the game runs very well on my medium system which is an AMD APU with integrated graphics.The sound effects are good but some cool warp like sound effect for the t-drive would be nice. The music is very good although perhaps some more variety would be nice especially for the battle music. The story and voice acting is probably the weakest part of the game but the game offers plenty of freedom to explore space and play how you want to. So you can play like a pirate or a trader, mine or do missions etc. There's plenty to do and it's all fun.The game has a nice rpg element which means you can upgrade your skills for when you are in battle and upgrade perks for various different effects like trading bonuses or ship capture bonuses etc. You can customise your ships weapons and buy bigger and better guns and ships as you progress through the ranks and acquire more credits. Overall I would recommend getting this game, especially if you are into space games.

content:
4, 2015
												This is a great space combat game, with RPG elements.  Cruising through space, capturing ships, looting and upgrading is a lot of fun.  There are not too many games in this genre. They all seeml to be too old, too complex or they require subscriptions.  Starpoint Gemini 2 is a winner. Short comments on the game:- It is more arcade than simualtion. - The story is not bad, but the presentation is very weak. - At times the voice acting is rediculously bad-  Dont worry about the story becuase the gameplay is engaging and addictive- The graphics are great, minus a few hiccups here and there- Would take about 30-40 hours to play through campaign- Lots to do in this game. DLC is also available and the devs love to support this game- Stop and take a screen capture! F11 will hide all the HUDs so your screen capture comes out like a Carl Sagan wet dream. - The trading and mining is weak, but the value and money making is in capturing enemy ships and selling them and their cargo. Its 5x better than running materials from one side of the map to the other to make money.- There are some great video tutorials on youtube that can jumpstart your ship capturing / pirating skils .  Search: "Tensiaka" on youtube for valuable ship cap[turing and combat tutorials,. They helped me a lot. Make a few million in your first couple hrs ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Despite a few flaws, the gameplay, ship options and open world win out.  I  give it   --   8.5/10

content:
, 2015
												I am loving this game - it feels like a mashup of X3, Elite and  a couple of other games.Your starter ship is good mix of everything, good size cargo bay, two weapon points (light - railguns, heavy missiles).  upgrading it is expensive so take care of it.You earn money by trading, completing missions, mining.  You can also try pirating, though this doesn't suit my game play.The universe is a series of hex's that you fly across normally.  Alternatively, their are gateways between locations that require jump drives, worm holes that require increased health (haven't managed to get through one yet) and rift lines, which accelerate your speed whilst you are in the rift.  The subtle difference between worm hole and rift - I think - is that you are exposed to enemy fire in the rift, but not in the wormhole.There is a story (and with the DLC, a second one), but often you will find yourself doing "things".  I targeted a level 2 pirate and thought it would be easy, but he called for help, deciding to avoid the agro, I pushed the engines to max, turned and flew through a rift and ended up in the middle of an uncharted system, alive, but with a battered ship.It is a slow paced game - so far at least - but you have to learn that your ship is NOT a fighter, but a small frigate with a crew and gimballed turrets which you can either fire, or have the crew fire.  Later you can buy carrier vessels or cloaked vessels.  You can also command some sort of fleet (hiring mercenaries to accompany you).Like I say, I am loving this.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
5, 2015
												This game could be so great. A real worthy successor for the likes of Freelancer and Privateer but it has so many flaws that it is very close to not being recommendable...I still recommend it though for those in urgent need of a space sim who don’t like Elite: Dangerous and can’t wait for Star Citizen since chances are good that you still will get lost in the vicious circle of just one more mission to be one step closer to the next upgrade/weapon/ship.Let’s start with the good things:I really like the music…ok… that’s not all, there is so much to see and do in this game, too. The galaxy is huge and there are many (unique) space stations and planets to visit, missions to do, artifacts/blueprints to track down and especially ships to destroy, buy or capture. Yes, you can capture enemy ships – in theory – that is one part where the design just doesn’t work out so well, more on that later. You also gain experience and level up which will give you skill points and every 5 level a point for perks. Skills feel rather cheap and bad for me. There are 4 active skills (temporary boosts) you can invest your points in, each skill for one of the available weapon systems (railgun, plasma, beam and heavy (missiles)). So you basically decide which is your favorite weapon system and put your skill points into that skill. Perks are passive but also don’t feel that well thought out. Again you can increase the effectiveness of your favorite weapon system up to 3 times and then there are a lot of semi useful perks to invest in. Additionally you get permanent bonuses by getting (steam) achievements (never seen that before in a game...)The actual space simulation needs to get used to, too. I was expecting a feeling like in the old games and even bought a joystick to get the good old times back, but that just doesn’t work out (for me). The shooting is turret based (you have chase cam and no cockpit view anyway), meaning you can see around your ship and you just move the camera freely and aim with your mouse (depending on the turret placement on the ship). Furthermore the hit feedback is so bad that I quickly decided to switch to beam weapons that are instant hit so I know where I aim is what I hit. Railgun and plasma are projectiles flying somewhere in the direction of the enemy and unless you are not fighting a huge freighter close combat you barely see if you hit or not and especially if not why not (ok, it might just need to get used to but beam seems the better solution). Also you can just tell the system to auto fire (that's why there are acurracy stats you can influence, but I want to play the game as space shooter and not strategy game like star wolves so I don't want to use autoaim...)What is really bad and I don’t understand how the design can fail so hard is that you can’t see your enemy information in the hud. Instead the hud is clustered with stupid, bad looking buttons I barely use (which I could easily access by keys). You only see the enemy information when the enemy is in sight and when he is close it is so fast moving that you can barely read it. So what is happening all the time is: There is a bunch of enemies closing in, you see them in the radar, you can target them (via hotkey) but you have either to start flying into their direction (which is a great idea when it turns out that they are deadly) or switch to turret and target mode and move your camera wildly to get them into focus and be able to identify their threat level. Both very inconvenient since you should be able to quickly cycle through all targets and identify them with one glance. Well perhaps I’m missing something, there even is an info hotkey but it won’t work for enemy ships, only for special objects.The other really bad design issue is the character level system. You level up quite fast and the missions you can get (you don’t have to visit stations to get missions, you will get them while in space, which is good) show the suggested level you should have to take that mission. The problem is: the character level does tell ♥♥♥♥ about your actual strength. That only depends on your ship and weaponry. So this indicator is useless in the first place. Coincidentally it is also useless in the second place because there are types of missions that are just no brainers – regardless of which level they show. If you have maintenance or science missions you just fly to the target, repair or inspect it aaand… it’s done. On the other hand, good luck with rescue or capture missions, which are often impossible even on low level. So the balancing is very bad in general but luckily you can cheat your way out most of the time: Early game you just start your engine boosters and outrun every enemy, mid game they sometimes start blocking your boost mode but you can have a ship with cloaking device by then and just turn that on. Later this doesn't work and thats when you get in real trouble…Talking about capturing… first you can’t capture 90% of the enemies because they have a larger crew than you have (capturing works this way: grapple the enemy with a tractor beam, send troops via teleporter to his ship, if you have more than him you possibly take over the ship). You can focus on capturing by searching for a cheap ship which allows a large army of troopers on board and you can get perks or officers (you can hire 3 officers for your ship, by the way, you can also hire merc ships that follow you and certain ships allow to take fighters on board you can launch during combat so you end up having your own fleet) that give a bonus on the capturing chances.Second most of the time there are other ships around. So even when you manage to find a capturable ship chances are high that it will get blown apart by some other ship nearby. So it is a great feature in theory that just is no real fun most of the time but satisfying when it finally works.Other weaknesses I like to mention:The presentation is really bad. The main story has a ridiculous voice over most of the time, sometimes just dialog (not sure if it is a bug that voiceover is not playing because the music gets muted anyway) and sometimes just a text popup – atmosphere = 0.The balancing of the main and some side missions is also a bad joke. You will be stuck for hours until you have enough money for a capable ship and after you finally progress you often get much easier missions afterwards.The menus are confusing and tedious to use. E.g. you can either sell all cargo or one good at the merchant, but if you have more than 1 of a good you always have to go to the next screen to select how much of the good you want to sell (well everything!). And you will do that a lot because the screen shows if you are having good, mediocre or bad prices so you most likely don’t want to sell the goods with bad prices and rather fly to the next station. I think the ship loadout menu is simply bugged. edit: it is not bugged, turret handling is just another unintuive feature. Also when I unmount a rocket launcher I lose my missiles. The good thing is that I can store my ships with their loadout in my garage and can swap them easily depending on the situation (cargo space/troop count/gun power).But the weapon/ship prices balancing could be much better. The next better systems are so expensive that it takes hours until you can afford something new that actually feels more powerful. The upgrade flow was much better/faster in Freelancer.Last but not least there are that most annoying situations where a cutscene triggers in the middle of a fight, you can’t do anything but the fight continues in the background usually resulting in your death or at least a great headstart for your enemies.So there are many occasions in the game where I ask myself: Did the developers actually play what they created?And then I go back to the game desperately hunting for the next better ship…
