number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
2016
												Starpoint Gemini 2 is an enjoyable Space Sim, and still looks good for its age, but I wouldn't grab it for the $35 price. It's definitely a game to buy on sale though. Some key points:1. This is a combat focused game. Don't bother trying to be a trader; it won't work, and you can't automate the process like in X3.2. Along 1 above, the primary way you can make money in this game is capturing ships. Unless you want to end up outclassed, learn how to use your troopers and grappling beam. 3. The progression through the classes of ships is well balanced; each feels like an improvement, without any of them feeling redundant.4. Each class of ship does feel unique, and the methodology of flying and fighting in a corvette is distinctly different than in a dreadnought.5. The different models of ships in each class are also rather distinct from one another, and will play well with different tactics. For instance, one ship may have great overlapping fire arcs between the side and front turrets, but have hardly any coverage on the top bottom and the back, while another will offer ballanced coverage over the whole ship, but can't offer the same forward punch.5. Ye gods, the voice acting is TERRIBLE, and the plot is a throw away at best. This wasn't a big issue for me, as the game is mostly free-roam.

The freeroam aspect is awesome and the ability to break away from whatever you are doing to pursue an enemy, deliver some goods, or just mess around compares to games like the X series. content:
r 20, 2015
												This game a is a tough one to decide. It really isn't a game that I can sit and dump 8 hours into daily like some of the other games I've played, but it is fun to come back to it every once in a while and get my "freelancer" fix for the week. I personally found this game to be pretty fun when in sandbox/exploration mode. Story mode on the other hand.. was poorly completed, I believe I spent about 20 minutes in, and dumped it due to the appalling voice acting and poorly scripted story.  Now for sandbox I loved flying around blasting and capturing ships to sell at the local stations. I loved upgrading my ship from the inventories of captured  ships. I'm always looking for the shield or weapon improvment. I loved exploring the map and seeing all the cool spacial anomalies. UnfortunateIy, though I did find some general weaknesses in the way content is utilized in the game, there are only a handful of side mission types such as capture ship A, Destroy ship B, or Haul element C these side missions do get old pretty quickly and is a main reason why I cannot dump countless hours into the game in one sitting. Sometimes I also receive missions I have no way in hell of completing, the AI levels way faster than I do... I'll be level 4 with missions that are level 12 around the beginning area. It's ok as you can just drop the mission, but is kinda annoying all the same. Overall, I find the game to be pretty engaging when played casually, but any longer than a couple of hours and I'm ready for something else. I've been looking at Elite: Dangerous but it looks like a tremendous amount of tedious work to play, just from peoples reviews, that and it's much more expensive.To the developer: I really hope you guys haven't given up on this game now that it's considered "Complete" there is still a tremendous amount of possibilities with it, and I would love to see more content(More engaging space stations, etc.) Thanks a ton for creating a game that allows me to get my space sim fix when I feel the urge. RatingsGraphics: 8/10Story: 4/10Game Play: 9/10 Overall: 7/10

Horribly frustrating, has some good points, but overall its a very bad game.The main thing, the fighting - it sucks, 99% of the time you have to turn on auto shooting, because you can't find on the screen enemies, they just keep flying outside of your view all the time, and it doesnt matter if it is a destroyer and you are flying with corvette it still jumps around you like if it was a small fly. number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
r 14, 2015
												I purchased this game almost immediately during early access because I had been wanting to play a good space sim for quite a long time. It is a vast improvement over the previous title in the series and successfully creates a fun space sim experience with some rpg progression for your character. Initially after release the game was somewhat buggy, but the developers have ironed out the rough edges and even successfully adapted most of the user interface for gamepad control. Thus far I have spent most of my time in the sandbox mode, but I have recently begun the story playthrough. Both modes are fun to play with the story mode featuring a rather standard, but competently-executed space sim plot. Best of all is that steam workshop is available for the game and there have been many great mods that improve aspects of the gameplay as well as those that create custom content. There is a good diversity of ships and weaponry in the game, with ship types ranging from small gunships and shuttle craft up to battleship size vessels available to be purchased. You can also hire officers who confer stat bonuses and other ships piloted by mercenaries to join you. There are numerous ways to make money including a robust trading economy, asteroids to mine, spatial phenomena to explore, odd jobs to be done, transport/taxi missions, and of course bounty hunter missions.Combat is satisfying, though you certainly feel like more of a ship commander than a pilot. This is probably due to the game's third person perspective which suits the game well because most of the ships you will use are more like capital ships than fighters. To sum it up, this is one of the best single player space sim/rpg's to come out in a very long time. In some ways I enjoy this game more than Elite: Dangerous.

content:
30, 2015
												I liked the game so far, but I play a lot. I am an avid player of sci fi games, medieval, simulation battle and strategy. I play games so much I do not have any other form of life except work and games. I do stay in shape as I work out a lot. I can practically tell you exactly how to make a good game and it will be a #1 top seller, I have even made games myself constucting whole citys and governments with plots and story lines along with political agendas on governments and war. This Starpoint Gemini is very promising and is a good game. Couple of pointers to the developers, you should have ships hunt you down as if looking for you and then take off before being destoyed. Somone you can recognize that you have seen before but make some what elusive so he/she can come back again to hunt you from a jurisdiction you are not welcomed of course, but this should be once in great while not an everytime thing. Another thing is that when you get high level in the game all you see is big hard ships all the time, almost no small ones. In the begining you would see them a lot. I am level 80 and it does not seem to be going any highier(no complaints). But sometimes you exit from a station or a star gate and you are jumped by a horde of big ships just out of the blue(c'mon a little ridiculouse at times)it happens often and half the time you dont stand a chance unless you have big hired mercenarys that are expensive to maintain, which does take a big toll on the money you make. Sometimes you fall behind unless you really try to keep up the hustle and bustle of making money, then its more stress instead of pure enjoyment to try and keep good powerfull mercenarys at youre side. You should fan it out more to where at least 50% of the time there are still smaller groups of ships, or one or two important people(hunters) that show up to hunt you like I said previously, Instaed of being mobbed by a lot of big powerfull ships all the time. There still needs to be smaller ships around of all sizes. All I see now are big ships everywhere and almost no small ones traversing through space or hanging out at space stations. Its almost as if everybodys super rich now and got dreadnaughts and carriers becouse I am level 80 now. You need to tone that down to be more normal. If you did that the game would excell in greatness, otherwise that is a major downfall. But I do see it getting bigger more powerfull ships to attack you as you are highier in level that makes sense, but overall it needs to be re-worked to how i mentioned previously, thank you...... Several hours later on re-editing, I am now back to write what I said. There is more randomness, I guess i was just to fast to express at 80th level. I went back in different parts of the galaxy, it does get heavy at times and then again light on battles just depends. Also what i like is there are also missions you can take that can be much lower than youre level and also much highier. There still needs to  be ones that hunt you down and occasionally escape to come back another time but with a name to them you can recognize. May i also add i have not played the story line yet and am looking forward to it, its just in the free roam you can choose other characters instead of bieng stuck with the same story line one. Overall its all good and was very enjoyable playing. Would be nice to have another dozen songs in the game, the music is similar to eve music which I liked a lot when I played eve back in 2009.

content:
r 9, 2014
												There's quite a few things to like in this space trading/shooter game. The developers have managed to infuse a fair bit of live into this one, and it does have some pretty neat game mechanics. The best way of defining it is as a crossover of Freelancer and Starfleet Command, even if I find SPG 2 to be neatly an inferior game to both. Compared with Freelancer, this title hasn't delivered for me the same degree of immersion and engagement with the storyline and the universe that I remember of playing Freelancer. Compared to the second, the tactical combat in this game to be flawed in some departments and shallower, even if there are some cool ideas in here.The stuff I like Even if we're restricted to one single system, there's indeed a lot of places to go and things to see. This is a *big* game. Trading and mining are actually viable professions, not just an side to mercenary or piratical activities. There's lots of ships, and lots of modules to fit your ships with.  Combat is engaging, and fun, at least for some time. I do like very much the "ammo-based" modules (scavenger drones, mining torpedoes, etc.). These modules can be swapped in flight - which might detract from a plausibility point of view, but I personally don't mind it much - and you can actually feel like having a purpose (they're quite useful actually). The game is highly moddable.The stuff that leaves me indifferent or I am not very impressed by While there's a great variety of weapons, I find that rather than having 5 varieties of the same thing with slightly tweaks to range, damage, power drain, etc. it would have made sense to have just one type and increase the "rigging possibilities". Per-module rigging is in  the game, but you can just add one type of rig to one specific module. You can recruit crew, but this crew is reduced to specific buffs to your ship (weapon accuracy, speed, etc.). They level out, and do provide with an extra layer of ship customization. But sometimes the bonuses are so specific that one wonders why are you paying religiously salaries on a monthly basis. There's no enemy leveling - that is, if you go to certain places you may find yourself vastly overmatched by NPC ships. Knowing when to engage and when to fly is an important skill to develop. The problem comes when these "hero" NPCs basically can appear anywhere and the information that allows you to assess whether or not you're outclassed is only visible if you keep it in your sights. Which can be quite difficult. The combat skills system looks good, but very much as with the crew, lacks some depth (and you also wonder why you should bother with those skills).The stuff I plainly don't like The HUD is functional, but I would have really liked that I could have waypoints (that is, locking on locations) and targets (that is, locking on ships and stations) at the same time. Currently, you either have a waypoint or a target. Even worse is that the waypoint/target data is only visible if you have your bow pointed towards the object you locked on. That makes stuff like checking on nearby hostile ships while travelling towards your destination disorienting or just plainly dangerous (since you will close onto these enemies). The world is very much structured like that of Privateer/Freelancer, but crammed into one single star system. What was plausible in those games, here feels a bit uncomfortably contrived. Even if the world is big, I didn't get that "to boldly go where nobody has before" kind of vibe that you get in Elite Dangerous or Evochron Mercenary, for instance. I find the main storyline to be completely uninteresting, and delivered in a very unappealing way.It's a cheap game, indeed, but since I haven't enjoyed it much, I can't really recommend it to anyone.

												It is interesting but fairly basic compared to other spaceship exploration type of games.  The combat is very fast and takes some of the nuance out of the skills. These crashes aren't just the game, they often freeze up my system in a way I haven't experienced in years.In researching this problem one comes across many attempted solutions (which I tried many) from others and then dev posts that point to it being a problem with Windows 10, and that they do not and will not support this game under Windows 10.  Also read from the dev posts that "this game is 2 years old" so they are not focused on supporting it further.  So, buyer beware.

content:
er 24, 2016
												Starpoint Gemini 2 is easily the best space adventure game available!  Little Green Men Games did a superb job in incorporating those features that make a space exploration game enjoyable while avoiding anything that would be dull.There is a main-story quest line to keep you engaged with multiple side quests to mix things up.  Space travel feels exciting and scenic without taking years in between events (with added wormholes to speed things up a little more).  There are space pirates, some dangerous while others are targets of opportunity for some quick cash, especially if you capture their ship to sell to a nearby friendly space station.There seems to be just the right number of ship and weapon variety to not get overwhelmed while still feeling like you have a choice in weapon loadout and ship type.  There are even some that you acquire through quest lines or obtaining blueprints for exceptional weapon types, including torpedoes, plasma cannons, railguns, etc.Lots of Steam achievements, beautiful scenery, fantastic spacestation design.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Only been playing Early Access Beta a few hours and so far I'm really enjoying it,Bit of a space sim fan in general…This reminds me some of Freelancer and EVE online.Beta access is “freeroam”, I’ve found that it is fairly easy to pick up the basics but takes a while to get proficient, there is some real depth here and I’ve only scratched the surface.First impressions, this game is looking great! Can only imagine how good it could be if it supported a multiplayer PU and had an optional cockpit/bridge view.To early to call yet, but this game shows so much potential I think I can rate it in my top 5 space sims.Anyhow having a blast so far and excited to see how the finished product plays!Edit 8th of October 2014 My first impressions of SPG2 was that it might make my favourite top 5 space sims… it has the potential but it lacks a few vital essentials like a functional overview such as Freelancer. I was probably more than 20 hours into my early access when I realized just how much I missed it.It’s no game breaker but having played Freelancer for well over 1500hrs and EVE online for much more you quickly realize just how much it holds the game back from being so much better. I’ve put some 140 hrs into the game (including beta) and I’m far from finished with it.The good news is that some serious HUD tweaks are coming... the DEV’s have worked  tirelessly to address a few bugs that appeared at launch and they’ve been responding to some imbalance issues relating to levelling, the game having only been released a few weeks ago is already feeling much better!Visually the game scores 9/10    Just beautiful!Soundtrack 9/10      Really great soundtrack.Storyline 6/10     Story was OK, I just didn’t get into it. Just dialogue, no character cut scenes at all. Voice acting 6/10  Some were hilarious they were so bad.Gameplay 8/10  Some solid gameplay mechanics, easy to get into but hard to master.Replay ability 9/10  I got my money’s worth just playing the Beta early access!General Content 9/10  Some real quality ships, gear, missions, bounties, capture ship gameplay etc…LGM Dev’s 10/10 Never come across such a great team working so hard with so little.I just finished the story mode… overall I enjoyed it, I’ve still got a few high bounties to go after and I haven’t explored all of the map. The game as far as the DEV’s are concerned isn’t finished they have a big wish list of features they still hope to implement and honestly I can’t wait.Starpoint Gemini 2 easily makes it into my top 10 space sim games and if you’e looking for something to fill the void while we wait for Star Citizen, Elite Dangerous etc Just get it already.SPG2 will keep on getting better as they go and I’m looking forward to it and new content.

content:
ber 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								I do not feel it's fair or accurate to describe this game as "Eve Offline", but it does give you a good idea of what you are going to get. Starpoint Gemini 2 looks great! And I really do love not having loading times. I haven't been able to explore the game's entire map yet but I can tell you it is huge and despite you are traveling in space it doesn't get boring. There is plenty of stuff to look around for, side quests, random encounters, etc. I can see myself spending 80+ hours just fooling around on this game before I decide to start/continue the main storyline. The controls are perfect, they do give you the feeling that you are commanding the ship. I'm still new to ship's customization but there seems to be plenty of options, and I really can't wait to buy a better/bigger ship. I'm sure this game will satisfy your scifi adventure needs, wether you desire join a fight between enemy fleets, flee through an asteroid field from a tougher opponent, become a space pirate or just travel through space... this game has it all.

content:
er 17, 2013
Early Access Review
								Regularly updated by the developers and quickly nearing completion. How many EA titles can say that?A great space flier with fairly simple flight mechanics - a nice change after some recent space game fails. This is not a dogfighting game. You spend most of your time flying bigger boats and trying to keep as many turrets on your target as possible. Standard mission running, war participation, trading and mining. The developers are keeping the campaign under wraps until release, so I don't have enough information to say how well it all ties together. I will say that the game is playable, as is, without the campaign. Random missions pop up on your map so it is more than possible to advance without it.The price is great for the gameplay value and the campaign isn't even implimented yet. Very few bugs or flaws, and the ones that do make it in are quickly squished.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
25, 2014
Early Access Review
								I find it hard to say that I recommend this game, or even that I do not.I was a huge fan of Freelancer, and I have spent years looking for something that could fill the hole that Freelancer left behind. While Starpoint Gemini 2 comes close, it's not... quite... there yet. This game is still in development (just recently in beta), so bear that in mind.All of the pieces are there - free roaming, trading, space battles - however, SG2 seems to fall flat a key area - ship movement. The starting vessel, a frigate, I believe, looks like a fish, moves like a fish, but steers like a cow. Most combat is spent circling around trying to get a bead on your enemy for about 1/2 a second before they move out of view once more. By that point, his buddy has been firing lasers up your butt. I'm a space combat noob with this game, but even Freelancer felt like it had more "zip" to ship movement. I had to crank the mouse sensitivity just to feel like there was some kind of response to the controls.Graphically, it's quite nice. Ships, planets, stations and space "stuff" is lovely to look at.The game requires some optimization. When you are in a serious furball with many other ships, I find that the game really chugs and slows down - even if you are not involved in the combat, and it's just nearby.The game is not multiplayer, and I am not clear on whether or not it is ever going to be multiplayer. That is also a major wall for a lot of people. Freelancer was great. Freelancer with friends was amazing.This is not a Freelancer replacement, though it comes close. If you're not concerned about a multiplayer experience, you're not going to find a game that delivers what this one does at this price point. However, I would wait for later in the beta cycle or even for wide release. It's not quite ready for prime time.

												18 hours in and so far this game is exellent. VERY similar to Freelancer for old school gamers out there. For new people think 3rd person space shooter with trading, mission, piracy or whatever. There are tons of different ships, weapons, loadouts and play styles.Graphics are excellent and it runs really well on my rig.It can be hard in places, so don't be afraid to go away, save up and buy a bigger ship. The mission level indicators can be a little bit off. Some are waaaaaay harder than you think, then others will be easy money.Still that is life in space:I don't careI'm still freeYou can't take the sky from me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
28, 2014
												My original review (while the game was still in EA) is shown at the bottom. Please note that the sections on performance are not entirely relevant now, since the game runs much better.REVIEW AFTER RELEASE:---------------------------------------------------------The game is a mix between Freelancer and X3. You can command fleets, hire wingmen, level up skills, buy massive battleships, trade, do missions. It's a lot like Darkstar One too, if we are comparing - but a lot better.The focus here is on large ship battles - and with many ships, rather than smaller dogfigthing. Your starting ship is fairly large ( gunship), and some of the stuff I have seen to buy looks cool. You can climb the ranks and get battleships, dreadnoughts and the like, and command officers and mercs to help you out in battle, either on your own ship or as a wingman. You can even board enemy ships and take control of them, or tractor ships back to stations to sell them.It looks lovely and has a massive open map to explore, complete with anomalies, slipstreams, wormholes, gates, planets, stations asteroid fields, nebula etc. - all you would come to expect from such a game and more.The campaign is basic, but enjoyable. The voice-acting is absolutely atrocious though - the accents are all over the place and it is detrimental in an necessary way. You also have the option to free-roam, doing missions as they come along, trading or becoming a pirate. It has a complete reputation and trading system, allowing you to become anything you want.A lack of multiplayer hits hard, since this game would be infinitely better with it and a real shame it is not included. It also seems to have a fairly repetitive and grindy feel to it - hence the mark of 6/10. If it had multiplayer I think my score would jump to 8/10 instantly though.Jimbo Rating: 6/10REVIEW WHILE IN EA:---------------------------------------------------------It's a mix between Freelancer and X3. You can command fleets, hire wingmen, level up skills, buy massive battleships, trade, do missions. It's a lot like Darkstar One too, if we are comparing - but a lot better.The focus here is on large ship battles - and with many ships, rather than smaller dogfigthing. Your starting ship is fairly large, and some of the stuff I have seen to buy looks cool. You can even board enemy ships and take control of them, or tractor ships back to stations to sell them.It looks lovely, but does seem to suffer from some performance issues. Putting the lengthy loading screens aside, I frequently experienced 0FPS drops when entering new sectors (occurrs quite often), which is a royal pain in the ♥♥♥ - especially if it happens to be a wing of enemy fighters.It's still beta, but if they can fix the performance issues (severe slow downs, long load times, crashing) then this game will be a winner.Jimbo Rating: 6/10Note: why have I "not recommended" this game - even though it's good? Simple: it's nigh-on un-playable (or very frustrating) at the moment, what with the aforementioned performance issues.

content:
28, 2015
												A quick review for this really cool space game.I spent 35 hours on this game, In that time I finished the base game + one DLC, reached maximum Level and bought on the best ship. So even if I am not an expert, I think I can write a fair review.+ Great Value.  You easily can beat the game 2 / 3 times without feeling bored. And the Dev team enhanced the First Starpoint to the new engine, it should give you around 50 hours more of gameplay.+ Cool graphic; not realistic like Elite Dangerous for example, but a very nice representation of space.+ Nice gameplay /  Mix of Rpg and tactic space game ; if you play in high difficulty it can be very challenging.+ A lot of things to do.+ A lot of ships and weapons to suit all tastes.+ A extremely nice and responsive Dev Team. Basically if you post anything ( interesting ) on the steam forum, there is good chances that a Dev will be the first to answer.+ A perfect example of how a Early Access should be done and handled.+ Mod support.- Scenario not great.- A little bit short. I know it is against my + on greate value, but the thing is  I think 35 hours to reach max level is a little bit to quick; of course if you want the best weapons you will have to spend a lot of times, but it lacks the motivation of leveling up.- At the end you are incredibly overpowered. Some may consider that a + , as a kind of reward but not for me.So highly recommend this game made by a very nice and little team of passionate Dev.Will by their next project without hesitation.

content:
4, 2015
												I want to like this game however the lower quality voice acting and the eventual repetitiveness of all of the mission are what broke it for me. There are still some missions that completely bug out for me and I am unable to complete them until I fail it and try again. The main story missions can be long and you can only save at the space stations so when it does fail half way through you have to start all over again and push through the voice acting once more.Other than mousing over the faction and reading it's description there is nothing that makes any of the factions feel personal in any way.There is the basis for a great game here and some might enjoy this title. I however cannot recommend it.Update:For a 9 man indie team then this is a very well done game. I must admit I did no research before reviewing. I'm very impressed that the developers care so deeply about their project to comment on my small post and describe their plans and ambitions for the future. I have decided to change my recommendation because in light of this I want this game to succeed. Space games are the future!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
6, 2016
												Up front:  Not deep enough or fun enough to warrant a $35 entry fee.  Definitely worth it for $10.Pros:+Artwork.  Ships and backdrops are pleasant enough to look at and cruising through space in your ride of choice is nice.+Simple, easy to use interface and controls.  Love the interface.+Straightforward missions+Stable and nicely refined.  Have yet to run in to a "broken quest" or a significant bug of any kind.+Decent enough sized sandbox system to play in.  It takes 15 minutes to fly across Gemini even with the fastest ship. +Game adjusts difficulty rather well as you progress to bigger ships.+Soundtrack is a definite plus that matches the mood of the task at hand.+Lots of factions.  No, they don't really fight all that differently but...they are labeled differently.+Faction loyalty.  It is simple to see who you are friends with and who you should avoid.  System is easy and intuitive.+Decent variety of ships, loots and weapons keeps things interesting.+Fighters and bombers can be launched from you ship.+Perk system.  As you gain rank you can shape your fighting style and abilities.  Easy and effective without being OP.+Steam workshop enabled.  I find looking at the hind end of an Intrepid Class is nicer than the stock ships.Cons:-Game progression can be very grindy at times.-Uncompelling campaign became unbearable because of horrid voice acting.  I began playing free-roam instead.-Ships all fly and feel the same.  A battleship handles just as well as a frigate, it just has more weapons, shields etc. :(-Unable to target specific enemy ship systems.-Sensor range is pitifully low.  You'll always see things before your sensors do.-Combat feels shallow a good portion of the time.  Tactics rarely decide outcome, usually ship stats are it.-Combat AI is downright stupid at times. As a level 18 I destroyed a level 70 pirate because they kept chasing me.  My one pea-shooter gun could hit them from 800 out, their guns could only reach 550.  As they chased me I eventually wore down their forward shield and nearly destroyed them before they turned and ran.  At that point I ran them down, overtook and finished by shooting through their non-existent forward shield.-Controls are simple, but can be awkward at times.  No target padlock option. (Really?)-3rd person views only.  You will never be "in your ship"and that hurts immersion.-No sense of running a crew.  Your "crewmen" are cards with stats that don't progress.-Game does not track ships destroyed, troops lost, total money accrued etc.  Nice touches that are easy to make.-Small variety in mission types.  Scan something, shoot something, ferry something.  That's pretty much it.-No ability to build up a true fleet, can just hire a couple mercs.-No feel of actually influencing events in the game world.-When you dock at a station or planet, all interactions are handled through a simple splash screen.Summary:Starpoint Gemini 2 is a nice little space romp for casual/arcade crowds.  I would personally prefer options available to transform this basic game experience into something a little more hardcore.  Replayability is hurt by lack of simulation options, inability to shape conflict and shallow combat mechanics.  Less than 20 hours in I have a dreadnought class warship, have maxed out alliances with half the factions and explored roughly 60% of the systems in the game.  I do not feel as though I will make any substantial new discoveries at this point, just find combinations of things already previously seen.  The game has begun to feel like a "digital fishbowl" but may come back if I find myself in the mood for mindless point and click with a spaceship involved.  Score: 7.5

content:
r 1, 2016
												Yes get this game, wait do you need to hear the dialog and be given direction? Okay less one sided. But if those are both no then hell yes get this game.Where to start, I got this game on sale, and wanted to refund it. However I gave it one more try and managed to get through the first little bit, and all of a sudden I loved it like crazy...Side notes I guessI really like the ship details and variety, although I wish there were more. (I always want more ships)The story line got kind of lame and or broken near the end.The main dialog is painful. Punishment for warcrimes painful...So if you are going to give it a go -Turn off the dialog! ----Do IT! (the music is nice though, and in freeroam the dialog is much less death)-And get ready to be spammed like crazy by "helpful" tutorial pop ups as soon as you start. (some are very helpful)----You can skip them or dissable them at your discretion though so not a big deal.-You can zoom out with the numpad +/- keys-You need to restore default keybinds when you start, or the delete key doesn't bring up your tactical view (which once up is handy)I think those are the main things that coloured my lack of enjoyment with it at first, so knowing that you should have a much better run of it. Oh I found the gunner class was less entertaining than the other two classes, even if you are mostly planning on shooting everythingBut seriously I have had a heck of a lot of fun with this game, and will likely continue to do so for a good bit more. I haven't tried all the ships yet and there are still some achievements to go.

content:
r 1, 2016
												I Love this game. Its a space RPG but you never you leave your ship. Sure its a bit old but graphics and gameplay are great.Its not too simplistic to be considered an arcade space shooter but not a mad in depth space simulator. Its quite easy to learn how to pilot, fight, nav and trade. Along the way you got many ship upgrades and ships. However be prepared to earn the credits to buy these. The space fighting is alot of fun, however its very level dependent if you engage with an emeny above your level you die. So run away tactics are sometime needed until you own a fleet of ships. There are a few problems sometimes the space fights can just kill you in seconds. You can only save you game at stations which adds to tension but alot of time you just end up replaying the same mission or area of space because of it. The soundtrack I tured off within 4 hours of gameplay its repitive and anoying and the sound effects could be better.So gamrplay is quickly learned but sometimes the fights are too difficult.soundtrack could be better.graphics are up to standard.A fun space adventure.

ber 25, 2016
												I went into this game as a buffer between waiting on a few other games im looking forward to.  Keeping that in mind I do love all scifi/space games in general.  The beginning was difficult i was having a hard time learning the controls and ended up giving up within the first two hours.  I gave it another try and got the basics down and now am 36 hours into the game.  I found myself loving it and enjoying the mystery of the story.  From what i expect from a 30 usd game it surpasses in all categories.  Yeah tutorials are not great,  the voice overs are off sometimes  and not perfect, finding the help section or explainations in the game about buying selling or how to bounty hunt and null and void.  But with all that it is a 30 buck game reg price and i bought it for under 10 bucks.  I rather enjoy figuring out how to figure out all the aspects of making money in game.  I say 2 thumbs up for what it is and i enjoy it even though i dislike 3rd person or control the ship games where im not in a first person view.  36 hours into it im not even in the dlc yet and havent even explored all the space available in the game aswell.  I say its a win win!!!!

content:
y 2, 2015
												I love this game!! Though it should come with a warning: "Warning, this game will make you lose sleep!" heh. I've played quite a few space games throughout the years, X3 series, Wing Commander, Freespace 2, Starlancer, EVE, Star Wars X-Wing and more and this one ranks right up there imo. If you're into these types of games I highly recommend checking this one out! Pros:-Great graphics-Epic music-Fun sandboxy type of do whatever you want freedom-Devs are very active and responsive (big seller for me)-Ease of modding (probably my favorite aspect of this game)Cons:-Requires a bit of tweaking to optimize and run smoothly on lower end systems. (Though there are mods that help, and the community is always willing to help with this)-No Multiplayer (but this isn't a factor for me, in fact, it's one of the reasons I bought this game...no griefers, no obsessively overpowerful others pwning you within the first ten seconds of you logging in. And it doesn't take 8 months to be able to fly a battleship! :) )I can't think of too many cons because the devs are always working on improving things, and fixing the few bugs that have surfaced here and there. Every time I think of a con, I find out they've already fixed it!Also, I have never actually published a mod before this game. It is insanely easy to mod...you want to change your loading screen? Easy. Want to change the music? Sure, you don't have to go through some maddening process of decrypting game files just to get to them, and then re-encrypt them using 20 different programs just to do that. Want to fly a ship that looks like a banana? Yep. And you don't have to learn eleventy different programming languages to do that. There are fantastic guides that help as well. And the devs are always around somewhere willing to help. Yea, big plus for me.The sandboxy aspect is a big plus too. Want to just roam around for a bit and blow stuff up? Sure. Want to just mine and get rich trading? Yep. Want to be a wanted criminal with a limited life expectancy? No worries.

content:
30, 2014
Early Access Review
								GREAT GAME!  This blows other open-"world" space games (Evochron Merc, X: Rebirth, etc.) out of the water as far as fun and dynamics go.  You don't have to grind too much to make geat profits.  Want a new ship?  Find one you can beat, board it, capture it, captain it, then work your way up the food chain.  Environments beautifully done, as well as artwork on the ships and weapons effects.  Combat is very tactical and lgical, taking into account where your weapons are placed and requiring you be at a certain azimuth to fire from them (left side, right side, front, back), so it takes some thought and power management during battles, especially when against tough ships.  I definitely recommend!

												Played for almost 20 hours now.  Good open galaxy, fairly easy to learn and develop.  One has said a mix between Freelance and Skyrim, and that's a pretty good idea of the game.  Begin by mining some astroids to get some dough.  Build up your ship a bit, then try a few missions.  Tells you the recommended level for the mission, so that's a plus.  Can hire some mercs to help out.  Build up an armada to go for big missions.  I expect this will get a LOT of play time, similar to Skyrim.  Looks like a random generator for missions, so the game isn't over until YOU say it's over.  Advice I heard was, buy it, you won't regret it.  I don't.

content:
r 2, 2014
												7/10I really enjoy open ended space sim games. This one is a very happy medium between easy to learn and fun to play.It does not have the vast options and customization as games like EVE or X, but I would trade that for a more fun and easy to play game.Like:-Open world with a variety of play styles.-Good selection of ships and equipment loadouts.-Looks great, cool ship and station designs. fairly immersive-Easy to learn controls and interfaces, even decent camera control.-Combat is fun and sometimes intense.Really enjoyed:-Capturing ships.-Trading (Easy to use "best buy/sell" interface!)-Exploring, pirate hunting-Completing full loadouts on a ship feels very accomplishing.Dislike:-Map feels small and underwhelming.-Copy pasted missions (gets old in any game though.)-Story started out pretty lame (avenge my father! collect stuf!) but i didnt get far into it. voice acting was passable..-Random impossible difficulty battleships showing up out of nowhere, or even in a mission.-I feel like some stats are missing, or hard to manage when making a loadout. Such as:Weapon energy consumption vs regen. And how to buff regen / lower consumption?Turret arc max angles. Fix: List this on ship stats, or a visual on the loadout page would be awesome.A better display of your ships stats (the circular display looks very awesome, but is not practical when zoomed out.)Is there a display for your own crew size? I may have missed it, from my reason above.Recommended for any type of space sim fan, but definitely leaning towards casual.

content:
29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Wow, suprised! This game was actually dang good! The reviews werent wrong at all. Its very similar to the X3 / X series of games except without the headaches, no laggy menus, no shoddy UI/maps, basically its everything that you wanted X:rebirth to be.. almostIts not the best game in the world, however the developers are hard at work polishing this title into a true gem. Its esentially flying around in space doing rpg-like stuff and creating your own armada/fleet and waging war.  Theres a few small issues and bugs left to be fixed and some features that will be implemented in the future, so this title has a bright future ahead of it, even though its worth buying As-is.  Theres moddability in the game itself so im sure the modding community will be able to fix/implement what the devs do not. The devs are actually active on the forums and not just to censor creativity and announce p2w and microtransaction garbage. If you like RPGs, buy it, support it, who knows? This platform/title could have a VERY bright future ahead of it.  This is probably the only Early Access title that isnt a rip off out of the lot.... And that's coming from one of the most virilent critics of the early-access system, so you know its for real.

content:
25, 2014
Early Access Review
								This games has tons of potential. It has decent graphics, good game controls, easy to learn and best of all, it's pretty addicting. There are three character classes, different type of ship classes, different kinds of ships within the classes, four different weapon types and tons of missions to do in sandbox mode.  I've been playing as the gunner,  especializing on weapons systems,with the ability to adds different bonuses to the weapon system of choice. My weapon of choice being rail-guns.  It's up to you how you want to play. You have the option of playing as a pirate, enforcer, bounty hunter, miner, trader or a freelancer (combination of all). How effective you are doing each type of job depends on the ship, the combination of skills you select as you increase in experience and buying a license. License determine how much money you will receive depending on what the license is for. For example, a mining license will get you more money when selling ore, a police license will reward you with moneyfor everykill, and so on so forth. The point of it all is to make money, so you can get better ships and better gear, you know, the same old formula that keeps us coming back for more.  Overall I really like this game and if you are a fan of freelancer and games likes these I dont think you will be disappointed. The best part? It's only  going to get better.

content:
24, 2014
Early Access Review
								Wow. What a fantastic game! While it is in beta, I found there was lots to do in this game. Lots of exploration and complete freedom to do as you wish. In a space sim, for me at least, that's a very necessary feature. I plan on logging many more hours on this game in the future.This game is absolutely beautiful. The universe feels immense; it feels like I could fly in any direction for miles. Just set a course, put full power to engines, and see what I come across. The game rewards exploration.Some of the graphics optimization features are locked as it is in beta, but I found that lowering the graphics settings available and the game's resolution fixed any issues I was having. I anticipate that anyone with a more modern rig would have no issues running this on high settings.Overall, it's worth the price they're asking for it. Good job devs! Looking forward to what comes in the future!

content:
7, 2014
Early Access Review
								This, game. I am enjoying it for all the reasons I bought it. Specifically, the play a game with the full freedom to drift aimlessly in space to look at something and say to myself... "I should go there" and be able to go there.  Issues arise in that so far there is no campaign, so there is a no guided leveling structure. Which is nice and freeform, but leaves you with a... "hrmm, now what", feeling similar to the sims or minecraft if you don't have a personal goal.  So far, you start off as  a rather beefy frigate off the bat, and from there are told there are other things you can do with your life beyond be a pirate/merc. Don't listen to that voice, stealing ships via boarding parties is the only way of acquiring money relatively quickly beyond the rare, bounty list job.  Which brings up space combat! This is both so much fun, and so much rage. Fun part! Depending on your choice of weapons, you are able to join random battles in space with next to no reprecursions as the two parties fight for life and you zap your enemy (see red guy), due to some laughably long range and guess shooting. Or you are able to watch in horror as you enter an area of space where everyone has some horrifyingly powerful guns that destroy your shields, hull, and happiness before you can make a pass at escape. Major issue is that you don't know what they are packing in weapons, you can't tell untill they open up on you, and the little info blerp provided is vague, very much so. The description varies from "trivial" to "Impossible", but you are not informed how they are rated to determine threat level to you. I seem to think it is an unspoken amalgamation of your ships type, and load out mixed with your level. But!  Trivial enemies in twos can wreck your life for reasons you are unsure of (maybe they are small glass cannons that are only GUN). Deadly enemies can just float around you in vain trying to bring their weapons to bare before dying to the explosion of their metal death trap.  Also, each ship has a load out of weapons, that are placed on four compass based directions on your ship, and each has a firing arc that is not discussed much, and even some of the fully decked vessels will always have blind spots in their firing patern.  So you are shooting, zapping, and hitting with all due fun then slightly tilt your ship to the left and stop. The weapons also have a range... which is an ignorable text box since it only matters in "Fire at Will" mode, unless you are being shot at then your AI ignore it just like you do and open up shooting everything like a Ork Freeboota.Exploration is fun, though potentially deadly since the whole area is teeming with bandits looking for the sweet rolls in your ships captain's quarters. There are about four mains ways of travel. Cruising, which is deadly and fun since for no reason at you can be cruising at a great speed (you think) then are knocked out of your cruise mode by pirates wanting you dead even if they are in no way a threat.  Or there are T-gates! Think stargate and that is exactly it, you anchor at the place and for a modest fee, travel in safety from one end of space to another point in space! T-gates are almost always at a space station/planet you can dock at (if your faction rep says so) and are the safest (relatively) way to go long distances.  Then there are wormholes..... wormholes are kinda like t-gates, if t-gates were a game you pay for up front, wormholes are the f2p that suck you in and slowly rob you with you having no knowledge where you are going. They are free to use, but they will kill your troopers (dudes you have on board to steal ships or keep yours from being stolen) each time and break your ship a little. And when I said sucked in I mean they have a gravity well that pull you into it and spits you out of another one, which is great but that other one has a gravity well too that pulls you into it. If not careful and if there are different pairs of wormholes nearby you can end up alone on your now burning ship on the other side of the map not really wanting to try to return.   Lastly there is an item that lets your teleport your ship in a circular radius of map hexes based on how many you want to use at time. Only to hexes you have already been to, semi safe since you have no clue what is waiting for you, can get expensive (you need a massive amount of the already costly items to even trying moving halfway cross map) but you wont get jumped on route like in cruising so, win?Lastly for now is the level up process... You can get experience from quests (variable from oh, nice to meh), and pirati- I mean defending your local area from them pirates and invaders. What does it do? lets you level certain skills you have chosen based on a life style of play I do not think impacts game too greatly. Really for most of the area I forget to use the things until I am nearly dying and go Save Me Buttons!  And Perks, perks are like skills but they are not tied to the action skills, they are always active.   Skills and Perks I think would be more impacting if they were not so dang situational, the buttons are very much a maybe use. Perks are very tied to certain aspects of the game, but are not acquired quickly enough to even remember to check for them. Or feel like they even do much when used.  It is a nice, balanced feature, but when you are able to reset your skills and perks the choices are less impacting on your decision time. I still am very happy I spent the cash on it, and if you like SPESS PIRATEZ, then you can be one in this one.  I do hope they keep this mode active if they come out with a story mode too.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Really impressed! It plays like a mix of Freelancer, X3 and Eve. It's super intuitive to pick up and play and the menus are all neatly laid out and self explanatory without sacrificing your ability to do what you need to do. Combat varies depending on the ship but for the most part it's slower than the frantic arcade dogfights seen in Chris Roberts games; with more emphasis on positioning and presenting sides of your ship to enemy.Trading and economy functions as you'd expect, with goods costing more or less dependant on their origins and the political affiliations. There's a fair amount of contraband so it's best not to use the "Loot All" button if you're trying to live a virtuous life.In terms of Early Access content; the game feels very polished already with much of the world content seemingly in place and all game systems working as you'd expect. The current starting scenario is possibly a little bit easy, starting you off as it does with a mid level ship and plenty of tools already at your disposal. The missions are all randomly generatied (apparently depending on your actions, though I've yet to make a big enough impact on my galaxy to see this) and most of them follow a fairly standard template. It'd be nice for some more intensive missions with multiple stages but the ones that are there give you enough to do, and when they involve going through hostile areas they can become quite harrowing. The full game will have a story mode, which isn't present in this E.A release, so who knows what that will entail.

content:
29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Wow, suprised! This game was actually dang good! The reviews werent wrong at all. Its very similar to the X3 / X series of games except without the headaches, no laggy menus, no shoddy UI/maps, basically its everything that you wanted X:rebirth to be.. almostIts not the best game in the world, however the developers are hard at work polishing this title into a true gem. Its esentially flying around in space doing rpg-like stuff and creating your own armada/fleet and waging war.  Theres a few small issues and bugs left to be fixed and some features that will be implemented in the future, so this title has a bright future ahead of it, even though its worth buying As-is.  Theres moddability in the game itself so im sure the modding community will be able to fix/implement what the devs do not. The devs are actually active on the forums and not just to censor creativity and announce p2w and microtransaction garbage. If you like RPGs, buy it, support it, who knows? This platform/title could have a VERY bright future ahead of it.  This is probably the only Early Access title that isnt a rip off out of the lot.... And that's coming from one of the most virilent critics of the early-access system, so you know its for real.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
25, 2014
Early Access Review
								This games has tons of potential. It has decent graphics, good game controls, easy to learn and best of all, it's pretty addicting. There are three character classes, different type of ship classes, different kinds of ships within the classes, four different weapon types and tons of missions to do in sandbox mode.  I've been playing as the gunner,  especializing on weapons systems,with the ability to adds different bonuses to the weapon system of choice. My weapon of choice being rail-guns.  It's up to you how you want to play. You have the option of playing as a pirate, enforcer, bounty hunter, miner, trader or a freelancer (combination of all). How effective you are doing each type of job depends on the ship, the combination of skills you select as you increase in experience and buying a license. License determine how much money you will receive depending on what the license is for. For example, a mining license will get you more money when selling ore, a police license will reward you with moneyfor everykill, and so on so forth. The point of it all is to make money, so you can get better ships and better gear, you know, the same old formula that keeps us coming back for more.  Overall I really like this game and if you are a fan of freelancer and games likes these I dont think you will be disappointed. The best part? It's only  going to get better.

29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Wow, suprised! This game was actually dang good! The reviews werent wrong at all. Its very similar to the X3 / X series of games except without the headaches, no laggy menus, no shoddy UI/maps, basically its everything that you wanted X:rebirth to be.. almostIts not the best game in the world, however the developers are hard at work polishing this title into a true gem. Its esentially flying around in space doing rpg-like stuff and creating your own armada/fleet and waging war.  Theres a few small issues and bugs left to be fixed and some features that will be implemented in the future, so this title has a bright future ahead of it, even though its worth buying As-is.  Theres moddability in the game itself so im sure the modding community will be able to fix/implement what the devs do not. The devs are actually active on the forums and not just to censor creativity and announce p2w and microtransaction garbage. If you like RPGs, buy it, support it, who knows? This platform/title could have a VERY bright future ahead of it.  This is probably the only Early Access title that isnt a rip off out of the lot.... And that's coming from one of the most virilent critics of the early-access system, so you know its for real.

content:
25, 2014
Early Access Review
								This games has tons of potential. It has decent graphics, good game controls, easy to learn and best of all, it's pretty addicting. There are three character classes, different type of ship classes, different kinds of ships within the classes, four different weapon types and tons of missions to do in sandbox mode.  I've been playing as the gunner,  especializing on weapons systems,with the ability to adds different bonuses to the weapon system of choice. My weapon of choice being rail-guns.  It's up to you how you want to play. You have the option of playing as a pirate, enforcer, bounty hunter, miner, trader or a freelancer (combination of all). How effective you are doing each type of job depends on the ship, the combination of skills you select as you increase in experience and buying a license. License determine how much money you will receive depending on what the license is for. For example, a mining license will get you more money when selling ore, a police license will reward you with moneyfor everykill, and so on so forth. The point of it all is to make money, so you can get better ships and better gear, you know, the same old formula that keeps us coming back for more.  Overall I really like this game and if you are a fan of freelancer and games likes these I dont think you will be disappointed. The best part? It's only  going to get better.

content:
9, 2014
Early Access Review
								I want to enjoy this game.  I can honestly see all the potential it has.  But I I have to hesitate in giving it a full thumbs up, but it's also not a full thumbs down.  As this is being written during Early Access, I can forgive any shortcomings.  Like I said, I can see the potential.  But try as I might, I'm just not feeling it.To start, I've always loved these types of games and felt they never made enough.  A space sim seems to have unlimited potential, but I prefer to avoid things that require subscriptions and groups like MMOs.  Conversely, I recall fond memories of doing just that in Earth and Beyond, lo so many years ago.  But what I loved most about Earth and Beyond is I recall enjoying crafting my ship and making it mine.  I'd say the same for the Lightspeed add-on to Star Wars Galaxies.  Clunky though it was, I thoroughly enjoyed taking those ship parts I blasted out of enemy ships and hoarding them, finally upgrading when I would get the time and adding it to my ship.  I felt like I owned that more.  Though you can certainly buy different ship parts here, there aren't that many right now, and some of the differences aren't readily apparent.  I can't even easily compare the old with the new.Funny enough, I started drawing comparisons to, of all things, the game FTL.  Though you don't actively fly a single thing, and the game basically consists of just a handful of screens, it does give you the ability to upgrade your ship in a way that makes you feel like you're in control of it.  And while even the upgrades themselves are a simple thing, I never really find myself using the same configuration over and over again because I find random things and random times.  Here, I feel less like I'm thinking on my feet and thinking more about where I'm flying next (fun, yes, but limited).Similarly, again, Early Access-itis: you get plopped into the game and are told nothing.  Zippo.  Sure, the tutorial is there, but it's not interactive.  It tells you what to do on one screen, then you need to close it out to try it, and  then reactivate the tutorial screen to move on.  Very clunky.  On the plus side, the controls feel pretty good and are easily customized, and yet, for it being space, it feels rather tight.  Granted, it's a game, so not everyone wants to sit there and patiently watch the seconds tick away, but it almost feels too quick.  It is space, after all.  If only to hammer the point home, once I figured out how to get where I was going, it didn't seem like I had to do much once I got there.  I also wonder about the items you get.  They don't seem to have much more purpose than to provide you with money.  And while that's all good, it also seems very limited.  Okay, I've got a cargo hold full of all these different things...that don't have anything special about them other than how much money they fetch you.  Then what?  Wash, rinse, repeat?  I could see where  the full game, story and all, would provide more substance, but I would hope it's substantial, because right now, like I said, I don't feel "at home" in this game.  I don't feel like I have a reason to be out flying, that my ship is no different than any other NPC ship flying around, randomly doing things "just because."So, like I said to start, I can see the potential: it looks amazing, the controls are customizable and feel natural, and there appears to be a real desire to embrace the mysteries of space.  Unfortunately, things feel like they move real fast, that customization needs to be greatly expanded to get some real tinkering done on ship, and that I'm not just moving from A to B to A again.That said, I eagerly await more content and gladly support the game.

content:
r 12, 2014
												Star Point Gemin 2 is a fantasic starship space genre game that will have you playing for hours on end. I’ve spent more than 60 hours with the game at this point and I’ve only just scratched the surface. I’ve primarily been playing in the games “free roam” mode as that was the real draw of the game for me. I knew from the outset that I wanted a game that gave me the ability to explore, fight, mine and trade at my own leisure and do so in my own ship like a “real” space captain. After researching SP♥♥♥♥ bit I realized that this would be the game that would allow me to do all of that.I’m not a diehard space sim player so games like EVE Online and Star Trek Online have always kind of intimidated me. I’ve never really had an interest in the X3 series (my loss probably) but I have played Sins of a Solar Empire and the Homeworld series. It's been a while since I've played anything space related but lately I’ve become re-interested in the genre with games like Star Citizen and Elite: Dangerous on the horizon. I knew I wanted to play a game that felt huge and expansive but I didn’t want to play a game that made me feel like a small fish in a huge pond. I’m a casual player so the size and scope of this game feels just right to me. The game's setting is huge and there is a lot to do in it. Also, it seems like the devs are really committed to making the game better all the time which made the choice to buy it all the more easy to make. The fact that I’ve continued to play it so much is a testament to how good it actually is.SPG2 reminds me specifically of two games I’ve played before, Nexus: The Jupiter Incident and Star Trek: Starfleet Command. Although I’ve played many other space genre games since, I really wanted to play something that felt similar to those two games. SPG2 has a surprising amount in common with Starfleet Command which also allowed you to “tractor beam” aka grapple ships, scan anomalies and commandeer other spacecraft with “marines” aka troopers. I haven’t played that game in over 15 years but I remember how much fun it was to do those things in the game.These are some of the things I like about SPG2:-	the music is great especially the main theme-	the ship designs are cool and I know there are still tons more to discover-	the space station designs are great and varied which is a plus-	the variety of weapons and their FX in game look great-       the descriptions for items and npcs in the game are numerous and often amusing-       there are many mods availiable which help to enhance gamplayThe randomness of missions and enemies is great but whether or not you like this aspect of the game will depend on how much you like doing things in this universe. After awhile the missions can seem repetitive but luckily the fact that the level required to do each mission changes all the time, forces you to decide which missions to do or not to do. This in turn helps mix things up a bit and keep things interesting.The only issues I have with the game so far are the way the menus in stations and on planets were a bit confusing at first and still seem a bit cumbersome to navigate. Also I wish there was a bit more 'humanity' in the game. By that I just mean it would be cool if officers had portraits in addition to their names and when ships attacked you they too had portraits instead of just insignias. I know that's a huge 'ask' as there are already a huge amount of randomized officer names in the game. Perhaps a feature that allowed you upload your own portraits to the game (specifically for officers) could be cool. Also, I’m not entirely sure, but I think officers gain experience the longer they are on your ship. I hope so but it would also be cool if they could steadily gain loyalty for additional bonuses.Other than that I’ve really enjoyed this game and am glad I bought it.

content:
r 12, 2014
												I'm going to give this a 5/10 at the moment.  The content that is present is well done and relatively stable/bug free.  Ship combat is fun for a while, and space is visually interesting with a few suprises.  But get a few hours in and the game starts to feel kind of pointless.  There is a faction system, but it doesn't do much of anything.  There is trading and mining, but neither give money at anywhere near the rate fighting does.  There are generated "missions", but they are extremely easy and give very little in the way of rewards (you'll probably do them just to have something to do).  There are enemy bases and structures, but you can't destroy them (you can get them to one health and they just hang there, and frankly it isn't hard at all to do that).  You end up collecting money to buy a bigger ship to collect more money to buy an even bigger ship (which isn't very rewarding, as the ship models are so small in relation to one another you dont get the sense that you have a bigger ship)...The game isn't garbage, and the devs are very nice and responsive.  At $5-$10 give it a shot, but not at $40.  The caveat here is there is a very soid framework to make a much better game (really this game is in the bin with so many others that are really in early-mid beta, but release early to make money).  If there is a content update that adds player bases and the ability to capture territory, balances out mining and trading, and puts in other end-game content and empire building mechanics, this game will be a 9/10 easy.  It feels like these things were intended, but just haven't made it in.  So, if you see a big update after this review, maybe give it a try.  Otherwise, skip it until there is a big steam sale (or skip entirely, if a space grind isn't your thing).

content:
ber 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Beta Review.First off, this is NOT my genre! I'm mainly fantasy (i.e. Wizardry, WarCraft, etc...) I'm much more turn based (i.e. Master of Orion, Galactic Civilizations, etc...) And I normally wouldn't even look twice at a flight sim game. But this game is fun!The game loads unexpectedly fast for being so vast and beautiful. The controls are very smooth (maybe even a bit unrealisticly so) and the hubs feel well thought out. For being a newly released into Beta game, it is very well polished (so far.)As of right now there seems to only be one mostly free-roaming map with little actual story or adventure to it, but even still I'm having a blast just discovering all there is to discover. I feel even with this one map there's still so many more hours (days even?) of fresh gameplay.If the Beta release is any indication of what the end product is going to be, it's going to be one great space game! And if someone releases a Firefly/Serenity Mod for Starpoint Gemini 2, I aim to misbehave.

content:
ber 27, 2014
												So far really enjoying this game. I am a huge fan of open-universe space games with ship and fleet customisations, but I do not like MMO-games (so unfortunately EVE is out of the picture for me). This game, to me, fills an X shaped void. It really offers a lot of what X3 had, and with some new and fresh ideas because it isn't X! And where the original Starpoint Gemini I couldn't get into because it simply wasn't as good as X, SG2 genuinly is. It is also particularly well timed, I loved all of the previous X games, until they released X reunion, which is probably the most sad, dissapointing and pathetic game ever made and totally missed the point of X and why it was good. I am glad to see that the developers of Starpoint Gemini have worked on, enhanced and listened to what space-gamers really want, and developed something that really fits. I am excitedly looking forward to where they take SG games in the future. I know I am basically saying "it is the new X", believe me when I say that coming from me, that is huge praise. If I were to nit pick, I would say that SG2s UI could use a little tweaking, the ability to zoom out on the map and a tool for selecting your own ships on the map and I'd like to see some of the fleet controls from X3 (for example telling a ships computer to go somewhere, protect something or trade something). I would also like to see space station ownership, and more skills and mods aimed at ship capture. But these are not huge criticisms, just where I think SG could be improved.

content:

Early Access Review
								GREAT GAME!  This blows other open-"world" space games (Evochron Merc, X: Rebirth, etc.) out of the water as far as fun and dynamics go.  You don't have to grind too much to make geat profits.  Want a new ship?  Find one you can beat, board it, capture it, captain it, then work your way up the food chain.  Environments beautifully done, as well as artwork on the ships and weapons effects.  Combat is very tactical and lgical, taking into account where your weapons are placed and requiring you be at a certain azimuth to fire from them (left side, right side, front, back), so it takes some thought and power management during battles, especially when against tough ships.  I definitely recommend!

content:
12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Bar none Starpoint Gemini 2 has been the greatest space trading and combat sim experience I've had since I played EV Nova in elementary school, but I can tell it's going to be so much more than that (blasphemy I know). The developers are clearly involved with the community and dedicated to seeing this lore rich galaxy through to the launch without cutting any corners. As is, I already feel as though I've reaped far more than the value of my initial buy into the alpha and though I know there's far more in store I cannot wait to see what they come up with for story/main missions. Showing my bias again here: I hope they stick with the open universe route they've already got going a la EV Nova with various plotlines to follow for near endless replayability. I would also like to see the captains name and profile photo become customizable, but honestly that's the only 'nit' I have to pick. As I've touched on previously there are a few kinks which one would expect of any game in its beta phase that are being tirelessly identified and smoothed out, so don't make the purchase just yet if you'd rather wait for a finished product. However I can't stress enough how cool it's been to be even a small part of an emerging work of art like this. Seriously, these people deserve buckets of money and validation.

content:
9, 2014
Early Access Review
								I want to enjoy this game.  I can honestly see all the potential it has.  But I I have to hesitate in giving it a full thumbs up, but it's also not a full thumbs down.  As this is being written during Early Access, I can forgive any shortcomings.  Like I said, I can see the potential.  But try as I might, I'm just not feeling it.To start, I've always loved these types of games and felt they never made enough.  A space sim seems to have unlimited potential, but I prefer to avoid things that require subscriptions and groups like MMOs.  Conversely, I recall fond memories of doing just that in Earth and Beyond, lo so many years ago.  But what I loved most about Earth and Beyond is I recall enjoying crafting my ship and making it mine.  I'd say the same for the Lightspeed add-on to Star Wars Galaxies.  Clunky though it was, I thoroughly enjoyed taking those ship parts I blasted out of enemy ships and hoarding them, finally upgrading when I would get the time and adding it to my ship.  I felt like I owned that more.  Though you can certainly buy different ship parts here, there aren't that many right now, and some of the differences aren't readily apparent.  I can't even easily compare the old with the new.Funny enough, I started drawing comparisons to, of all things, the game FTL.  Though you don't actively fly a single thing, and the game basically consists of just a handful of screens, it does give you the ability to upgrade your ship in a way that makes you feel like you're in control of it.  And while even the upgrades themselves are a simple thing, I never really find myself using the same configuration over and over again because I find random things and random times.  Here, I feel less like I'm thinking on my feet and thinking more about where I'm flying next (fun, yes, but limited).Similarly, again, Early Access-itis: you get plopped into the game and are told nothing.  Zippo.  Sure, the tutorial is there, but it's not interactive.  It tells you what to do on one screen, then you need to close it out to try it, and  then reactivate the tutorial screen to move on.  Very clunky.  On the plus side, the controls feel pretty good and are easily customized, and yet, for it being space, it feels rather tight.  Granted, it's a game, so not everyone wants to sit there and patiently watch the seconds tick away, but it almost feels too quick.  It is space, after all.  If only to hammer the point home, once I figured out how to get where I was going, it didn't seem like I had to do much once I got there.  I also wonder about the items you get.  They don't seem to have much more purpose than to provide you with money.  And while that's all good, it also seems very limited.  Okay, I've got a cargo hold full of all these different things...that don't have anything special about them other than how much money they fetch you.  Then what?  Wash, rinse, repeat?  I could see where  the full game, story and all, would provide more substance, but I would hope it's substantial, because right now, like I said, I don't feel "at home" in this game.  I don't feel like I have a reason to be out flying, that my ship is no different than any other NPC ship flying around, randomly doing things "just because."So, like I said to start, I can see the potential: it looks amazing, the controls are customizable and feel natural, and there appears to be a real desire to embrace the mysteries of space.  Unfortunately, things feel like they move real fast, that customization needs to be greatly expanded to get some real tinkering done on ship, and that I'm not just moving from A to B to A again.That said, I eagerly await more content and gladly support the game.
