content:
r 12, 2014
												Star Point Gemin 2 is a fantasic starship space genre game that will have you playing for hours on end. I’ve spent more than 60 hours with the game at this point and I’ve only just scratched the surface. I’ve primarily been playing in the games “free roam” mode as that was the real draw of the game for me. I knew from the outset that I wanted a game that gave me the ability to explore, fight, mine and trade at my own leisure and do so in my own ship like a “real” space captain. After researching SP♥♥♥♥ bit I realized that this would be the game that would allow me to do all of that.I’m not a diehard space sim player so games like EVE Online and Star Trek Online have always kind of intimidated me. I’ve never really had an interest in the X3 series (my loss probably) but I have played Sins of a Solar Empire and the Homeworld series. It's been a while since I've played anything space related but lately I’ve become re-interested in the genre with games like Star Citizen and Elite: Dangerous on the horizon. I knew I wanted to play a game that felt huge and expansive but I didn’t want to play a game that made me feel like a small fish in a huge pond. I’m a casual player so the size and scope of this game feels just right to me. The game's setting is huge and there is a lot to do in it. Also, it seems like the devs are really committed to making the game better all the time which made the choice to buy it all the more easy to make. The fact that I’ve continued to play it so much is a testament to how good it actually is.SPG2 reminds me specifically of two games I’ve played before, Nexus: The Jupiter Incident and Star Trek: Starfleet Command. Although I’ve played many other space genre games since, I really wanted to play something that felt similar to those two games. SPG2 has a surprising amount in common with Starfleet Command which also allowed you to “tractor beam” aka grapple ships, scan anomalies and commandeer other spacecraft with “marines” aka troopers. I haven’t played that game in over 15 years but I remember how much fun it was to do those things in the game.These are some of the things I like about SPG2:-	the music is great especially the main theme-	the ship designs are cool and I know there are still tons more to discover-	the space station designs are great and varied which is a plus-	the variety of weapons and their FX in game look great-       the descriptions for items and npcs in the game are numerous and often amusing-       there are many mods availiable which help to enhance gamplayThe randomness of missions and enemies is great but whether or not you like this aspect of the game will depend on how much you like doing things in this universe. After awhile the missions can seem repetitive but luckily the fact that the level required to do each mission changes all the time, forces you to decide which missions to do or not to do. This in turn helps mix things up a bit and keep things interesting.The only issues I have with the game so far are the way the menus in stations and on planets were a bit confusing at first and still seem a bit cumbersome to navigate. Also I wish there was a bit more 'humanity' in the game. By that I just mean it would be cool if officers had portraits in addition to their names and when ships attacked you they too had portraits instead of just insignias. I know that's a huge 'ask' as there are already a huge amount of randomized officer names in the game. Perhaps a feature that allowed you upload your own portraits to the game (specifically for officers) could be cool. Also, I’m not entirely sure, but I think officers gain experience the longer they are on your ship. I hope so but it would also be cool if they could steadily gain loyalty for additional bonuses.Other than that I’ve really enjoyed this game and am glad I bought it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
r 12, 2014
												I'm going to give this a 5/10 at the moment.  The content that is present is well done and relatively stable/bug free.  Ship combat is fun for a while, and space is visually interesting with a few suprises.  But get a few hours in and the game starts to feel kind of pointless.  There is a faction system, but it doesn't do much of anything.  There is trading and mining, but neither give money at anywhere near the rate fighting does.  There are generated "missions", but they are extremely easy and give very little in the way of rewards (you'll probably do them just to have something to do).  There are enemy bases and structures, but you can't destroy them (you can get them to one health and they just hang there, and frankly it isn't hard at all to do that).  You end up collecting money to buy a bigger ship to collect more money to buy an even bigger ship (which isn't very rewarding, as the ship models are so small in relation to one another you dont get the sense that you have a bigger ship)...The game isn't garbage, and the devs are very nice and responsive.  At $5-$10 give it a shot, but not at $40.  The caveat here is there is a very soid framework to make a much better game (really this game is in the bin with so many others that are really in early-mid beta, but release early to make money).  If there is a content update that adds player bases and the ability to capture territory, balances out mining and trading, and puts in other end-game content and empire building mechanics, this game will be a 9/10 easy.  It feels like these things were intended, but just haven't made it in.  So, if you see a big update after this review, maybe give it a try.  Otherwise, skip it until there is a big steam sale (or skip entirely, if a space grind isn't your thing).

The writing is cheesy, the voice acting cringe-worthy. If you want a single player game that stands toe to toe with Freelancer, you won't find it here.Get this game for the sandbox mode that is freeroam and go explore the Gemini star system!

content:
r 2, 2014
												7/10I really enjoy open ended space sim games. This one is a very happy medium between easy to learn and fun to play.It does not have the vast options and customization as games like EVE or X, but I would trade that for a more fun and easy to play game.Like:-Open world with a variety of play styles.-Good selection of ships and equipment loadouts.-Looks great, cool ship and station designs. fairly immersive-Easy to learn controls and interfaces, even decent camera control.-Combat is fun and sometimes intense.Really enjoyed:-Capturing ships.-Trading (Easy to use "best buy/sell" interface!)-Exploring, pirate hunting-Completing full loadouts on a ship feels very accomplishing.Dislike:-Map feels small and underwhelming.-Copy pasted missions (gets old in any game though.)-Story started out pretty lame (avenge my father! collect stuf!) but i didnt get far into it. voice acting was passable..-Random impossible difficulty battleships showing up out of nowhere, or even in a mission.-I feel like some stats are missing, or hard to manage when making a loadout. Such as:Weapon energy consumption vs regen. And how to buff regen / lower consumption?Turret arc max angles. Fix: List this on ship stats, or a visual on the loadout page would be awesome.A better display of your ships stats (the circular display looks very awesome, but is not practical when zoomed out.)Is there a display for your own crew size? I may have missed it, from my reason above.Recommended for any type of space sim fan, but definitely leaning towards casual.

content:
ber 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								There's a lot to like about this game, equally it still has room for improvement, but overall I'd recommend it in its current state for the price. If you've ever played EVE, you will immediately see the attraction of an "offline mode" style game, that you can pause when the pizza guy comes or save before doing something stupid.Things I really like.* The universe is already pretty big, lots of places to explore but the game has features like wormholes, JumpGate networks and TeleportDrives to get you around faster than full speed ahead into one direction.* Ships look cool, there is a good variety of designs and varied configurations already, Its obvious there will be more to come.* Great maneuverability of the ship, it's the type of piloting I really wished EVE had, you can really out maneuver a lot damage if you get good at it allowing you to take out larger ships that claim to be "impossible".* Shielded sides, you don't fly around in a "bubble" shield like most games, each side of your ship has emitters and if one side is busted you're taking hull damage! That really fits my play style of focused attack. I hope that later one you can divert power to bolster one side or the other depending on where you are taking the most damage.* You can board other ships with what amounts to raiding parties and fight their crew, if you manage to take them down, you can grapple their ship and tow it (painfully slowly) back to a station and sell it or use it as your own. This will be a good source of income if it didn't take ages to get a ship back to station. I'd suggest adding a towtruck style ship that we can come back with or something and get it there much faster, just let us bookmark the spot and return would be fine.Areas in need of improvement* I guess its the pilot's radar, but its way too small to be useful and you can't zoom-in, you can tell if there are enemies in the area the same as if there are friendlies, but it's hard to gauge you're position or distance from them without "looking out your window" by turning your ship or the camera. I'd prefer more thought into that, it needs to be bigger and zoom able and a lot more detailed about what each tiny blimp is. For example, you can drop a ZETH which is basicly an automated sentry fixed in space, but if you fly too far from it you may never find it again and its not cheap. I frequently lose mine if there are NPC friendlys around because it's impossible to tell what anything is.* Stations need to be able to attack, I love the warnings that tell me any enemy station is nearby, so the first time I heard that I saved the game and flew right at one, but nothing happened, I think they should start firing some lasers if enemy craft turn up.*Needs more ship system customization and I think this is already on the way based on some of the anomaly scans I've done, cause you need jamming, ECM, shield boosters, etc. The ability to vary your ship should be based on more than just what skills you're pilot has, not to keep bringing up EVE but there's a lot to take for example there.

content:
r 6, 2014
												This gem is somewhere between the X series (vertical learning curve) and Galaxy on Fire 2 (my dog plays this game) in terms of difficulty with some of the best combat in any space game I've ever played.  SPG2 may not have any entirely new concepts or features but it has taken a lot from past games and the end product does all the little things right.  Ultimately this game meets the same fate as Skyrim, a giant world that is unfortunately only about 5 feet deep.  While I have absolutely no regrets throwing out $28 for it, I can't help but feel this game will be so much better in a year thanks to workshop support and a dev team that truly cares about their B - level game.  While the voice acting is pretty bad, It isn't House of the Dead 2 bad so it's playable, other than the voices the sound is pretty good, I could wish for a few more effects and songs but that's just nitpicking.  The one thing I truly don't like about this game is the faction system, if you do assignments in the Trinity sector your reputation goes towards lawful...Which means all lawful factions like you more, the unlwaful (pirates) well, they never liked you anyway.  If I do things in the Trinity sectors I want perks in the Trinity sectors, not halfway across the solar system.Unlike most titles I am actively looking forward to DLC for this game, which I'm hoping will greatly increase depth.-Throw in some: player built space stations, automating a freight company that I have built/stolen and funded, faction control, and territory conquering and this could truly be something special.8.5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
r 10, 2014
												Where to start... The game itself requires some minor polish, mainly in the balancing sector, but it's already at a very good/stable state otherwise. There are various tasks to do inside the game, such as exploration, boarding ships, mining, trading(These do still need balancing.) and ofcourse, the campaign mode and pewpew fighting. The game is fairly complex, once you start getting into it, learning to fly and maneuver different ship classes, the firing arcs of various ships, finding fighting tactics that work for you and your ship, the enhancement system... And for those who get bored quickly after having played through the storyline, which did happen to a lot of players in other games such as Freelancer, you do have a nice amount of achievements to hunt, some of which aren't exactly easy to accomplish. Nothing is stopping you from hunting down the "Heros" either. ;)The community and the devs are active and communicating a lot, which reflects into the product and the pace patches, fixes and balancing attempts are coming through. There are plans for an expansion and DLC, which will further add to the amount of content in the game and ofcourse, the community made mods, which will be the crowning jewel of this game. The tools might not be fully functional yet, but as soon as the game itself is at a state where the devs and community are happy, the tools will be recieving some much needed love.A lot has been said about the game in many of the reviews, but here's another list of just some of the features already in the game and some which are being worked on:Already in:-Boarding Ships.-Working Campaign.-Lots and lots of ships.-Weapon/ship system enhancement.-Trading.-Dynamic events which effect item prices.-A large amount of space to explore, which can also be further expanded.-Lots of different factions.(Which will also get some more love in the future.)-Freeroam mode for those who don't wish to play the campaign.-Mercenaries to act as your backup.-Blueprints.-Working collision system.-Cloaking!-Heroes to hunt,-Mods.Planned/in the works:-Player owned faction and base(s).-Dynamic struggles for power/regional control between factions. Once this is implemented, every single playthrough will be and feel different!-Expansion/DLC.-Modding Tools.(Currently some work, some don't. Somewhat prone to crashes.)-Improvements to the HUD and other elements of the UI.-An entirely new ship class.(Larger, naturally. Bigger is always better!)... and the list goes on.If you aren't a fan of space sims or dislike games with emphasis on exploration, this might not be for you, as there is no MP in the game to increase its lifespan. However, if you do like what you've seen/read and can get past the fact that there is no MP and that the game relies entirely on mods/expansions/DLC to keep breathing fresh life into it, then this game just might be a perfect fit for you. Atleast I've completely fallen in love with the game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
y 2, 2015
												I love this game!! Though it should come with a warning: "Warning, this game will make you lose sleep!" heh. I've played quite a few space games throughout the years, X3 series, Wing Commander, Freespace 2, Starlancer, EVE, Star Wars X-Wing and more and this one ranks right up there imo. If you're into these types of games I highly recommend checking this one out! Pros:-Great graphics-Epic music-Fun sandboxy type of do whatever you want freedom-Devs are very active and responsive (big seller for me)-Ease of modding (probably my favorite aspect of this game)Cons:-Requires a bit of tweaking to optimize and run smoothly on lower end systems. (Though there are mods that help, and the community is always willing to help with this)-No Multiplayer (but this isn't a factor for me, in fact, it's one of the reasons I bought this game...no griefers, no obsessively overpowerful others pwning you within the first ten seconds of you logging in. And it doesn't take 8 months to be able to fly a battleship! :) )I can't think of too many cons because the devs are always working on improving things, and fixing the few bugs that have surfaced here and there. Every time I think of a con, I find out they've already fixed it!Also, I have never actually published a mod before this game. It is insanely easy to mod...you want to change your loading screen? Easy. Want to change the music? Sure, you don't have to go through some maddening process of decrypting game files just to get to them, and then re-encrypt them using 20 different programs just to do that. Want to fly a ship that looks like a banana? Yep. And you don't have to learn eleventy different programming languages to do that. There are fantastic guides that help as well. And the devs are always around somewhere willing to help. Yea, big plus for me.The sandboxy aspect is a big plus too. Want to just roam around for a bit and blow stuff up? Sure. Want to just mine and get rich trading? Yep. Want to be a wanted criminal with a limited life expectancy? No worries.

												Highly recommend this for a good Space RPG. Seems to be running stable. It's got a tad bit of grind in good RPG fashion but still has that solid space sim feel to it. It seems emphasis is palced more on efficient captaining (This is the RPG aspect, with abilities and consumables) than direct combat skills although it does allow you to manually aim and focus fire. So far I really enjoy it. The story isn't as enthralling as a story driven RPG like the Witcher, but hey we're a mighty space captain who goes around blowing up everyone around us and stealing their loot so it doesn't matter much anyway. Did I just describe a space hack 'n slash, yes I think that's what I'd call this. The story gives you some primary goals to focus on while exploring the game and shooting up the place ;3

content:
ber 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								This looks like its going to be a great game...someday...which is the only reason I give it a thumbs up. I say 'someday' because I sat down and tried to play it today and after selecting gamepad with my xbox360 controller connected, I was forced to watch a series of tutorials that meant absolutely nothing to me because they were referencing joystick buttons rather than the familiar a,b,x,y,etc. They are also not interactive, which is great to help you learn the controllers. Simply saying that A = 'whatever' doesnt have nearly the same benefit as actually seeing what A does first hand. I searched online for an xbox 360 conroller map for this game and also came up empty. I kind of figured out the controller basics on my own. but I soon realized that the mouse has been completely disabled in the game, making impossible(?) to access certain hud elements.  ~scratches head~ Why would they disable the mouse??The other frustrating experience came right after the tutorials finished. I was left to play around on my own, but then I asked myself, now what? There was no nudge in any particular direction after the tutorial and even after landing on the planet (for a hefty fee) and a space station in orbit, I was still no closer to understanding how I should begin my journey. Between the lack of controller mapping info and the non-descipt beginning, I was left feeling somewhat abandoned.Now, I realize this is still in beta, so I think I will just shelve this game for now, until I can figure out how to play it properly. Hopefully with the help of a decent tutorial.

												many hrs in....8 out of 10 stars. :) - Huge sandbox universe to explore and interact within. :) - Beautiful graphics and framerates with settings maxed out :) - Many Corporations with their own ship visual styles:) - Solid game - not the typical steam crowd-funded title.:( - All ships are the same graphic scale, regardless of the class size you are playing.  So be prepared to be underwhelmed by the Corvette or Frigate upgrade visually, as well as tactically - especially given the amount of time saving up for them.  You gain only an extra weapons mounting point or two each upgrade.:( - Fleet Commander? No, not really. You to hire mercenaries (max 2) that follow you (bumping into each other) that you have no command or interaction over what so ever.  Most of the time they go off and get themselves destroyed or wirte you off as MIA when the green rifts take you for a ride.Restarted many times to try all the player skill sets, and starting ship types.  I will continue to play it for now as I anxiously await patches and expansions - or as usual, the steam community to mod out the oversights that the devs / testers missed (ship scale, enemy bases don't consider you a threat, complexity doesn't scale with firepower).Perfectly priced for what you get - especially if you catch a STEAM sale.

content:
r 3, 2015
												Starpoint Gemini 2 is surprisingly easy to handle quickly, it offers a variety of piloting styles through a few shortcuts (i.e. space bar, or v for turret mode). It is indeed a versatile game where you can choose from 3 classes which can evolve in a RPG-lite fashion. Each class has 4 base skills and in each 5 facets you can improve when you activate the former, and classes share perks which can enhance some facets of your character (i.e. you like boarding? enhance your troops efficiency, you like trading? enhance your mercantile skills, you like piloting destroyers? enhance your skill with that class of ships).Several RPG aspects are simplified yet overall the existence of each feature serve a justified purpose. Depending on your actions, you will gain positive or negative reputation which in turn will make you hostile or friendly towards this or that faction. Once you are friendly with a faction, you may be offered to buy some "licences" which may provide diverse advantages like extra coin for destroying some other factions' ships or get free repairs at friendly starbases.All-in all, the sandbox space opera SG2 is pretty vast both in terms of maps, weapon choices (while there are only 3 types of light weaponry: beam, guns and plasma and 3 types of heavy weaponry: torpedoes, missiles and shockwave, there is a vast arsenal to choose from in each types and categories) and ships. The latter comes into no less than 10 types, 8 of the standard military classes and 2 in the more civil transporters, and each major faction provides its own versions of each class (with different hardpoint layouts, cargo and trooper capacity, etc.) so at the end there are plenty of ships to choose from and you can perfectly go through the game flying a corvette (the starting class) if you like to and still be some kind of challenge for heavier classes. You can also deploy fighters and get mercenary ships (of any class) to escort you (one of the player character class, the commander, may enhance those drastically).The combination of RPG and sandbox space opera inevitably means you have to grind (twice here since you need both money and xp), you'll be given the opportunity to peacefully mine ore, ice and much more (various type of asteroid fields, with more stones than you can dream of), you can attack any ship you like or you can do some mission from a panel of several ones (repair stuff, scan stuff, kill stuff, protect stuff from being killed, transport stuff) and while there is some diversity there it is of course very likely you'll do the same missions several times. In addition to the storyline (which is secondary in this game - you are even offered to skip it at the very beginning) you will unlock also some side missions (while some are custom scripted versions of the normal freelance missions, some are totally unique as well). So there is plenty of things to do, and the difficulity of the missions also scales up depending from where you are in the galaxy and your level. As a sandbox (freeroam) game, it is also possible for you to go to hostile territory and try to shoot down and loot anything you can, although this may be pretty difficult to do and you're more likely to die if you are not prepared for a proper war. If you are reasonable at start, you will do missions in neutral/friendly territory, watch enemies get shot by friendlies and scavenge the spoils of war (good thing being you still get exp).Sadly, SG2 is not exempt of flaws and one of the major one I've noticed is the IA in the battles. Sometimes (emphasis on "sometimes") enemy ships stop there and don't do anything until you shoot them. While I am not sure what causes this, my guess would be that the IA is programmed to have the same behavior regardless of having guns on the side or back of the ship or not. While sometimes the IA manoeuvers around you, many times it also just stop there and shoots you at full stop. In fact and especially if you pilot even heavy ships like if it was a fighter, you will find yourself having to reduce speed drastically in order to catch anything (unless you have several manoeuvrability enhancement like officers and equipement). While this is something you can surely get along with, it is still one aspect of the game that can be considered a critical shortcoming as it does not give you a intuitive feeling of piloting and the latter does not have so much impact on the fight (beside getting your enemy in your firing arcs). So if you expect a simulation of space battle, you won't find it here yet there is still enough complexity and customisation options in SG2 to actually make up for that in some way.A few other things kind of annoyed me like few specific types of ship seemed to always disconnect from my grappler when I set engines on overdrive while towing them. It only happened with those specific ships so far for some reason, so at some point, if I was too far from a station I would be discouraged to attempt to capture them. Some part of the UI are a bit clunky, manageable but lacking ergonomy like the contextual menu which you typically use for repairing or scanning which obscure the view. As I said a bit of a detail and easy to work around but still its one amongst several design calls that leave this "meh" impression instead of a "wow" one. Fortunately, there are a lot of well thought features that actually balance such little things in my opinion.Also, be prepared to stare at your screen for sometime while your autopilot is active, there is no time-acceleration feature in SG2. You can of course set the "power to engine" which greatly accelerate travelling and you have several ways of enhancing your ship's speed even further. There are also space highways (wormholes, gates - this one being expensive to use) that you can use, but most of the time you will have to travel through the void (not so empty at all actually) just looking at the distance counter shrinking for a few seconds/minutes till you reach destination. Of course a lot can happen when you do so, an asteroid or structure can be in the way (autopilot may not always detect it), a cloaked raider may attack you from nowhere or good old pirates may invite themselves to your party. Also you may want to keep an eye on some space anomalies like those space streams that may actually send you to hostile territories without your consent. A big part of your gaming time will be just that, travelling and making sure you reach the intended destination (although I find it quite bearable myself, it may be a matter of personality/taste).Overall, SG2 offers a decent space sandbox experience, with enough content, RPG elements and customisation options (character development, variety of space ships and equipements, additional bonuses with officers).  With the 3 character classes, there is of course a bit of replayability along with the 2 aligements (positive or negative reputation) nevertheless you will have to go through the grinding again (with a bit of experience though, you'll know how to progress faster on subsequent playthroughs). Economy is pretty balanced and merchant, mining, pirate, bounty hunter, military, scavenger etc. are all viable options to progress at similar paces (some are just more appealing to some types of players. some are more efficient for credits or xp's) and it is easy to switch from one career to the other" just by changing ship (you can store several in a garage accessible from all stations) and playstyle (for a cost you can even reset your abilities and perks).If you like the genre (sandbox, not story driven) and do not mind the inherent features of it (grind) SG2 offers a fresh take on the open-world space opera. It is not as deep as the X series, yet it is much deeper in terms of game mechanics than many venerable predecessors like privateer or the earlier elite series to name but a few.

content:
4, 2016
												I obtained this game in early April 2016 during a great sale. The TL;DR is this: simple enough to pick up, complex enough not to put down. For me The game is marred only by its poor save mechanic and truly terrible voice acting. I was a bit surprised at how good this game was. Others have called it “Eve Light” and guess what? Its good enough comparison. Like other games such as “evochron Mercenary”, the Various “X” games like X3:Terren Conflict” , Freelancer etc, you fly around and do stuff for folks and get money from that. You can mine, salvage, build an economic power house, play taxi, attack the meannies, etc. What sets this game apart from the rest is a mix of easier to use controls, a good mix of things to do, good pace and an active community. If you think many space games are just too complicated without a joystick and throttle then you may like this game. Since I am not a pilot in real life, do not have a us$200 joystick, and have no desire to learn an intricate set of controls, I think this game is much easier to play and enjoy then many others of the same genre. Pros-	Controls are easy to learn but hard to master without needing an expensive joystick and throttle-	Enough choice to feel in control-	Good selection of mission types-	Fun achievements-	Good mix of things to do-	Fun exploration-	Developers are active in the community-	Enjoyable forum community-	Single player offline goodness. -	Survives repeated alt-tabbing out of the game.-	A slower pace then some space games -	Enough choices to feel in control without being so overwhelmed that you cant wrap your head around where to even begin-	Long tutorial campaign is kind of fun but not mandatory you can start it and pick the main campaign back up when you want to. Cons-	Really poor voice acting. Seriously BAD. Its cringe worthy how poor the voice acting is. -	Poor save game mechanic you can’t just save when you want to.  you’ll have to fly back to a station so its not the right choice for busy life if you can’t set aside a block of play time. This sis not a game that you can start to play if there is much chance of interruption since you may often find you cant save for another 5 or 10 minutes. -	Boring choice of ships in the start – just your own ship, nothing compares for some time into the game. There is nothing wrong with your starting ship but you can’t just swap it out for another other until much later in the game the other choices are simply too weak compared to what you start out using. -	Often inscrutable choices – you’ll need to use google allot to get a hang of what is going on. It’s a good thing that alt-tab does not break the game. It is a good thing the community is so active and there is plenty of information out there. -	Tutorial is bit thin you’ll need to google allot. it will help if you have played other space games like Eve Online, Freelancer, etc before this game.-	If you have played other space sims and want an immersive dog fighting, pirating power house this is not the right game for you.-	Single player may be a snooze fest if you are used to the pace of online games

content:
12, 2016
												I wrote this review in January of 2015 on Metacritic.  I thought I posted it to Steam, but did not.  This game deserves a review.  Here's a copy/paste of my former review.  The game has only gotten better through expansions.I am a Star Citizen backer. Want to know a dirty little secret? I love and crave 3rd person space games. En route to searching for something to fill this desire, I came across this game. "A Steam sale?" I asked. "Twenty-four bucks?" I blinked. "I spend that on 2-3 drinks at a restaurant with the wife..." So, I plucked this one out of the Steam shelf, downloaded and started playing. Eight hours later I looked up and saw it was 4am. "Woah..." The next (read: later that) day I dove into the Starpoint Gemini 2 Community and learned I was late to a really cool party. Did you love Freelancer? Are you craving a 3rd person Space game? What are you waiting for...? Pick this gem up ASAP. There are few games that are so worth your money that you'll want to encourage others to purchase, but this is certainly one for me. In a day when space sims are seeing a great resurgence, it's refreshing to see a game that's not afraid to be 3rd person and give the player a bit of a relaxed take on space. I feel like a Malcom Reynolds, flying around in my ship, always with my eye on a new shiny, but lovingly holding onto, in my case, "Big Red," until the time is truly right. There's dangers around every planet, but I've got a crew, a purpose, seemingly endless space to explore (certainly more than my limited time allows), and a ship. There's even a fun plot-line to follow along as you make your way in the galaxy--or don't; whatever--it's all up to you. I can assure you that if you want a rewarding, relaxing, and immersive (but not taking itself too seriously) space game, this is it. I give it a 9 (I'd have done 9.5 if it let me) because of the somewhat outdated UI, and the graphics are not the most polished. That said, the graphics do not detract from the game too much and again, it's sort of a breath of fresh air of late with the Elite: Dangerous's and Star Citizen's of the world. The development team has their ear to the forums and though I am new to the scene, they appear to be largely shaping the game around their community. It's mod friendly, and seemingly more so as time goes on, and there's already some great mods out there. It's much of anything you want in a fun game. Cheers.

content:
r 11, 2014
												gotta say this was exactly what i hoped it would be. an awesome galaxy surfing vehicle combat game with excellent mods and dev support. endless replay value and more ships to choose from than you will ever even see in one playthrough. seriously ive played about 100 hours so far and still half my map is unexplored. as all good games are you start out weak and end up becoming a juggernaut of near infinite power. and yet you can still get ganged up on to the point where your only choice is flee or die. tactical decisions go a long way and you definitely want to gather the best weapons, enhancments, officers and skills. but the best part is the freedom to choose what you do. do you mine asteroid and gas with a freightliner, or become wealthy thru the destruction of your enemies in a carrier, or do you become the master trader soaring around the galaxy at incredible speeds trading resources and transporting vip's in a cruiser. its totally up to you how you play this game. if i had complaints about this game it would be these. 1) more mods, 2) more weapon levels and choices, 3) more levels, and 4) better explained stats. so 3 out of 4 complaints are that i just want more. thats always a good thing. to play a game you can never get enough of. and if boredom ever does set in i can always start anew with a different approach, class or end goal. THIS IS A MUST HAVE!!!!!!

er 31, 2016
												great game with a lot of modding potentiala lot of content here, and with a lot of factions, freeroam, and campaign plus dlc, so really a lot of variationmods are nice, as are the dlc campaigns, and the mods can be dlc specific.you soon get used to zipping about, and you can play it so many wayspiratesmugglerfaction backerbounty hunterarea patrol/faction waryou can control upto 3 fighter wings and 2 escorts.titans are super warshipsRPG style tech and skill treesFull trade systemLoads of ships, equipment and weapons to pick fromFaction system.I play freeroam, headhunting and taking on entire fleets with a 16 turret dreadnought and 3 fighter wings plus 2 escorts can be a demanding and intense experience, some wont like the effort required to get to the large space battles, but its worth it for the eye candy of two fleets duking it out, also the locations and variety of ships will want to make you explore each sector, to uncover more of the game loadout and the massive rpg elements to this game, as for the campaigns and dlc, that adds hundreds of hours to the gameplay offered, so its worth investing and exploring, especially if the game is offered on discount.The mods do add another dimension to the game, especially the visual and hud improvements, extra missions, scenarios and campaigns are all available, as well as extra ships and other treats.

content:
r 2, 2014
												I'm only an hour or so in, but already I have that feeling as with many games I've loved over the years. Love the size of the system, love the campaign mode, love the visuals... combat is great fun and the addition of expendable modules is really clever. The Fleet isn't that well expanded on, I don't quite understand how best to use them or how to upgrade them.The way you access menus is fantastically intuitive, I didn't need a tutorial (which come thick and fast without any real sense of being anchored to what you're doing in-game) to reload weapons or move cargo, the buttons were just... where they should be.EDIT: Three hours in and still loving it. Worked out a few more of the game mechanics (loving the tactical overlay which you have to manually map, I have it on left-shift) and realised that I don't have a fleet yet! The RPG-lite elements are great, incremental improvements on all sorts of things means you have to really put some thought into what gameplay you want to get involved in. At this stage, unsure if it was wise to go with campaign mode, I think this could be even better in pure sandbox.

content:
r 2, 2014
												I'm only an hour or so in, but already I have that feeling as with many games I've loved over the years. Love the size of the system, love the campaign mode, love the visuals... combat is great fun and the addition of expendable modules is really clever. The Fleet isn't that well expanded on, I don't quite understand how best to use them or how to upgrade them.The way you access menus is fantastically intuitive, I didn't need a tutorial (which come thick and fast without any real sense of being anchored to what you're doing in-game) to reload weapons or move cargo, the buttons were just... where they should be.EDIT: Three hours in and still loving it. Worked out a few more of the game mechanics (loving the tactical overlay which you have to manually map, I have it on left-shift) and realised that I don't have a fleet yet! The RPG-lite elements are great, incremental improvements on all sorts of things means you have to really put some thought into what gameplay you want to get involved in. At this stage, unsure if it was wise to go with campaign mode, I think this could be even better in pure sandbox.

content:
r 17, 2014
												This is a fantastic game that truly expands on an experience given to us by games like Freelancer. If you've played Freelancer or any other game like it, then you should have a great idea of what to expect.That being said though, there are problems that should be mentioned. Right now, in it's current state, the economy is ridiculous, or at least feels that way. Everything is ridiculously expensive (and by everything, I mean everything, including fast travel). And the only way to deal with an economy like this and still be able to buy stuff every once in a while is to hijack ships.So yes, you are allowed the freedom to do whatever you want when you want to which is nice, but if you ever want to advance your ship, you're going to eventually have to hijack other ships to be able to earn enough money. Or be prepared for a really long drawn out game of mining, trading, or being a freelancer.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
r 14, 2014
												While I've played this a ton over past 2 weeks, was very tough call on whether to recommend this for others.Pros:- Generally entertaining, I love the premise of an open-world space sim in general- Good performance & interesting visuals (no sigificant lag or graphics issues on my rig with GTX770)- Enjoyed exploring and "freeroam" option to explore galaxy & amass wealth as I desired- Fair amount of flexibility to do different activities such as trading, mining, fighting pirates, capturing ships, smuggling & choose to side with "good" or "bad" factionsCons:- Capturing vastly overpowered for gathering wealth quickly, breaks scaling- Enemies scale ... inconsistantly ... with your level & ship power, if don't gather a lot of wealth early can be very rough- Lots of late game special add-ons not quite working right yet / buggy (blueprints) and take a ton of work to collect- You can't actually land or explore planets (just get same menu interface as at any shipyard by clicking on it)- Factions vastly simplified, no complex interactions (while having something like 20+ factions, they all break down into 3 options: the hate everyone factions, the good factions, and the evil factions)- Also, as a "space sim" I find it extremely jarring from immersion that it disregards most aspects of physics as they operate in our universe (severe viloations or completely ignoring gravity with all objects permanently hung in same spots in space & no orbital mechanics observed at all, relative sizes/scale of objects at distance are wildly inconsistant and in particular planets are massively distorted relative to distance and relative to stars, optics of light/dark side of planets not shown, vacuum transmits sound, no conservation of momentum, space completely littered with stationary debris everywhere)Basically if you love the idea of an open world single player space sim with some very light RPG elements in upgrades/statistics, you might find this entertaining for a while as I did.  If looking for a movie-like story, or any realism in economics, politics/diplomacy, or physics, or multi-player options, or longer term RPG depth, you won't find it here.

content:
ber 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you enjoyed Freelancer or the X series, you will probably like this game too.It took me about 30 minutes or so to figure out what the hell I was doing. The tutorial was decent, if intrusive (you can turn it off and access it later), and gives you a basic run down of how to control your ship, and some information on the various HUD icons and such. After that, its up to you to explore and play around with things. The (arguably) nice thing about this game is that, unlike the X series, it seems difficult, if not impossible, to fatally screw up in the early stages of your game.Give that this is early access, there are, of course, some issues:  Choppy performance - I bold this because it made the game very difficult to play. I am not sure if its simply my machine, or if others are experiencing it too, but it is a tad annoying.  Enemies are too easy - I am not sure whether they get more difficult as you play and level up. At the moment, if feels somewhat final fantasy-ish in that early enemies are deliberately easier to give the player time to power up and such before throwing them to the wolves. If that is the case, then cool I suppose, but right now, given how easily I seem to be able to wipe the asteroid belt with these pirate's ships, I'm not sure why anyone would pick a fight with me at this point.  Weird random graphical bugs - Whilst switching from auto to manual targetting, suddenly thousands of beam weapon streams fired out from my ship, followed my curser wherever it went. Looked cool though.  Lack of clear explanations - It took me a little bit to figure out what the different colours on various commodity prices actually meant. Yes, I did assume that red meant something bad (probably a bad selling price) and green was good, but it would be nice to have a tooltip, or something, to confirm my gamer's hypothesis. I'm still not certain what yellow means.  Probably some other issues I've either forogtten, or those I"ll encounter as I play...Despite the issues mentioned, I think this will turn out to be a really awesome game. I'm quite impressed with what the developers have done so far, and look forward to more updates.

content:
r 3, 2014
												First off: I like this game quite a bit. It is neither too expensive, nor bad looking or somehow broken or buggy.This is a first impressions, not a 100% review, because the game is huge.The good stuff:- Fly around in space in your own "capital" ship. I put that in quotes, because your first ship is a small semi-freighter whatever, but packs quite a punch. Apparently you can go all the way up to cruisers, destroyers, carriers and stuff.- Simple, yet efficient trading system (X3 would have done good to use that). You can see all available goods for trade as well as best buy and sell prices on the star map and can automaticall plot a course to the desired station.- Space looks good. Graphics are really not all that bad.- Combat is interesting in a sense that it's a mix between flying and shooting yourself and also using several skills to enhance damage, survivability etc. I'd just have hoped to have more interesting skills to use. You can also use items and fire your heavy guns like missiles etc. The coolest part, however, is to just have your turrets fire automatically while you concentrate on evading. This is not advised 100% of the time, but it's neat. Turrets will also have fire arcs to take into account. You can easily see the status of your shields and hull and can high tail it out of a fight with max engine power. You can also distribute power between engines, shields and weapons, so that is all very solid if basic (whoever played Freespace 2 for example knows what I mean). I would have liked to redistribute power from my forward shields to my rearward shields for example or have some sort of pause mode where I could issue my gunners or fighters to target a certain area of a ship. Either I just have not found a way to pause the game (because I see comments that it was supposed to be a thing) or it isn't there. I also don't know if you can target different subsystems on a ship. So far I have found an option to target "ship systems", but not individual ones. It would have been great to target a ship's engines or weapons individually to disable it, but I guess that would be a task better suited to fighters than capital ships. There are apparently also boarding torpedoes so you can take over enemy ships. The weapon types encompass all you really need, from railguns, to beams, plasma weapons, rockets and torpedoes. I'd just look forward to getting a bigger ship, but the only bigger thing I see costs a million credits and money is hard to come by if you don't invest a lot of time into trade or something like that. The cruiser even costs 15 million! Long way to go.- The map is huge and full of different factions and pirates.The not so good stuff:- You can apparently only have control over 1 ship (and some mercs) but not command your own fleet (maybe in an expansion or so I've heard), which is kind of disappointing, but ok. - Automated freighters. I don't see a possibility to have those either. You can own different ships, yes, but there seems to be no way to assign a freighter to go trading on his own in order to generate money while you do something more interesting, because seriously...trading is great and all but it IS extremely boring to have to fly the routes yourself every time...that is a ♥♥♥♥ing slow way of making money...but I think you can have stations or something like that at least...- The flight distance. Crossing from one point of the map to the other could potentially take a looooong time. There are fast travel routes, but those cost money...lots of money as far as I can see...that kinda sucks. There are also worm holes at least.- The campaign is...ugh...so utterly boring thus far? Go here, collect a core here, help this dude we totally don't even know or get to know...destroy a ship, bam 30 secs, go back...and all the while suffering through the TERRIBLE dialogue...I'm sorry, but this is definitely the weakest part of the game. Especially the main character just does not have an enticing voice to listen to in a game. Some spoken dialogue is even missing lol.- Scale. The fighting is a bit weird sometimes, because you don't even see a lot of the enemies you are shooting. At least not in the earlier stages of the game. Keeping track of multiple enemies in a fight is painful, because your automated gunners will not necessarily target your target, but whatever they damn well please. Also, the fighting is kind of weird some times. I've encountered an enemy that was apparently "impossible" for me to take on according to the game. I was level 1. I killed it. By staying on its tail and out of the reach of its main guns...really? ;) That was kind of anticlimactic...- Weapons and ships. I can currently buy some different ships and lots of different weapons systems and stuff, but it all seems worse than what I have, so either the game is not good at giving me information or there is no purpose in me buying new stuff. For example, I can buy a gunship for about 250k. That gunship has less hps than my starting ship, cannot carry missiles and has less power available, so why would I buy that? Also most weapons systems seem to deal less damage than what I have installed. That is weird.- Contraband. I once picked up illegal drugs from a destroyed ship. I was told I was entering an area where these drugs are illegal. I sold them. Nothing happened. Why can I sell this stuff at a station in a system where the drug is supposedly illegal? I don't get it.So, take everything with a grain of salt, but I'd say the game is definitely worth the asking price. If I had to rate it I would give it a solid 80+ I'd say. It does what it says it would do. It controls nicely, looks good and thus far I have not encountered any real bugs. There is always room for improvements and I hope an expansion or dlc will come out.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
3, 2016
												It's a space sim.If you expect soul-mouving roleplay or vast army battles or deep scale business management, you'll be disapopointed cause... it's a space sim.It's a pretty darn good space sim at that. It's pretty, atmospheric and quite fun to play.  There are a few bugs still out there but nothing major, nothing to break the game.  The map is huge.  You have good control over your ship and character. There are more factions than you need and there's always stuff happening.  Nothing heavilly scripted, it's all pretty much standard space sim missions.  Destroy that guy, smuggle this, escort that, repair this, explore that. You know.  Space sim.The voice acting is abysmal.  So abysmal, it's awesome.  Honestly, it feels like a game made by people who have a lot of love for the genre.  I expect to spend many, many more hours exploring space. I just throw a few Malcolm Reynolds one liners here and there and suddenly, I'm in space, doing space stuff. I'm cool like that. (I may or may not be taking meds regarding this)Oh and the music... I would have bought the game for the music alone.

												Super fun game.  Took me a while to get into it, but its fun.  If you liked the x series, Indy war, Rebel Galaxy etc this is great fun.  The atmosphere is great with a nice feeling of exploration, opening new sectors, finding derelicsts, enemies, etc.  Its open ended in a very assesable way.  Also, being captain of capital ships is a lot of fun with turrets, large weapons, crew and marines.  Super fun to capture other vessels by deploying your marines (best way IMO to make money early on).  Tons of fun stuff to do (mining, exploration, cap ships, smuggling, missions, etc.), and I haven't really played the campaign other than the first couple missions.  Also, the community is great and the developers are very hands on and make changes based on feedback.  Highly recommended.

Also, being captain of capital ships is a lot of fun with turrets, large weapons, crew and marines.  Super fun to capture other vessels by deploying your marines (best way IMO to make money early on).  Tons of fun stuff to do (mining, exploration, cap ships, smuggling, missions, etc.), and I haven't really played the campaign other than the first couple missions.  Also, the community is great and the developers are very hands on and make changes based on feedback.  Highly recommended.

content:
14, 2016
												Starpoint Gemini 2 is to space exploration games what Skyrim is to fantasy adventure games. Vast, full of lore and play styles and activities for everyone, and just so beautiful to stroll through and appreciate the scenery. The long list of buttons and actions appear daunting at first, but are easy to learn and facilitate a rich level of interactivity that makes an enjoyable experience for both the casual gamer and the hardcore strategist. Stats, activities and tricks offer a healthy challenge for micromanagement fiends, and movement and combat are simple yet satisfying enough for someone who has an actual job and no time to micromanage in a virtual world. Also like in Skyrim, the voice acting is endearing and the accents are so thick you could cut through them with a knife. It's not often I play a game with just the right balance of exploration, story, environment, gameplay and general polish that I don't mind playing all day on a day off. Also like with Skyrim, STEAM WORKSHOP! Can't wait to find some funny mods in the future. Little Green Men Games nailed it. 10/10, would buy for the wife and kids.

content:
10, 2015
												Did you like Privateer and Freelancer?  Did you read the reviews comparing this game to those, as well as Outlaw Star and other anime classics?  Don't believe them!  I did and I regret it.  If you like tutorials that are either outdated and no longer have any bearing on the game, or "tutorials" that are nothing more that a summary of key bindings, this game is for you.  (By the way, anyone who points out the shortcomings and is desperate to learn how to play the game they just bought are often derided as 5 year old simpletons in their tutorial forums.)Combat system is a joke:  The manual controls are wonky and attempting to manually control flight will send your ship into endless oscillations and fishtails.  If you let the computer take over this function by using the fire at will command, the ship stands still and shoots randomly at enemys off the edge of the screen, occasionally getting a hit but never resolving combat.  (I tried this, walked away for 1/2 hour, came back and it was still randomly firing at the same enemy with no real damage to my ship or theirs.)Don't care about combat and want to be a trader?  Good luck!  When you try to go somewhere, you are ambushed and drawn into combat, resulting in the frustration loop that I described above.Feels like an Alpha.  Despite what the developers say, this game is unplayable.  It has too many rough edges and still needs alot of work.Don't buy it.  I did and I regret it.Spend your money on X3, or some other legitimate franchise.

content:
er 27, 2015
												After a few hours in freeroam I feel like I've experience enough of Starpoint Gemini 2 to review it. First of all, this is mostly a classic space sim when playing in freeroam. It's mining/trading/mercenary grind to get better equipment and ships but it has some differences - there's skill points and experience levels, which is nice if you enjoy playing RPG's (I do)You don't start in fighter class ships. In fact - you can't fly the fighter class ships. You start in a Gunship class ship (or above if you have the DLC's). Your crew can man the turret hardpoints for you, and you will want them to. They are perfect shots every time. The turret AI is *very* good. You don't need to concentrate on weapons except to line up for heavy weapon shots, which are ammo limited but deal more damage per shot than your turrets. But....you probably won't even have to use them. Starpoint Gemini 2 has a problem if you're a pilot who knows basic concepts of space sim combat. If you can assess firing arcs, manage shield energy and experience in MMO type skill buffs, normal difficulty is a relaxing grind even if you take assassination missions 6 to 10 levels above your level. Most enemy ships don't have cloak scanners, so you can drop out and unleash hell with an undetected approach and take down "Deadly" and even with a little luck "Impossible" targets. This is a bit of a shame as this game wants to force you to fly combat role ships. I haven't seen ore freighters or transports. You can seemingly only buy Gunships and above with military kitting. Mining/Trading is viable but the cargo holds are disgustingly small and the mods that increase them in the workshop do not work with the DLC. You can not upgrade cargo capacity. If you're a frieghter captain your best bet is to get something with the biggest hold in the class which is marginally bigger than the rest and prepare to make MANY trips to and from asteroids and debris fields. Which is also a bit strange - asteroid and debris fields are EVERYWHERE, and you can't take advantage of it. Unfortunately most of the modders seem intent on putting in ridiculous godships instead of addressing the lack of civilian vessels. I usually like to play as a frieghter captain, in my game now I'm just a mercenary taking contracts well above my level for the massive increase in EXP and Credits. Overall I'm very pleased with this game. It's very underrated. I can expect I'll be putting many many more hours into it, as I have with X. This isn't Starpoint Gemini 1 for sure, and it's not the mess that is Star Wolves. It's not X either, but it's a better game than say Tachyon or Darkstar One and a nice alternative. Haven't played story yet. Not sure I will. Also this game and the Rebel Galaxy soundtrack works very nicely together. 10/10 Exploded a frigate as a gunship by exploiting cloak and firing arcs.

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
21
												Since it has drawn so much attention, i have played it recently to see what was new offline ( internet issues). For some reason it didnt show how much i played recently and my total is incorrect because i got the spacebuttplug ( tsar) and restarted a few times, played some of the story. so since you all are reading it, let me elaborate further, What i noticed that has changed, Gravity field of wormholes, wormholes are now working, some balancing stuff, same ship enemies dont go down as fast and use their abilities. Gameplay: The central game mechanic is the combat and trade system which are very tight, trade is simple but at times exploitable thanks to licenses and some close stations that are close by, no big deal though you can only get a few millions at most each run. Camera views, weapon systems etc were good but for the love of all that is space worthy why not include a database for weapons and enhancements like you did with trading? This might seem minor to you but it is infuritating to go to wiki ( which also turns the game to windowed so i have to restart) while same thing exists for trade. Gameplay is very solid which is why it got my hopes up. Those are pros mostly, cons would be mostly with presentation. Story: I must say i mainly played freeroam but when i did try story mode. Something about main character put me off. It might have been choosen one wibe i got from the start (son of an admiral and all that) not to mention his accent was strange. The voice acting was done by professionals this time i see but the ghost from starcraft 2 telling me where to go felt funny, love his accent and voice. Those are fine, what kind of broke it with me was that missions were presented through text that was in a box and UI designers would know, the things in small boxes should be small because for some reason we are not inclined to read all that. Nice flavor text on bouties though. 2 major problems with freeroam story, repetitive missions ( transport X to Y, or go here kill all that moves, very little flavor to it but if the surrounding fluff is good, that is all you need, world of warcraft did it. lots of games had repetitive missions that did not feel repetitive, Why? Answer in presentation )reputation that do not even feel like you are progressing, easier to read reputation bar and actually meaningful reputation would be nice.  I will explain the biggest problem that is connected to this in presentation. By meaningful some contact from faction representatives contacting you for special missions and thanking you for your help, you can go nuts from there. As it stands now. the only faction i know is trinity coz they have a weird space station. Presentation: Here is the place where i loved it and hated at the same time. Graphics are some of the best i have seen, sounds are great ( computer voice being modable is good too), ship designs are hit and miss but even the ones that are bad have something good about them such as tsar the spacebuttplug, it is pretty funny how it looks but is still intimidating. Tutorial is a bit annoying but the game is complex so its fine, takes practice but not as bad as many other games ( elite dangerous comes to mind, which i quit because 4D parallel parking in a flying box is not my fun)  The problem is, the real problem is despite all those great gameplay, the space is made lifeless, it would have been so easy just to add some flavor fluff like in rebel galaxy, visit a bar, with people, get some place specific music and visuals. Officers are nothing but stat sticks. In fact let me explain the crux of the problem by drawing comparison from world of warcraft and harry protter: In harry potter, wands are used for spell casting but are such a big deal and visible in the story that you know what they are and they make the universe feel complete. In WoW: They are stat sticks, something you forget you had and just use for stats exactly like officers here, wasted potential.That is why it is so painful to engage in all that space combat again and again, the space feel lifeless, like you are the only living thing in the galaxy. I understand your main thing was the gameplay and combat, i get it but you need to support it with other things. This could have been mount and blade in space easily. Why did mount and blade succeeded? Because outside of its outstanding combat ( just like this game), it had decent world building, there were lords who acted based on whats going on in the world, lords and ladies who talked, npc's who you would see face to face, so what if they had literally 2 lines of dialogue, it was still an improvement over a text box, It is even more painful when you see these gorgeous graphics but all this dead space. The only reason i considered rebel galaxy superior because it had this world building, world still felt shallow but it felt like a world, not a combat simulator. Remember why No Man's Sky failed? Trillions of planets that all felt same and lifeless? Here it is the same thing but here is is painful because it can be fixed so easily. As a side note: combat is meh compared to other RPG games, in space simulator genre, its pretty good ( but can you make the boarding a bit more interactive? Its a space sim not pokemon) I hope this wall of text explains your worries, again i played before and after writing this review  ( after since the reactions) I think it could be great but you need to work on the world building, it is simply inexcusable with such talent you guys got.

												A Freelancer-Style Space shooter with little rpg and the illusion of a sandbox.The main problem is... there is nothing to do. Unless you can pick it up for less than 5 bucks. It'll do for an afternoon, but nothing else.

content:
er 10, 2014
												Firstly, understand that although my review will say I've only logged 9 hours on this game, it's more like 20 because I played a lot in offline mode.This game is beautiful, both visually and with the music. But other than some eye candy and a few atmospheric soundtracks it doesn't feel like it has anything else going for it. Saving up for better ships is a slow grind, and combat becomes repetitive quickly. Once you get the better ships all you really accomplish is the ability to throw some more bullets/lasers at people at some different angles, but gameplay never fundamentally changes. Stronger enemies are just like the easier ones only they have more health and higher damage output, but you fight them all fundamentally the same way. The enemy AI is terrible; they have a self-preservation instinct akin to plastic ducks in a carnival shooting gallery. Killing enemies ranges from extremely easy to just downright tedious, but never feels challenging. The universe is clutterred with interesting stuff (real space doesn't have objects this close to each other) so there's no shortage of places to explore, but there's no real incentive to explore anything. One region might just be another solar system but with a blue nebula instead of a red one and the asteroids are made of some different resource. I'll give this game an alright/10. It's fun when you first pick it up, but playing for long periods will make the game stale quickly. I'm at a point where I want to play this game, but I just can't stomach flying around in space shooting at the same pirate ships to travel to some samey looking region- not for more than maybe 5 minutes at a time. I feel like there's nothing to do in this big universe the game presents. Hopefully the mod community will be able to salvage the game so I can feel like I got my money's worth.

content:
ry 10, 2016
												Pros:-It's pretty straightforward and fun. You don't need a month to learn all the controls.-lots of ships to collect and fill your garage-upgrades and things to spend money on-pretty good atmospheric space with things in itCons:-the ships feel a little same-y. After progressing from gunship through cruiser so far, there's little real difference-the missions feel a little same-y, side quests are just the same as the randomly generated quests. Main quests are only slightly different so far.-no dynamic economy, at least as far as I can tell. Gods are such small money compared to capturing ships and doing missions that you'll find yourself just hitting'sell all' instead of telling around for best pricesThis closest game to compare I've played is x2. This stacks up as a much simplified relative. It's more fun much faster, but there's also less depth. In x2 I would leave my computer running all day with time compression on and come back to see how much money I'd made reading. A game that can pay itself, and you build in the means to speed it up, should probably put a little more focus on fun. But it also was a much more engaging dog fighter. Here ask guns are on turrets, so the most effective combat is to just set them on automatic. Not the most engaging. The capture mechanic is decent, better than the x2 random bail out thing. But you can't command your own fleet and start and trade empire or manufacturing empire. There just seen to be fee ways to interact with the world. You can shoot things, scan them, grapple them, shoot them... I like the grapple mechanic by the way. But the ships don't feel different and lack a grand sense of scale. So yeah it's fun to capture and collect a bunch of ships, but the upgrades are a little wonky and there's not a ton to do outside of that. The weapons can be upgraded and swapped out, but all the other systems on the ship are fixed and can only have upgrades added. Why can't I customize whether I wasn't cloaking or a hanger? Style of pay is dictated by ship choice, not Games are cool and the most fun when you feel like you're discovering something special. An abandoned derelict that you can salvage for special items? Or one that's functional and maybe had a special feature. Hidden upgrades, officers, unique items that you can find as you explore would all help the depth of the game world. Overall 7.5/10Fun, but comes across a little flat. Could use some flair to make it feel more special.

content:
ry 26, 2016
												First off ignore my play time. I do most of my gaming at work and dont have an internet connection. Unfortunately Steam doesnt keep track of play time while in offline mode. As of writing this I have around 24 hours of gameplay in. In short this game is excellent and well worth the money.The universe is huge. And it would take a long while to fly from one side to the other. The ships are awesome. There is a lot to do.. You can be a trader, a pirate, a bounty hunter... The list goes on. It takes a lot of work to acquire new ships and level up. Not in a bad way.  I actually love it.. In my 24 hours of playtime I've only recently just captured a ship worth keeping and transferring to. Its not really grindy in my opinion as there is so much to do it seems you're all the time doing something different or new. I see that as a really good value for my money. I have only done 3 main/campaign quests at this point as you have to take time to level up and gear up for them. So its not a game you're going to beat within a few hours. Capturing ships better than yours is a real challenge and its very rewarding when you finally get one. So far Ive found capturing ships to be the funnest and most profitable thing to do. And when you finally get out of the starting gunship into something better it gets a little easier and much more profitable. The learning curve is easy. Not like learning X3 or anything. You can pick it up fairly quick.The game doesnt baby you.. You can run into a battleship that will destroy within minutes of starting the game so you always have to be careful and keep an eye out. There's always a challenge..It's not a game that will allow you to feel like a god that just steam rolls everything that comes along. I like that as it gives you something to strive for. However I will say now that I've gotten a better ship (Its a corvette btw) i come across a lot more ships that are weak or trivial. Its extremely cool when you come into an area with a bunch of them.. I just turn on Auto fire and watch my ship just destroy 5 or 6 ships within minutes.. It's awesome.So far the only things that Ive found to be less than great are the voice acting and traveling..The voice acting is far from good. Its not so bad that it destroys the campaign for you.. But its not good either lol. Your ships computer voice is great though and thats the one you'll hear 90% of the time. The traveling.. When you first start you dont really have a choice but to fly all the way to each location. As warp gates are expensive and not really an option at first. Worm holes do damage and really dont have enough of them to justify them as a good way to travel. Rifts help but they are kind of hard to stay in. So at first the traveling gets kind of old as the map is just so hufmge it can really take a long while to get from one point to another. But after you get a decent income going and you can afford the warp gates its not bad. All in all the game has been an excellent experience. And I feel the user rating should be quite a bit better than it is now. It's a game that I've quickly became addicted to and I already know I'll have hundreds of hours into before I get tired of it.If your looking for a good space rpg, sandbox, freelancer type game this one will not dissappoint.

content:
9, 2014
Early Access Review
								Starpoint Gemini 2 – ReviewHi everyone,This is my first ever review that I am writing.  I just bought the game last night and started playing this morning.  Before buying I read some other reviews just to get an idea if I should take the leap into the void.  Well, I took the leap (based on some good reports) and what I found was far from a void.  Here are some bulleted remarks:•	I was immediately impressed by the structure and layout of the game as soon as I entered. No nonsense.  Get in and get on with it.  I loved that.•	There is a lot of depth to the game with a creative insight to usability.  •	Personally I like the way the tutorial is incorporated into the start and the way that it is presented (simplicity and effectiveness).  Here are some thoughts:o	The font on the display was a little difficult for me to read (15`` screen, max settings), but that could be due to the screen size, not sure).o	At the start where you select from the three types of careers, it also might need a better font and colour scheme (just my personal opinion) to read a bit better. Everything still very good, don’t get me wrong.o	Would also advise to have a smart lady voice to read out tutorials as you go along, whilst displaying text (always keep the text).  Do not overcook and cause annoyance.o	Just mention within the tutorial that a “Collect all” indicator will pop up (after you destroyed an asteroid) once your close to the collectable. Was a bit unsure at first how I would collect, but became obvious when the pop up appeared to collect when I destroyed an asteroid up close.•	In- game graphics, display hub and layout is amazing. Great job.•	I absolutely love the small tutorial button, accessible at any time, especially when getting use to the game (keep it).•	Like that I can scroll up and down with mouse wheel in tutorial and other hud displays.•	Like that there is a info bubble over icons and other aspects.•	Love the idea of boarding and capturing ships and that you can do different things with those ships, brilliant.•	Great idea to be able to launch the whole or individually selected fighter wings and that there is criteria added to the fighter wings as well.•	Personally I like that there are asteroids all around to get some loot from and that it’s not just in pockets.I am a teacher by occupation and therefore I like clear and structured instructions.  I think the developers got this done well and that the "polishing" is going to make the tutorials and overall game experience even better and better.I love this game already and I have only been playing for a couple of hours.  I am super excited about what it is yet to deliver and the hours and hopefully years of joy I will get from venturing through this vast space full of life and challenges.If you love space sims you will not regret buying this game.  It is definitely worth the money for me below $17.I will try and write more reviews on the game as I continue to play.  Man, this is a lot of fun.

content:
31, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you happen to be a fan of science fiction and flying around in space, Then this game happens to be for you. There is no out of flight sections of this game or any gun fights that don't end in space. This game is purely a fly around and shoot things kind of game. The world is open to you from the start but you will find yourself overwhelmed in any other sections of space past the first planets, You can mine for ore's for money to buy over priced weapons and ships or you can destroy enemy ships (or allied) for higher grade loot and income, That said..Mining is safe and unrewarding, Unless you find yourself in the deepest part of space mining in the most dangerous of places you will not find anything worth the time spent. Meaning most of you're money will come from hunting down bandits right? Well, even this can become unrewarding quickly. Depending on you're situation you may find yourself battered from all sides or simply obliterating you're opposition, Movement quickly becomes clumsy in combat and you will find you're ship is rather slow compaired to everything else. That said, Combat can easily be just as rewarding as it is dissipointing, The game in the beginning will feel slow but more options will rise up to meet you as you advance to better ships. The game is also in Beta and many of these issues will probably be fixed, I'd buy it again, So maybe you will enjoy it.

content:
1, 2014
Early Access Review
								As it stands now, even in Beta, it's a gorgeus game, and you can have great fun with it if you are a fan of the X4 genre or the more arcadish space sims out there. Well worth the money asked for.But I feel it needs a little push in some directions. It can become much more than it is now, if given enough deep and polish. For instance, weapon stats are confusing, and they have no description. Uniqueness and a little story for each weapon/ship/commodity in the world would make it deeper. The huge starmap needs more deepness too, the different factions are not different enough, more involvement in each of them would make it more fun. You need to love some factions and hate others, to be really immersed in the world. Currently, there are only good guys, and bad guys. You shoot the bad guys, that's it :-). Voiceovers and images of the different factions are a must to achieve this.Balance is still a little off, but it's to be expected in beta after all. You can destroy large enemy ships (destroyers or battleships) with your starter ship, without much sweating, but overall it's very fun and asks you for fairly involved gameplay, you need to use special powers and equipment to see it through the large battles unscathed.I know for a fact that the team is constantly updating and expanding the game daily, so I have high hopes for it all to be fullfilled in the end.Must buy for every space combat, space trader lover out there!
