content:
9, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'll update my review as the game continues development.7/19/2014, First ImpressionsI bought Startpoint Gemini 2, in spite of not really caring too much for the first one, but since it was on sale, and since it seemed to be so popular, I thought I would give this development studio another shot.  So far, I am glad I did.  Being an early access game, I expected some features needing polishing, and other features not yet to be fully implemented, which indeed is the case at the time of this initial post.  Having said that, I must say I find the gameplay mechanics very interesting, and the combat compelling.  If you are a fan of the old "X" games (except for X: Rebirth), you'll find some familiar concepts such as trading and boarding.  I also enjoyed how functional the developers made their starmap, making it easy to find missions, side jobs, or other distractions, whilst providing a wealth of information such as reputation and factions of each sector.  My only complaint here, is the lack of a legend.  I hope, in the near future, that will be provided as an on/off toggle.The combat is fun and flexible.  With the ability to upgrade, enhance, or otherwise customise your ship, each ship type you are capable of flying provides a wealth of possible combat configurations to fit your playstyle, or to try out different tactics.  I found the tactical overlay in combat especially helpful, though I had to manually assign a hotkey for it.  Of course, being an early access game, there are several areas upon which they can improve, such as providing a text-based battle log, or some other method of communicating more detail on what exactly is happening.  For example, when targeting an enemy, you have no consistent view of their shields.  There is some kind of HUD element that pops up when you first target them, but it does not stay up, and there is no clue on how to consistently get the information available.  It would be nice to be able to see, at least, the target's shield status on a consistent basis.  Likewise, critical hits are communicated, but no details are provided, such as what systems were critically hit.The Skills & Perk system of your officer is pretty cool.  It adds a lot of depth by allowing skills to provide several affects at once, while at the same time keeping the amount of button mashing (or mouse clicking) to a minimum.I will say one thing in this "first impressions" entry, and that is I was disappointed at not being able to command a fleet whilst directly controlling a ship of my own.  It is my hope that the developers have plans to allow this, as some of the game menus and screens suggest (such as "fleet management"...implying the ability to manage more than one ship in your fleet).

content:
0, 2014
Early Access Review
								Great Potential.I have not touched the first Gemini, this is my first time into Gemini world. But I have been a huge fan for Freelancer, X3 series and EVE. Right now it feels like this game is pretty close to Freelancer in the sense of combat and universe design. It provides a huge universe for you to explore, combat whatever or whoever you see as enemy and different ways to gather credit.So far I think there are several problems with this game.1. The universe feels detached from the player. Of course this has something to do with the absense of campaign and a main plot, but the universe still feels lonely, even worse than X3.2. Some of the UIs need more work. Sometimes it is difficult to find out more information about an item. I hope the game can impliment something like the info page in EVE, which gives a full list of all the details about an item and you do not have to go around the place to find out or get confused.3. The combat. The combat is very similar to X3, you have several batteries on diffent side of your ship and they can be controlled independent of the ship. This is OK but when you are engaged in a multi ship combat, you will most likely lose the sense of situation. I hope a third person view can be implimented. Also the weapon/damage/energy balance feels a little strange. Most weapon will suck your energy dry while taking less than 25% of your enemy's shield. It looks like it is encouraging hit and run tactics which is perfectly fine for small agile ships. What bothers me is the big boys like battleships do not get a substantial upgrade on the battery energy. Other than those, I think this is an exciting game and it has a lot of potential.PS, it looks like the game has some hints of a fleet feature. I hope they can do it right because fleet in X3 is a nightmare. Eithre do it right, or don't do it at all.
